PETITION.TITLE: Census
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:

PARA.TAB: That the current practice of destroying the Census is denying future generations an invaluable and irreplaceable resource of data on medical, historical, social, scientific, and demographic factors.
Your Petitioners request that the Senate should:

Request the Government to review its current policy of destroying the Census; and support a proposal to retain the census forms for release for specific research purposes in either 70 or 100 years time.

PETITION.TITLE: East Timor
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned draws to the attention of the Senate Indonesia's continued denial of human rights to the people of East Timor.
Your Petitioners ask the Senate to call on the Australian Government to:
1. actively support all United Nations resolutions and initiatives on East Timor;
2. actively support the right to self-determination of the people of East Timor;
3. work for the immediate release of all Timorese political prisoners;
4. repeal the Timor Gap Treaty; and
5. stop all military cooperation and commercial military activity with Indonesia.

PETITION.TITLE: Marks Royal Commission
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned expresses widespread community concern about the Federal Labor Government's decision to pay Dr Carmen Lawrence's legal expenses in her legal challenges to stop the Marks Royal Commission.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate:
(a)note and endorse the concerns expressed in this petition; and
(b)call on the Government:

TAB.TAB: (i)to publish full details of the basis of the decision by Cabinet, including copies of official advice; and
(ii)to immediately reverse the decision and cease public funding of attempts to stop Commissioner Marks finding the truth about the Penny Easton petition.

PETITION.TITLE: French Nuclear Testing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned expresses the widespread community outrage throughout Australia at the decision of the French Government to resume nuclear testing in the South Pacific.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate note and endorse the concerns expressed in this petition and convey to the French Parliament in the strongest terms Australia's opposition to this decision.

PETITION.TITLE: Landmines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned shows that we citizens of Australia support a world-wide ban on the production, stockpiling and use of all forms of anti-personnel land mines.

Your Petitioners request that the Senate support our call for a world-wide ban on the production, stockpiling and use of all forms of anti-personnel land mines, give high priority to support for efforts to clear land mines in affected countries and use its influence to encourage other countries to financially support the clearance of land mines in poor countries.

PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We are dismayed at the continuing destruction of old growth and wilderness forests around Australia, despite the National Forest Policy Statement jointly signed by the Commonwealth and all States except Tasmania.

Intensive logging, most often to feed a voracious woodchip industry is underway or planned for many high conservation value forests. These forests should be protected by the commitments of the Commonwealth and State Governments under the NFPS.
These forests include:

PETITION.PARA: Coolangubra Wilderness and other areas of the S.E. Forests of NSW along with rainforest and other N.E. areas of NSW including Wingham, Mistake, Richmond Range, Chaelundi, North Washpool, Barrington and Dorrigo.
The Southern Highlands, Great Western Tiers and Tarkine Wilderness of Tasmania.
The Karri and Jarrah forests of S.W. Western Australia.
The Errinundra Plateau and other areas of the East Gippsland forests of Victoria.
The rainforests of the Proserpine region of Queensland.

PARA.TAB: We request that the Government act urgently to protect our precious forests by utilising the Commonwealth's legal and constitutional powers, including:

PETITION.PARA: Protection of areas listed on the register of the National Estate
Protection and effective funding of areas identified for their World Heritage values.

PARA.TAB: Genuine and effective action by the Government to protect these and other old growth and wilderness forests is critical. A comprehensive plantation strategy rather than exploiting native forests is the way forward for a truly environmentally responsible timber industry. We further request that the Government take effective action without further delay.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows: the unjust and inequitable nature of the Government's policy to restrict Childcare Assistance where a parent is outside the workforce to 12 hours per week. This policy will cause hardship to lower income families, to the children of those families, and child care workers. The Government should be condemned for breaking its promise to ensure access and affordability in child care.

Under the Government's policy parents will have to pay full cost fees after 12 hours of childcare per week if one parent is outside the workforce. This will widen the gap between rich and poor, and many child care workers may lose their jobs.
Your petitioners therefore ask that the Senate should oppose the passage of this Bill into law.

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned, call on all members of the government, and in particular the Prime Minister, as the representatives of the Australian people to show strong, continuous and vigorous opposition to the French nuclear weapons testing in the Pacific Region .
We ask the government to stop the sale of uranium to all foreign powers.
We call on the government to send a frigate to Muroroa Atoll as an official protest.

Dear Minister

The Committee noted your advice that the retrospective instrument does not impose financial liability on any person other than the Commonwealth. 22 September 1995
Senator M Colston
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Colston
I refer to your letter of 28 August 1995 and the notice of motion in Parliament on 31 August 1995 to disallow Determination HS/1/1995 made by me under section 3C of the Health Insurance Act 1973.

As you are aware, the health funds are not required to pay "gap" benefits for the service covered by the determination for the period of retrospectivity, i.e. from 1 November 1994 to 26 May 1995. The clause in the determination specifying that section 4 of the National Health Act does not apply for this period is necessary as the Acts Interpretation Act precludes retrospectivity in legislation if it imposes a financial liability on any person or organisation other than the Commonwealth. Nevertheless, patients are still entitled to receive a benefit of 75% of the Medicare Benefits Schedule fee.

I felt that this was a reasonable compromise, which allowed patients some benefit but did not disadvantage the health funds through a retrospective arrangement. Without this determination patients would have received no benefit at all.

The determination corrected an anomaly whereby no Medicare benefit was payable for the specified service. The Health Insurance Commission had been holding claims pending the determination which was made retrospective to allow payment of these claims. Under the determination, patients are entitled to a Medicare rebate of 75% of the specified fee from 1 November 1994 to 26 May 1995, with a 100% entitlement from 26 May (i.e. 75% Medicare benefit plus 25% fund "gap" benefit) for insured patients. An item to cover the service is included in proposed amendments to the health insurance regulations to be introduced from 1 November 1995.
The effect of disallowing the determination will be to deny patients any benefit for the service until 1 November 1995.
I request that you withdraw your notice of motion to have this determination disallowed.
Yours sincerely
Dr Carmen Lawrence

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Administrative Decisions (Effect of International Instruments) Legislation

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, contingent on the Senate concluding its consideration of any item of business and before the next item of business, being the Administrative Decisions (Effect of International Instruments) Bill 1995, is called on on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: (1)That, for the reasons set out in paragraph (2), so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Chamarette moving a motion that consideration of the bill be postponed until 2 sitting days after the Minister representing the Attorney-General (Senator Bolkus) tables a copy of the report of the review, announced by the Attorney-General on 5 July 1995, of the effect of international instruments on administrative decision-making.
(2)That the reasons referred to in paragraph (1) are as follows:

TAB.TAB: (a)on 7 April 1995 the High Court, in the Teoh case, held that the `legitimate expectation' doctrine applies when the Government ratifies a treaty;
(b)that doctrine has been part of the common law since 1969;

(c)one of its effects is that people have a legitimate expectation to be informed, consulted and heard when the Government decides to depart from its international obligations and this affects people who might otherwise have relied on the expectation that the Government would adhere to such obligations;

(d)the doctrine does no more than create a procedural, not a substantive, right, it does not oblige the Government to adhere to its international obligations, but only to inform, consult and listen to those likely to be adversely affected by decisions which do not so adhere;

(e)the bill is designed to destroy that procedural right and as such it has been the subject of condemnation by almost every significant legal figure and organisation involved in human rights and international law;
(f)the Attorney-General has announced a review of the effect of international instruments on administrative decisions;

(g)that review, by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission and th e Attorney-General's Department, has no reporting date and is to have no additional resources to facilitate its completion;
(h)it is improper, if not absurd, for the Government to require the Senate to debate the bill before either the Government or the Senate has the benefit of the findings of that review; and
(i)debate on the bill should, therefore, be postponed until the review is tabled.

SPEECH.PARA: 28 August 1995
Senator the Hon Bob Collins
Minister for Primary Industries and Energy
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister
I refer to the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Code Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1995 No.137, considered by the Committee at its meeting of 24 August 1995.

The regulations double almost all of the fees relating to the assessment of relevant chemicals for registration. The Explanatory Statement does not give reasons for the increases and the Committee would welcome your advice.
Yours sincerely
Mal Colston
Chairman
26 September 1995
Senator MA Colston
Chairman
Senator Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Colston

Thank you for your letter of 28 August 1995 seeking advice as to the reason why most of the fees relating to the assessment of agricultural and veterinary chemicals by the National Registration Authority for Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals (NRA) were doubled by means of the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Code Regulations (Amendment).

The NRA recovers its costs by a three-tiered fee scheme, namely a levy on sales of agricultural and veterinary chemicals, annual reregistration fees on agvet chemicals, and application fees for the various tasks undertaken by the NRA. Additionally, in 1995/96, the Commonwealth is contributing $ 50 000 to fund the Minor Use Program.

In 1995/96 the NRA will receive $12.8 million, the levy providing approximately 50% of that amount and the reregistration fees and application fees each providing approximately 25% each. The application fees were, of course, the subject of the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Code Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1995 No 137.

Full cost-recovery for the NRA has been introduced in a phased manner. In 1994/95 the rate of cost-recovery was 83.3%, and in 1995/96 it will be almost 100%, with, as noted above, only $50 000 being contributed by the Commonwealth. The NRA has therefore needed to raise extra funds commencing, on 1 July 1995 to cover this higher level of cost-recovery.

Prior to this recent amendment to the regulations application fees only covered a small portion of the actual cost of assessing applications. Accordingly, it was felt that, while some supplementation of application assessment costs by way of reregistration fees and the levy was appropriate, the then-prevailing level of cross-subsidy, or supplementation, was too great. The recent doubling of application fees brings application fees closer to the real cost of assessing applications.

In the early part of 1995 the NRA completed a review of its fee structure, and provided me with the results. The NRA received 53 submissions from industry in drawing up its report, and advised that adoption of the recommendations was widely supported by industry. The NRA also advised that the proposed fee changes reflected proposals from the two main industry organisations, Avcare and the Veterinary Manufacturers and Distributors Association.
Yours sincerely
(Bob Collins)

That the Austudy Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1995 No. 132 and made under the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973, be disallowed.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government welcomes the support of the opposition parties for the Austudy actual means test. I am pleased to advise that, in response to concerns raised by opposition senators in recent discussions, the government can assure the Senate that, firstly, only a small minority of Austudy clients are expected to be affected by the test. Around two per cent of the Austudy client base is expected to be ineligible for Austudy under the actual means test. Secondly, the majority of clients subject to the actual means test will need to complete only the four questions on the Austudy application form which will provide a broad picture of their overall financial circumstances.

PARA.TAB: Thirdly, the actual means test will take into account the means of the student applying for Austudy, the means of the parents or partner of the student, whether there are any dependent children in the family under 16 years of age and whether there are any full-time dependent students in the family aged 16 to 21. Fourthly, the actual means test will not target parents on the basis of their choice to send their children to non-government schools. Fifthly, the government will publicly release a review of the actual means test within the first two years of its operation.

I also make clear in response to a further concern, which was raised by Senator Baume, that families subject to the actual means test will not be precluded from Austudy solely on the basis of bona fide gifts from otherwise non-assessable family members given solely for education purposes and not exceeding $6,000 per annum in total for each dependent student aged 16 to 21. For its part the government believes that the actual means test is a fair, equitable and cost effective method of ensuring that Austudy assistance is provided only to genuinely needy families.

Austudy is aimed at students from the neediest sectors of society. For example, for a 16-year-old person living at home in 1995, the standard rate of Austudy normally cuts off at a combined parental income of $31,687. This represents a take-home income of $24,727. The actual means test responds to community concerns that a small number of students get Austudy even though their families clearly have financial resources well in excess of the take-home pay of the Austudy target group.

The actual means test applies to all students who have a parent or partner in one of the designated groups. These students will be required to demonstrate that their families' actual means, as measured by their expenditure and savings in the year of study, do not exceed the take-home pay of an equivalent pay-as-you-earn family.

The test does not apply to families where parental or spouse income is drawn exclusively from wage and salary or pension sources. The real means of such families are adequately assessed by existing Austudy income and assets tests. The actual means test will be administered through a two-stage assessment process which will ensure that needy clients will not face administrative barriers or delays.

The four key expenditure questions on the Austudy application form provide a broad overview of the family's circumstances. The majority of clients will satisfy the actual means test on the basis of this information alone. These clients will then be assessed for Austudy on the basis of the usual income and assets tests. Only where the apparent expenditure of the family exceeds the take-home pay at which Austudy is normally payable will the family need to provide more detailed financial information.
The government believes that the actual means test will address community concerns about rorting of the Austudy scheme. I urge the Senate to vote against this motion to disallow the regulations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, will you table the document from which you have been quoting? I think it would be helpful to all concerned.
—I am happy to table that for you.

I also want to recognise the work that has been done by my colleagues Senator Baume and Senator Tierney to improve the lot of Australian families that will have to face this new test. My colleagues entered into a process of consultation with the minister's staff and finally obtained from the minister the assurances that Senator Faulkner read into the record this morning. Whilst we believe that the situation is improved, we are still quite concerned about the application of this new test that will apply principally to the self-employed.

It should be unnecessary to say that we support the Austudy system, because I would have thought the whole world knew it. But, apparently, the Australian Labor Party has started a fear campaign in various universities around the country, telling students that when we come to office we will scrap it. That is just another Labor lie, Senator Faulkner, but we might as well take the opportunity to put it on the record in a clear and unambiguous way that we support Austudy. If the Australian people choose wisely and put us into office at the forthcoming election, the Austudy system will continue.

We also accept the concerns, particularly those that came out of the Senate standing committee, which called for better targeting. The government, of course, says that this is an initiative at better targeting. We obviously do not support rorting of the system and, in fact, the government claims that through these anti-avoidance measures it will be able to save some $29 million a year. That is yet to be seen, but it must be understood that when further and more complex tests are applied, not only do they involve more work on behalf of the families of those who are seeking the benefit but also there is the danger that some who justly deserve the benefit will be excluded as a result of the additional tests.

The issue is whether the tests have been drawn in a way that is fair and adequately precise. In this instance, in relation to these new tests that are to be applied to the self-employed, there is a concern that comes out of their ambiguity and their extreme complexity. That is one of the concerns, and I think anybody who has sat down to read the formula contained in these regulations will only be shocked at the obvious complexity. One must wonder if it is not beyond the wit of our government and its bureaucracy to produce something that most Australians would be able to understand, because most Australians certainly would not be able to understand these regulations. That has to be of concern to the parliament.

The assumption that seems to underlie these regulations—that it is those who are self-employed and it is those in small business who are particularly rorting the system—is an assumption that the government does not justify on the basis of factual material. I guess in some ways it might just further demonstrate the prejudice of this government: that if there is an abuse, you first assume that it is an abuse by those who are self-employed, those who are in small business and those who are creating wealth and providing jobs. I think it is rather sad that it seems to be the natural assumption of Labor governments.

Beyond the issue of complexity, however, is the issue as to whether the tests, the further requirements that are being placed upon individuals, are reasonable. I think there is still room for very significant debate as to whether the government has gone beyond what is reasonable.

However, we must be conscious of the fact that if there is rorting, it has to be overcome and the taxpayers' dollar has to be protected. We have certainly approached this debate on that basis—to try to get the balance between what is fair to the taxpayer and what is fair to families who need the support of Austudy is, of course, a challenge that we accept. We have also been influenced by the statement of the government that, unless these regulations can be now settled, it will be impossible for them to be implemented for this next year.

On balance, in the light of the additional assurances that Senator Baume and Senator Tierney have been able to extract from this government, we have therefore decided that we will not support the motion. Notwithstanding the fact that the government says that the practice of the regulations will be reviewed within two years, if we are successful at the next election we will commence an immediate review of them; we will not wait for that two-year period. From the position of government we will want to be satisfied that they are fair, that they are not unduly intrusive and that they are not prejudicial to those who are self-employed as opposed to those who are employed.

In the hesitant frame in which we say that we will not support this disallowance motion, we want to give those assurances. It is much easier, in many ways, to do a job such as that from within government than it is from opposition. We certainly undertake to do that upon coming to government. But, on balance and in the circumstances that I have outlined, we will not be supporting the disallowance.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—While I realise that I made a contribution when Senator Harradine moved the disallowance, we have had presented to us some further information which has addressed some of our concerns. It is important to respond properly to that. I am a member of the Senate Employment, Education and Training References Committee which inquired into Austudy. We received submissions from the public and from interested parties. Mention has been made this morning that part of the concerns the committee raised were concerns that there was potential for rorting of the Austudy payments, and that potential existed in those who are able to manipulate their taxable income.

PARA.TAB: The committee had a great deal of difficulty in getting beyond the anecdotal evidence. We actually found it impossible to gain from the public, from departmental witnesses, from dispassionate observers or from academics anything other than anecdotal evidence that such rorting occurred. Inquiries were made, and I must claim to have been persistent in those inquiries myself, but we were unable to obtain objective evidence as to how such rorting occurred, who was perpetrating it and how they were managing it. It is in response to the anecdotal evidence and not really in response to powerful objective evidence that was placed before the committee.

One of the problems is that, while the general public might claim to know of somebody, proving it is another matter because if you could prove it then the rorting would probably not occur. In the light of that, we have this response that was embodied in the regulations to which Senator Harradine has objected. I have received assurances, similar to those which the minister has expressed today, from the department that this is the way in which that response will be driven.

My concern is that these are assurances, and assurances from ministers have been received before. I am concerned about what the status of these assurances is and about what authority those assurances would have under the Acts Interpretation Act in the administration of the regulations as they stand in writing, in law. It is all very well under the Acts Interpretation Act to be aware of the intentions of the minister as expressed in a second reading speech, but this is not a second reading speech. The document tabled is speaking notes. We have a list which is quite specific and reasonably detailed. I think we could have asked for perhaps even more detail.

We have had bald statements but we do not have any indication of guidelines for the administration of the regulations and what will be put in front of officers. One thing which did emerge from the inquiry and did form part of our recommendations was the constant demonstration—real objective evidence—that there were hundreds, if not thousands, of incidents where the advice received at one level of the department administering Austudy was contradicted by advice given at another level, compromising the people applying for and people receiving Austudy to such an extent that quite often people had been in receipt of inappropriate amounts and had to carry the blame themselves.

To put it plainly, we saw reason to recommend that there be a system implemented of recording advice in writing so that people receiving advice could demonstrate why they acted the way they did and why they were in receipt of the amount of money they were. So having recorded advice was one of our recommendations and increased training of staff was another.

We were impressed negatively by the complexity of the regulations and the administration, something Senator Hill has also pointed to. We also expressed a need to recognise the need for flexibility in the administration of the Austudy threshold points, in applying or not applying Austudy provisions, and in the calculation of incomes. This is really an expression of that—a flexibility. We have also introduced this concept of the means test. One wonders what the means test means if it is not an actual means test. I know what it means but when you are talking about regulations and accuracy, we have to be careful about definitions.

So, in the light of those things, I bring a greater uncertainty than the one Senator Hill has expressed. We have to emphasise the advantage that has been brought to us this morning by the actions of Senator Harradine in his moving to disallow these regulations. The reaction has been to provide us with assurances. I am questioning the status of those assurances. I do not know what the minister can do at this point to reinforce or amplify these assurances but we have to be very careful about accepting that this is the be all and end all of the situation.

It is to some extent satisfactory to see a reaction of this sort to Senator Harradine's motion to disallow. But I am very wary about expressing any faith in this being the complete solution because of the possibility, as was raised during the debate initially, of there being abuse of these regulations by the administrators to an extent which will deliver hardship and inequities to the recipients of Austudy. Those possibilities still remain and are not completely removed by these assurances. That is the problem. The problem has arisen because the gap—I think Senator Baume introduced that concept, and it is a very useful one—between what is intended as expressed by the minister and what is potentially to be delivered by the regulations is considerable. This assurance goes a long way towards reducing that gap. But I still remain to be convinced that it will mean the complete resolution of that problem.

I am sorry that I cannot suggest what the minister could do this morning by way of amplifying that assurance. It is his responsibility to convince us that the possibilities of the inequities which we described in the earlier debate will not happen. It is up to him to devise a way to not only assure us but also prove to us that it will not happen. I accept the assurances and the good faith in which they were prepared, but I remain to be convinced.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly on this debate. On balance, the Greens will not be supporting this disallowance motion. The fact that $28 million is expected to be collected by the government on this measure and that 12,500 students are expected to be cut off will mean that quite a lot more students would be required to fill out the form. That would work out to be a considerable compliance cost in relation to the small business community.

PARA.TAB: Two years down the track would seem to be a long time to work out whether the compliance cost to the community is being balanced out by the increased revenue that the government is earning. I add my voice to the call that waiting two years would seem to be too long to make sure whether the way that this is being done is fair.

I certainly have not seen a copy of the Austudy form in question, so it is difficult to know how long it would take a family of an Austudy applicant to fill out the form. If possibly 12,500 students are expected to be cut off, one would expect that a great deal more would be required to fill out the form. What kind of proof is required and so on is not something to which I am currently privy. It would seem a long time to wait. If there might end up being a couple of million dollars in compliance costs across the country, we would certainly like to find out in less than two years whether the government is collecting $28 million, whether people are being unfairly targeted and whether it is producing yet another compliance cost for small business. I am not against the principle that the government seems to be aiming at. However, we want to see its actual effect and how it operates. We would have appreciated receiving a copy of the form so that we could find out exactly what people are going to be asked to fill out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Battling Australians whose children are excluded from Austudy because they are not poor enough have every reason to be angry at rich people using sneaky devices to get Austudy for their children. Let us get this clearly on the record. That is the opposition's strong view. However, I commend Senator Harradine for moving the disallowance motion. I was keen to do so myself, but I am overjoyed that Senator Harradine did it.

PARA.TAB: He has provided us with the opportunity to narrow the gap, as Senator Bell pointed out, between what the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) said was the intention and what the Department of Employment, Education and Training came up with. Quite frankly, I do not regard these regulations as acceptable, reasonable or even decent. They are discriminatory and unfair. As Senator Bell said, we have narrowed the gap between the intention of the minister, which was to target bids, and what the department has done, which was, in the regulations, to hit one-third of total Austudy applicants.

I am concerned, as is Senator Margetts, about the compliance costs. That emerges from a speech I gave a couple of weeks ago when this matter first came up. However, we have a double task. We have to resolve the conflict between the need to stop what is claimed to be $29 million of rip-off and the need properly to inquire as to people's means and whether they are entitled to Austudy. On the other side of the ledger, we must not impose an unfair burden on a particular section of the community, the section of the community that happens to be self-employed because, in many cases, they have lost their jobs under the recession we had to have; or who are in partnership, in many instances with their wives or other family members; or who have a share, no matter how small, in a proprietary company.

If ever there was an example of how not to prepare a set of regulations, it seems to me this is it. Here we have the minister targeting a narrow group, two per cent of Austudy recipients, who are claimed to be rorting the system and you belt about one-third of applicants with, on the face of it, regulations requiring presentation of massive detail as to expenditure and savings, some of which is grossly unfair because it does not take into account the costs involved in those expenditures. PAYE income is a net income to the recipient. Expenditure is gross expenditure.

The principle that has been applied in this matter is absolutely appalling. It represents a lack of basic understanding of or concern about that section of the community which is self-employed, or in partnership or has a share in a proprietary company. What a disgrace! Fancy having a share in a proprietary company! You must be a filthy capitalist! This attitude is totally unacceptable.

These amendments adversely affect about one-third of claimants by reclassifying as designated parents who face an additional means test all parents or guardians who are self-employed, except farmers; who are in partnerships; who have an interest, no matter how small, in a trust—some superannuation funds are trusts—or a proprietary company; or who have overseas assets or income. That phrase `overseas assets or income' interested me. It appears from the evidence presented to the Senate committee that this may well be a major area of concern.

As Senator Bell pointed out, there is no hard and fast evidence about where this rorting comes from. In my negotiations and discussions with the department I could get nothing other than anecdotal complaints from people who, quite rightly, might live next door to someone who drives a Mercedes Benz, who lives in a large two-storey house, who has a live-it-up lifestyle and whose kids are getting Austudy. I would have thought we could have done better than some anecdotal evidence. Nonetheless, I am intrigued about how the department got the view in the first place that $29 million was the amount of savings. Being a trusting chap, I am prepared to accept their broad brush view that about two per cent of people are rorting the system.

The trouble is that to get these two per cent, these amendments to the regulations clearly discriminate against small business people without any evidence being presented that they are a major source of abuse of the system. As I have said before, the minister's press release and the report of the recent Senate inquiry suggest that permanent residents, rather than citizens of Australia with foreign assets, are the key target area.

The department did give me—and I am grateful for them—oral assurances that designated parents would only be required to answer four additional questions among the 70-odd in the Austudy form. There is no doubt that parents have to have received a decent sort of education to be able to cope with the form in the first place. This is required in order to establish the target group that will be obliged to provide full details of their expenditure and savings to establish their entitlement to Austudy.

The first of the four questions that it is intended to be asked is: give details of your principal family home, the current market value and address. That is not information that is obliged to be provided by people who are PAYE income earners and who do not have these other `assets'. The second question is: give the current market value of any other properties or investments, including holiday houses and share portfolios in which any family member has a personal interest. Any family member. I am grateful that the minister has clearly indicated that that is a fairly limited question. We have got an assurance now about how you define family member. The question continues: include properties in Australia and overseas.

The third question is: give details of current market value of any motor vehicle which any family member uses. I do not know whether a Comcar driver can be accused of using a motor vehicle if in fact he is entitled to drive that Comcar home after work and to drive that Comcar to work the following morning. There may be many people in that situation who may well have access to a vehicle owned by the business they work for or, in fact, may be in partnership in a lawn mowing business and so on. Anyway, given those problems, I acknowledge the need for these lifestyle tests.

The fourth question is: give the total education expenses, including tuition and boarding costs, for all family members in 1996, deducting any fees waived. The department describes these as four lifestyle questions, the answers to which, in combination—that is the key word—will provide a clear indication of those who are in the high risk group of Austudy abuse according to the department. We do not know because, as I said, apart from anecdotal evidence, we have not seen it. I am prepared to accept the department's view—they are experts in this area; they have been listening to complaints for a long time—that that is an area of risk.

What concerned me at the time was that the question on education, which is the only one on expenditure in that four, appears to target families with students in non-state schools, which is contrary to the strong finding of the recent Senate report that `any targeting of non-government schools in an effort to reduce rorts would be totally inappropriate'. Administrative procedures, in my view, such as these under the regulations, have the potential to cause the greatest discrimination. The regulations themselves are bad enough; the administrative procedures give a capacity to create greater discrimination. Unfortunately, until today, there were no directions, either in the regulations themselves, nor in any ministerial statement to the parliament or press release, to indicate how these discriminatory regulations should be implemented.

The problem that I faced—and I do not know whether Senator Harradine or Senator Bell in particular are concerned about this—is that the department advised me that if these regulations were disallowed, it would be unable to implement any replacement regulations to stop the abuse for the 1996 year. Apart from anything else, it has distributed enough forms to cater for 500,000 Austudy places for the year beginning 1 January.

As far as I am concerned, the department created that problem. It is the department's fault. The normal processes of the parliament should be taken into account when departments are putting up regulations of this kind. The fact that Senator Harradine moved a disallowance motion does not excuse the department from not giving itself enough time to take this sort of thing into account. The department, in effect, took the parliament for granted and that is not acceptable.

However, the coalition and I have no desire to block the end of the rorting of Austudy by cheats. We do not wish to put ourselves in a position, because we are saying that these regulations are not good enough, where people can get away with almost $30 million by ripping off taxpayers. That is why I was so determined to try and find a solution to the problem, and why I was so determined to try and get, if you like, a set of riding instructions from the minister to ensure that these regulations would involve the minimal amount of discriminatory activity that is possible whilst still achieving the objective of stopping the rorts. We have a conflict of principle here.

I acknowledge the fact that the regulations are still unsatisfactory. I acknowledge the fact that the department fought tooth and nail to retain them unaltered—and I think that is a mistake by the department. I have had a very reasonable and decent level of cooperation extended to me by the department. We had many, many lengthy discussions, in one of which Senator Tierney was involved. We had many discussions extending over many hours both in my offices and on the telephone. I am grateful for the time given by the department. However, I found it unfortunate that the department appeared to be so determined to dig in its toes on some matters that I thought were indefensible.

However, I have to thank the minister and the Hon. Ken Reed in the minister's office for their very, very cooperative, rational and sensible approach aimed at trying to resolve these problems. The whole point of this sort of discussion is to resolve problems; not to dig yourself into entrenched positions. I hope that the department might have learnt a few lessons from the minister's office about how to do this. I did not find the way that the department went about things acceptable.

There is no doubt that the burden of benefit does lie in allowing the regulations to stand, provided that we have the sort of ministerial statement that is now being made to the parliament which is effectively giving directions as to the implementation of the regulations. My understanding is that these assurances bind the secretary when he, under these regulations, has to satisfy himself that someone who is a designated parent has not in fact exceeded the equivalent income level for someone who is a notional parent—in other words, a normal parent.

If, as Senator Bell says, he is reluctant to accept assurances, I can only say that we will find out, when we have our inquiry into this early next year from government, whether in fact the secretary has felt himself bound by the ministerial instruction. I might say that any secretary of any department who did not find himself so bound would presumably be looking for another job under the sorts of arrangements that now exist in the upper echelons of the Public Service.

That is not a threat; that is just stating the reality. The parliament is seeking to bind the secretary in getting this assurance. Let there be no doubt about the intention of the parliament if these regulations are passed. Let there be no doubt about it at all. This debate itself normally must be taken into account in any disputes over these matters before any tribunals, such as the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

I sought an assurance that the regulations would not be used to target parents of students solely on the basis of their children attending non-state schools. Apart from the discriminatory nature of the regulations as they appear in terms of self-employed people, there was a clearly different treatment of people in non-state schools as against those people in state schools in the sense that expenditure on education was singled out as the only expenditure item in the four lifestyle questions. I am very glad to see the way the minister has recognised those concerns and acted upon them.

For the record, I want to say how much I appreciate the letter I received this morning from Mr Free. I sought an assurance that the regulations and the administrative arrangements are aimed at only about two per cent of Austudy applicants so that only a small proportion of designated parents will be required to provide full details of their expenditure and that this targeted group will be determined on the basis of no more than four lifestyle questions.

The response from the minister was that only a small minority of Austudy students are expected to be affected by the test, about two per cent of all Austudy clients are expected to be ineligible for Austudy under the actual means test and the majority of clients subject to the actual means test will need to complete only the four questions on the Austudy application form which will provide a broad picture of their overall financial circumstances.

The minister gave me an assurance at my request that the actual means tests and question 70 take into account the means of the student applying for Austudy, the parents or partner of the student, any dependent children in the family under 16 years of age and any full-time dependent students in the family aged 16 to 21. In other words, if a grandmother, an aunt or whoever it happens to be decides to pay the school fees of the student, that person is not a member of the family for the purposes of the actual means test.

I sought, and got, an assurance that the actual means test will not target parents on the basis of their choice to send their children to non-government schools. In other words, that test alone cannot be the only test which excludes someone from receiving Austudy. The minister gave me an assurance that the government will publicly release a review of the actual means test within the first two years of its operation. As Senator Hill has already said, we will do that a lot quicker when we reach government.

I had also wanted to make certain that if a grandmother, an aunt or someone like that paid a child's education expenses, particularly at a non-government school, that is not counted against that student applying for Austudy because it is not counted against the student, up to a limit of $6,000, of a PAYE taxpayer. All I was seeking to do was to get rid of the discriminatory treatment of a self-employed person as against someone who is simply a PAYE taxpayer or benefit recipient, because something like 40 per cent of Austudy parents are in receipt of benefits. I wanted there to be no discrimination.

I must say, it took a long time for me to convey this view effectively to the department, which disappointed me. In any event, the minister and his office readily recognised the merit of what I was saying and, as a result, they have given me an assurance. The minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: After consideration I am prepared to give the further undertaking that families subject to the actual means test will not be precluded—
in other words, the 30-odd per cent who enter this description of a designated parent—

from Austudy solely on the basis of bona fide gifts given solely for education purposes not exceeding $6,000 per annum in total for each dependent student aged 16 to 21 from otherwise non-assessable family members.

I am very pleased indeed that all these concessions have been made. They make these regulations, if I can use the expression, less worse. They are not ideal; they are less worse. They are significantly less worse than they were. I hope that the experience the department has had in dealing with the parliament over this and the clear expression of the parliament's views—which I think are evident from the minister's own statement and what has been said in this chamber—will encourage the department to act with discretion and reasonableness in its administrative procedures. It is under instructions to do so. I can assure the department that we will be watching and that we look forward to that scrutiny to ensure that it is doing so as soon as possible.

PARA.TAB: Finally, I thank the minister and his office for their cooperation. I thank the department for the amount of time it has taken in dealing with my matters. I want to assure the Australian Parents Council, who are very unhappy indeed about Austudy regulations—not specifically these ones but a whole range of Austudy regulations—that we share a great deal of their concerns and will be examining this matter in office very closely indeed.

There must be a better way of doing it than the bureaucratic nightmare that seems to have been thrust upon us by the department so far, a nightmare which we have had to try to resolve, I hope not just by taking appropriate bromide but, in effect, by instructing the department to act in a particular way so the evidently discriminatory nature of the regulations will be offset by administrative instructions.

This has been instructive to me as well. I hope that those designated parents, self-employed and so on, will not be disadvantaged in any way under these less worse arrangements that we have been able to successfully request from the government. If any such parents are disadvantaged and if any parents of children attending non-state schools are disadvantaged I can only ask that they advise the opposition of that disadvantage. That will help, I would hope, to ensure that the regulations are implemented the way the parliament wants them to be implemented.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —It falls to me to close the debate since I moved the disallowance. It is certainly not my intention to canvass all of those matters that I canvassed on the last occasion, but I need to respond to what the minister has said in this chamber today. We are faced with a very grave situation. As a Senate we should be very careful about our consideration of it. The matter was raised by Senator Bell in his contribution as to the legality of what is likely to take place. It has been raised by Senator Baume. The cost of it all has been raised by Senator Margetts.

PARA.TAB: I do not want to go over the matters that I raised before. It was quite clear that the intention of the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) was to ensure that certain alleged rorting was prevented, which is a very commendable intention, but his intention clearly was not reflected in the regulations. I moved this disallowance because they imposed an unfair, discriminatory burden on certain designated parents. The fact that the regulations did not reflect that intention has required the minister to now say how the regulations will be administered. His representative came in here and put on the record of this parliament how these regulations will be administered.

So we now have regulations that do not mean what they say and we have now had the minister saying what they mean. That causes, and will cause, considerable problems. It certainly causes me a problem. I would have thought it ought to cause the government, and indeed the opposition, to further consider the matter. No matter who wins the next election, you should not have a situation where the regulations do not mean what they say to such an extent that the minister's representative has to come into this chamber and say what they mean by saying how they will be administered.

Certain aspects of what the minister has said in relation to how the Austudy regulations will be administered conflict with what the actual regulations say. For example, in relation to questions 67 to 68 the minister says, `The majority of clients subject to the actual means test will need to complete only the four questions on the Austudy application form which will provide a broad picture of their overall financial circumstances.'

Question 67 states: `Give the following details of your principal family home: current market value and address.' Question 68 states: `Give the current market value of any other properties or investments, including holiday houses and share portfolios, in which any family member has a financial interest, include properties in Australia and overseas.' Question 69 states: `Give the details and current market value of any motor vehicle which any family member uses.' Question 70 states: `Give the total education expenses, including tuition and boarding costs, for all family members in 1996.'

So the minister is saying that those questions will satisfy the secretary of the actual means of the designated parents, as he is required under regulation 12K. Of course they will not. How can they? There are certain details of expenditure which are not asked for in those particular questions.

Let me remind the Senate that the regulations actually mean that self-employed persons and those in the designated group are subject to a means test based on their total expenditure without any allowance for the cost of earning their incomes. How could the secretary, by reading the responses to the four questions, make the assessment required to be made under 12K? For example, there is no means of knowing if there are three overseas holidays per annum.

The minister is saying to the secretary that the answers to those four questions ought to be sufficient. I suppose in most cases they might be, but in some cases they might not be. We need to deal with the other legitimate expenditure that is made, for example, by the designated parents in the course of earning their income. I can see what the minister is trying to do in ignoring that expenditure and I commend him for trying to do that.

I take this opportunity to commend those people who have taken part in the discussions which have resulted in a situation which is a little more less satisfactory than what might otherwise have been the case. I do not want to knock that effort. I think the efforts of the minister, the department, Senator Baume and others who were involved are commendable, but I think we do have a problem.

I thought Senator Baume said that, on his assessment, once the minister made his statement and it was on the record of this parliament then it was binding on the secretary. I may have misunderstood him. The High Court has ruled that the secretary has an obligation under the regulations to do certain things no matter what the minister says. This obligation is imposed on the secretary.

I believe it is a very dangerous situation for the government to accept a situation whereby a piece of legislation or a regulation imposes a duty on, say, a secretary to a department and that duty is ignored. What this ministerial statement says is that the minister can instruct the secretary to do things that are not consistent with the regulation and the secretary is required to do that. What if the opposition wins the next election?

The government is creating a very bad precedent I believe, so much so that I think it ought to have a look at amending the legislation. I appeal to you that there are two ways that we can go about this. The first is to send the matter off to the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances to see whether the statement by the minister does reflect fully the obligations that are imposed by the regulations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can tell you as the Deputy Chairman that that is the understanding of the committee at the moment.

—Thank you, Senator O'Chee but, with respect, I cannot see how it is. Let us have a look at another example: the regulations require the secretary to determine the designated parent—12L—and it goes on in 12L(1)(b) to talk about having an interest in a proprietary company or an unlisted public company or having an interest in a trust. An interest in a trust could be an interest in a superannuation fund because most superannuation funds are trusts and that opens, really, a Pandora's box. The minister is saying, `Don't bother about superannuation funds', but some of them are trusts. I am saying there is example after example like that.

PARA.TAB: At this stage I would have liked to move that the statement of the minister be referred to the regulations and ordinances committee for that committee to consider whether or not those examples and the statement are consistent with the regulations themselves. Bearing in mind this very important principle we are talking about that if a regulation that is approved of, or not disapproved by this chamber, imposes an obligation on a particular person, in this case the secretary, then we should not have a situation one way or the other where the minister can order that the regulations be administered in such a manner as would interfere with that obligation. That is what I am getting at. I am not going to move that, by the way, but I would hope you have a think about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will take cognisance of it.

—Have a think about that matter. I accept what the deputy chairman of the committee says. I think it would be a good idea if you did look at that. The minister might like to give further consideration to the regulations with a view to coming forward with amendments so that his intentions, which I believe were also his original intentions and very worthy intentions, are properly reflected in the actual wording of the regulation.

PARA.TAB: I will leave it at that because there is not much point in proceeding any further. I will not withdraw the motion. I will not seek a division. The matters that have been considered here are about issues which go to the very heart of the administration of justice and good government.
Question resolved in the negative.
Consideration resumed from 18 October.

SPEECH.PARA: OZONE PROTECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: The bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: OZONE PROTECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1995OZONE PROTECTION (LICENCE FEES-IMPORTS) BILL 1995OZONE PROTECTION (LICENCE FEES-MANUFACTURE) BILL 1995

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must confess that I am a little disappointed that the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) is not present—no reflection on you, Senator Cook—but I think that it is important, because of the content of the Ozone Protection Amendment Bill 1995, for him to be present and to give answers in relation to some of the technical aspects.
—He will be here shortly.

—Thank you very much. I think it will not preclude me starting on the first amendment that has been circulated in the name of the Greens. I must say that what I want to do at this point is withdraw the particular amendment that has been circulated and replace it with another one which I believe has also been circulated.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Herron)—Could you identify which ones they are?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am trying to. The amendment I want to withdraw has a number at the top, which is cw/3957/Cha-1. I would like to replace it with the amendment which is numbered cw/3965/Cha. I will just explain to my colleagues why that is.

PARA.TAB: Both of the amendments relate to the impact on this particular legislation of the legislation which, it has been foreshadowed, will be coming into the parliament and which is the government's legislative response to the Teoh High Court decision. The reason I am withdrawing the first amendment is that it was a very harsh and blunt way of demonstrating how wrong I believe the government's legislative response is. In fact, the amendment with which we have replaced it is a far more conservative and subtle way of demonstrating those concerns.

Basically, the amendment is presented because I once again wish to highlight the retrograde impact of the Administrative Decisions (Effect of International Instruments) Bill 1995. The withdrawal of the original amendment, as I said, represented a mistake on my part of circulating it, but it is useful to illustrate the problem that we have. The Greens want to show up the fraud the government perpetrates on the Australian community when it signs treaties in an international spotlight of virtuousness and then reneges on the commitment back at home.

My original amendment was an overly blunt attempt to show that. It was an attempt necessitated by the void that exists in Australia's international treaty procedures. We have no effective and comprehensive mechanism for consultation, scrutiny and implementation of international instruments, and that is really what the debate in this area should be about, rather than to propose legislation that makes the problem even worse.

However, what we really want to do, which is the substance of the new amendment which has been circulated, is affirm in law the very modest doctrine of legitimate expectation and have honourable senators put on the record why they support or oppose this aspect of the common law. So this bill and the government's ongoing commitment to implementing the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer are commendable. The convention and protocol are in this case being used as they should; that is, as a minimum set of standards, not a maximum. However, this is rarely the case.

In this instance, I am moving an amendment which simply affirms in law what the common law has been saying since 1969: that Australian citizens should have a legitimate expectation that if Australia becomes party to an international treaty, then we will conform to its provisions. Where a decision maker does not act in conformity, then they have an obligation to give notice and provide an opportunity for a person affected by that to respond.

The doctrine of legitimate expectation is such a modest principle that it is very hard to fathom why the government wants to stamp it out—until we look further. The only conclusion which can be drawn is that the government wants to continue to perpetrate the sham of being an upstanding international citizen while never needing to honour its obligations except at whim and, what is more, being able to blame it on a recalcitrant opposition or on a recalcitrant Senate.

It is really a win-win situation for governments. They can look good internationally and then, when they cannot do anything about it—when they have no capacity to influence administrative decision making until they have actually enshrined in domestic law—they can blame it on the sluggishness of domestic parliaments. It is not good enough. As the Greens, the coalition and the Democrats have pointed out, our treaty making process is fundamentally flawed. We may believe this for different reasons but what we need here is a debate on a comprehensive approach not a piecemeal one.

Even though this bill that we are talking about—the Ozone Protection Amendment Bill—is exemplary in terms of implementing our obligations, this amendment is still required and will be required because the amendment addresses the timelag problem. That is, between the time when the international treaty is in place and domestic legislation comfortably comes into place to enforce it, there needs to be some capacity for administrators to need to take the implications of that treaty seriously and at least consider it.

There is no obligation that they are forced to abide by because it is not yet in domestic law. However, if we say they have no obligations at all in relation to the treaty, it will then negatively affect any changes we might be able to bring to bear in the domestic law. This bill, because it does want to move in relation to the international treaty, is a good example of why we need the legitimate expectation principle enshrined within the bill; so that administrators do have that kind of notice that they must at least consider whether the decisions they are making are in conformity with an international commitment which we are aspiring to put into international law.

The effect of the amendment is to ensure that a legitimate expectation will exist from the time that Australia signs the treaty—we mention in the amendment the Vienna Convention for the Protection of the Ozone Layer and the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer—and not wait until it is legislated for. I am very keen to hear from senators as to what their objections are to the doctrine of legitimate expectation and its application in this case. I am really sorry that the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) has missed my convincing arguments. I seek leave to move two amendments together.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 1, page 3, after item 1, insert the following item:

PARA.TAB: "IA. After section 3:
Insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Convention and Protocol give rise to legitimate expectations

SPEECH.PARA: '3A. Unless and until this section is expressly repealed, the fact that Australia is a party to the Vienna Convention for the Protection of the Ozone Layer ("the Convention" as defined by this Act) and the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer ("the Protocol" as defined by this Act) gives rise to a legitimate expectation, on the part of any person, that, to any extent that this Act does anything less than implement the requirements of the Convention or the Protocol:

PARA.TAB: (a)an administrative decision will be made in conformity with the requirements of the Convention or the Protocol (as the case may be); or

(b)if the decision were to be made contrary to any of those requirements, any person affected by the decision would be given notice and an adequate opportunity to present a case against the taking of such a course.'.".

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 1, pages 3 and 4, item 4, insert the following definition in alphabetical order:

PARA.TAB: ``administrative decision means:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) a decision by or on behalf of the Commonwealth under this Act; or
(b) a decision by or on behalf of an authority of, or office holder of, the Commonwealth under this Act;
that is a decision of an administrative character and includes such a decision reviewing, or determining an appeal in respect of, a decision made before the commencement of this Act.''.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats have raised in this chamber on a number of occasions the inadequacies of the way in which international treaties are dealt with and also, by the same token, the way in which intergovernmental agreements within Australia are dealt with in the national parliament in that they do very often bypass the proper democratic processes of the parliament. We have seen that on a number of occasions where we have been told that we cannot amend or change a particular piece of legislation because it has been agreed between the Commonwealth and the states or that we cannot change a particular piece of legislation because our bureaucrats—not even our government—have gone overseas and agreed with foreign governments that certain things will occur.

PARA.TAB: Our attitude has always been that, when we enter into those international agreements, which we often do for very good reasons, at the very least they should only be the minimum conditions and that Australia should have a perfect right to pick up the broad principle—in this case, the principle of protecting the earth's ozone layer—and move beyond that if we choose. Of course, parliament should retain the absolute sovereign right to modify those undertakings in any way it thinks fit. After all, in a representative democracy we are the representatives of the people and have that responsibility. We have raised those concerns.

In relation to the other principle brought out by the Teoh case, namely that there is a broader and legitimate expectation in the community that where the government has entered into an international treaty or an agreement, despite the fact that there is no domestic legislation to give effect to it, the people in this country should have and can have a legitimate expectation that the government has expressed a genuine intention to give effect to that treaty; and that can have some force in legal argument.

Picking up on what Senator Chamarette said earlier, in this particular case we have, in fact, moved well beyond the Vienna convention and well beyond the Montreal protocol, so the issue of whether we are or are not meeting at least the minimum conditions does not arise; we are already exceeding those conditions. For that reason, I was a little concerned with Senator Chamarette's original amendment because it might have tied us to conditions which are less than the conditions that we had already implemented. That would have been really quite disastrous. Now that the wording says `does anything less than implement the requirements of the convention and the protocol', I am very happy with it. I really cannot see any reason why the government should not accept this as an amendment, given that we are already going well beyond that and that, in fact, it is a claim which was made repeatedly in the minister's second reading speech.

I would point out that in some respects, the Vienna convention is somewhat more broadly drawn than the protocol. I see some advantages in that. I hope that would not give the government any cause to vote against this amendment. The convention, which has 152 parties to it, does not expressly refer to ozone depleting substances; it requires the parties to `take appropriate legislative and administrative measures to protect human health and the environment against ozone depletion and cooperate in scientific research and formulation of measures and protocols'.

This was the beginning of a process. One reading of it is that it was more broadly drawn than the protocol and the Australian legislation which has been built on it. Nonetheless, I would argue that it would still be very valuable to bring those broader interpretations into consideration in Australian legal debate. Whether or not those additional factors are given effect within Australian legislation, they are certainly not in this package of amending legislation that we are dealing with today.

I think this is an excellent idea. It should not cause any concern to government. The only argument that government might bring up is that it does not want to see this as a precedential matter with respect to other bits of legislation. I suspect that the minister might be wanting to put that sort of argument. Coming back to the arguments that have raged to and fro over the Teoh case, if we enter into international agreements, whether or not we have given effect to that in our law, citizens of the world—not only Australian citizens—should have some reasonable expectation that that is the genuine intent of government and that should have some force in arguing legal cases. Therefore, we support this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to raise some questions in relation to the amendment moved by Senator Chamarette. I look forward to her responses. I do not say this in a churlish manner, but it would certainly help if we could get these amendments at a time when they could be properly and carefully considered. I do not pretend that she has indulged in some conspiracy to dump them on the chamber at the last possible moment in the hope that we will be stampeded to get them through. All of us have not kept entirely to the rule I enunciate, which is that it would certainly help the consideration of important amendments if they could be provided at an early stage.

PARA.TAB: I am sure that many in this chamber like to seek and operate off the best advice available as to the ramifications of amendments. I sought advice in relation to the ramifications of your previous amendments and put a lot of people to a lot of hard work. I have noted since coming into the chamber that, much to my surprise, all that research is out the window and I have another amendment before me. I raise that as an issue that we can probably all do better at. It would certainly have helped in its consideration if we had been able to have this amendment a little earlier.

The treaty bandwagon is becoming exceedingly crowded as it moves out of the station. So many people around this chamber are very concerned about treaty making operations and their implications for Australia. Although the passengers on this train may hold a variety of views and be coming from a variety of directions, it seems that only one person left at the station—the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans)—seems to think we are in the best of all possible worlds. Senators may recall that I have raised with Senator Evans and others the fact that the implications of international treaties are important for Australia. Therefore, they have to be very carefully considered. The ramifications of these treaties go far wider than the government was prepared to concede at the time. Subsequent events have indicated that that is the case.

I believe that the rule of law is one of the great features of our community. It is ingrained in our system. It is not always observed. Nonetheless, why are these treaties so important to Australia? Basically, we see them as part of international law.

Having reflected on what has happened in this area, the government, for reasons that both my colleagues raised in the chamber, have big-noted themselves on the international sphere and tried to portray themselves in an internationalist light. They have signed treaties and then found that their ramifications do not always suit them in the domestic manner. They have denied for a long time that the ramifications exist.

Senator Chamarette, you and I may differ in some of these debates—I suspect that we certainly would—but we do not differ in the fundamental principle that the ramifications of these treaties go far wider than Senator Evans was ever prepared to concede. If we want to protect the institution of the rule of law in our society, people have to be satisfied with law making activities. Where we believe that law should apply to our community, we want to make sure as a democracy that our people are involved in some way. There will be debate on how that involvement comes about. But there is no debate on the general principle that people should be involved. The government has persistently denied that issue as well.

This issue concerning treaties, and the procedures by which treaties are signed, is an important one. There is a broadening consensus. I have been encouraged by people like Sir Ninian Stephen and Justice Michael Kirby who have raised similar issues that there is a democratic deficit in relation to treaty making activity.

I made this point yesterday, and I make it again: it is time that Senator Gareth Evans and his advisers addressed that issue and came up with a fuller and more frank approach to this parliament. I believe that when this period and activities of the government are reviewed he will come out very poorly. In some cases we have seen almost secret treaty making activities. Treaties have been signed before elections, never announced to the public and then used as heads of power. I refer to ILO Convention 158.

Returning to your amendment, Senator Chamarette, I raise this with you: it says that an administrative decision will be made in conformity with the requirements of the convention or the protocol, as the case may be. My understanding is that the bill which Senator Faulkner has brought to this chamber, typically, in some areas goes further than the international convention. That dilemma was raised by Senator Coulter.

I would have liked to seek this advice from a lawyer. Knowing you are an expert on international law, Senator Chamarette, I will certainly rely on your advice on this. Would it not be open to somebody to say that because this bill goes too far it is not operating in conformity with the international convention? I can see the direction you are coming from in that you wish to make sure that the international convention is applied. Would not someone who felt the government had gone further than the international convention, I ask you, under your amendment, be provided with a vehicle by which they could appeal, which could produce results which certainly, from the comments you made and probably from what most Australians want, would seem to be very perverse results?
I would have liked to have put this to a lawyer and have got some international expertise on this, but I will be interested to hear your comments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise not only to Senator Kemp but to all people in the chamber. He is quite correct. There was no deviousness on our part to fail to circulate or to mischievously circulate an amendment that we would have no expectation of anybody agreeing with, except that it would allow us to make the point. We attempted to address the possible implications of the government's response to the Teoh case so that we could protect the spirit of this bill. We apologise for the lack of notice.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kemp said he would have a respect for the rule of law. You expressed other sentiments we agree with. We agree that we need a comprehensive process in place in relation to our international treaties and the way in which parliament can scrutinise them. However, I hope that your respect for the law also applies to the fact that all this amendment does is simply make explicit that which the High Court decision in Teoh actually made explicit, which is that it has always been a part of our common law to have a legitimate expectation and it has always been a procedural, not a substantive, right that a person should be able to query a decision that did not seem to be in conformity. We would not need this amendment if we did not already know that there is a possibility of legislation coming in which would make the current situation far less beneficial in terms of honouring what this act is all about.

The third point Senator Kemp made is a very good one. It was answered by Senator Coulter. As Senator Kemp pointed out, this bill is in advance of our international treaties. It would certainly have been possible, under my previous amendment which has been withdrawn, for anybody to challenge administrative decisions and say that they are in excess of what our international treaty obligations are.

There are two things to say about that. First, if somebody felt they wanted to challenge it, then they would have that right. And they should have that right. I am sure that Senator Kemp would not want to take that right away from them. However, I have phrased the amendment in a certain way to say that the fact we are a party to these two conventions:

SPEECH.PARA: gives rise to a legitimate expectation, on the part of any person, that, to any extent that this Act does anything less than implement the requirements of the Convention or the Protocol . . .

That is, we are protecting the progressive stance that we have already taken, but we are protecting it to the degree that, before we move to put it in law, we can actually check its compliance with the international covenant. We can then have that vehicle for repeal if we fall below the standards or the requirements of the convention or protocol.

PARA.TAB: The wording of the amendment does not allow the challenge if it is `higher than'. But I presume unless we take away the procedural rights, which we may well do in this anti-Teoh legislative bill, we are not interfering with a person's right to query it. Because of its phrasing, it is interfering with the person's right to be able to support it, I suspect. There is nothing in this amendment that should not be able to be supported at this point in time.
