The only reason for it not being supported would be if the government and the opposition were intending to undermine our legitimate expectations in response to conventions and an administrative and procedural right to challenge decisions made that are not in conformity with those conventions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know how Senator Kemp intends to vote on this issue, but I simply want to add to what Senator Chamarette has said. If Senator Kemp's concern is fundamentally about too many international treaties and conventions being entered into with or without proper parliamentary scrutiny—perhaps the concern is that there are just too many—I put it to him that recognising the legitimacy of those international conventions within Australian law may well have the effect that he is seeking, which may be different from that of other people in this chamber. He may be seeking to alert government that it has to be doubly careful in future about entering into international conventions lest it gets caught out. If Senator Kemp is minded to vote against this amendment and if his objective is to see fewer international treaties and conventions entered into by Australia, he might achieve that by supporting this amendment.

PARA.TAB: As we have pointed out, the act and the amending bills that we are dealing with here go beyond the convention and the protocol. If this clause is inserted, at some future time—as long as the clause is in there—the government will be stopped from dropping below those minimum standards. I think that is valuable. It puts in place a stopgap, a safeguard. I do not think government has any intention of dropping below those standards. They have, as we have all said, exceeded those requirements. But it puts in that safeguard and prevents the government from dropping below those reasonable expectations which are built into the convention and the protocol. So for that reason I urge Senator Kemp to bring his party on board and to support this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the contributions in this debate have been well made. I think the Teoh debate is another debate. I can see how you have connected it into this bill, which in some ways is a bit awkward because, as we have noted, the bill goes further than the international convention. I certainly welcome the interest that people are now showing in this issue. Some of us felt we were a lone voice a couple of years ago, but I think the GATT bill and a few others have raised the understanding that this is a wider concern.

PARA.TAB: I listened carefully to the arguments. I am still not entirely convinced that the amendment will achieve exactly what the senators hope it will achieve. The minimum standards in this bill, on my understanding, are largely set in the bill itself. If the government wished to fall below those minimum standards it would have to bring a new bill into the parliament. It is this bill which sets some of the key standards. If the genuine fear is that this government, or a future government, might fall below these standards, we would have to bring a new bill into this chamber. Senator Faulkner will not be there, but if a future government decided that it would not abide by these standards it would be in breach of its own law. I am not clear that the logic remains.

I am not too sure of the extent to which you elevate a further international treaty. Perhaps you might open up grounds for someone to produce perverse results which we would not accept. I will be very interested in the minister's reflections on this issue because I know that he has been very carefully following the debate. My feeling is that we are bringing in another very important debate. It is a debate that perhaps should be had elsewhere. I am not convinced on the basis of the arguments that this amendment will assist in any way in protecting the bill. It may open the door to producing perverse results.

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem is that the act could be amended at some later stage to fall below international obligations. This amendment would make sure that we could not administratively do that. If it is passed we are stuck with it. This would operate on the way in which administrative decisions would be made in between any change and would actually protect the act that we have in place at the moment until such time as it is repealed. That is the point of having it. Whilst I appreciate that we would not want it to be used perversely, I am not anticipating that that will happen at all. All I am saying is that it is perverse to remove a legitimate expectation and a procedural right that could protect the spirit of the laws that we enact in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Kemp makes something of a reasonable point when he argues that there will soon be another bill for debate before this chamber in relation to a number of the issues that have been canvassed, including the Teoh bill. I think that was accepted by Senator Chamarette in her earlier contribution. That bill has passed the House of Representatives and has been examined by a Senate committee. It will be a matter where senators will be able to make contributions in this chamber in the very near future.

PARA.TAB: The government will be opposing the amendment proposed by Senator Chamarette. The proposed amendment gives the convention and protocol direct legal force. In the government's view, that is inappropriate. It is an important principle that international conventions do not have legal force in Australia other than through legislation passed by the parliament.

Usually, the provisions of conventions are unsuited to a simple incorporation as part of domestic law. This is because the language of a convention normally will allow a country some scope in the manner in which it is implemented. This is certainly the case in relation to the Vienna convention and the Montreal protocol. I think a good example of what I am speaking of is article 2.2(b) of the Vienna convention, which provides:

SPEECH.PARA: To this end the Parties shall, in accordance with the means at their disposal and their capabilities:

(b) Adopt appropriate legislative or administrative measures and co-operate in harmonizing appropriate policies to control, limit, reduce or prevent human activities under their jurisdictions or control should it be found that these activities have or are likely to have adverse affects resulting from modification or likely modification of the ozone layer;

I think that is a good example of a provision that is unsuited to be given the force of domestic law. The provision contemplates that governments will enact legislation to give effect to our obligations under the convention or protocol and also uses terms which clearly contain an element of discretion, such as `in accordance with the means at their disposal' and `appropriate'.

PARA.TAB: I do think the arguments against the proposal of Senator Chamarette in this case are strong. Senator Kemp makes the point that the legislation we have before us goes further than the convention and the protocol. Both Senator Chamarette and Senator Coulter in their contributions accepted that that is the case. We can go to areas such as aerosol bans; bans on CFC refrigeration and airconditioning equipment; the earlier halon phase-out; a lower limit on HCFCs, a path allowed under the protocol; and so on.

I think the case that the Australian position contained within our legislation is stronger than that embraced within the Vienna convention and the Montreal protocol is an open-and-shut case. I accept that that was accepted by all speakers in relation to this amendment.

I will not comment, Senator Kemp, on the other point you made. I thought you did mangle your metaphors a little when you started to talk about the treaty bandwagon and then had it pulling out from a station and about the passengers in the carriages and so forth. It was a rather mangled metaphor, but I suppose that was because it was in some part an attempt—very unfairly, I think—to criticise my colleague Senator Evans. I was disappointed that you brought the debate down to that level, Senator Kemp.
I do think that that the arguments presented against this amendment are strong. It is for those reasons that the government will not be supporting the amendment as moved by Senator Chamarette.

TALK.START.PARA: —There should be a brief response to the minister. As he says, the Vienna convention has some aspects that we are fulfilling, in fact at a better level. But there are also aspects of the protection clause that relate to high altitude aircraft and missiles that are not covered in this act. So certain aspects of the Vienna convention are not covered in this act. There are certain ones, particularly in relation to the protocol, where we are ahead. All I am pointing out to the minister is that the very commendable standard that we have here, where we are in advance of our obligations, needs to be protected from now till the next time we improve it. There should be some capacity for administrative decision making to take that into account.

PARA.TAB: To choose a convention which we are already honouring in spirit and in technical reality means that the objection to the amendment from the opposition and the government is nonsensical. I could understand that if international treaties were forcing us to put aside our domestic law, Senator Kemp, you would have considerable concerns about that. We are not talking about that; we are talking about a situation where our law is actually in advance. We are allowing people the procedural right to query whether we are going in the right direction still as we make further decisions. So to honour our bill and our international treaty obligations is not moving in different directions. The amendment that is in place is simply to maintain and protect that.

Senator Faulkner, just one last thing. You had people making considerable fun of you and Australia's inability to maintain a high international profile on our climate change. This is an area where you are going to make treaties that cover our international obligations in relation to the environment. It would be a disgrace if people in the international arena knew that Australia were making international treaties which it had no administrative intention of following or being obligated to look at until such time as domestic legislation were to be put into place. This is fairly grave and will have an impact on anyone who is involved in international treaty making in future. If every country around the world did what we are contemplating doing it would make any international treaty irrelevant. It would have no implication or legitimate expectation within the eyes of the community.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Chamarette's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will endeavour to move my amendments in clumps to assist the committee process, but I have two confessions to make in that regard. Firstly, I am not totally familiar with the way in which the numbering will be affected by this and I may make some mistakes. Secondly, my expertise on ozone protection matters is not as vast as I would like. I have to acknowledge the very fine assistance of Senator Margetts's adviser, Dhanu River, on these matters. From time to time I may need to refer to my adviser because some of these amendments are fairly technical, but they are extremely valuable. I will be at the mercy of the chamber to a certain extent as I work through them. I am sure Senator Coulter will be able to assist me as I am sure the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) will. The first clump I will move are general amendments relating to HFCs. I seek leave to move amendments Nos 1, 2 and 14 together.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 1, page 3, item 1, proposed paragraph 3(a), omit "of substances that deplete ozone in the atmosphere; and" substitute:
"of:

TAB.TAB: (i)substances that deplete ozone in the atmosphere; and
(ii)substances (for example, hydroflourocarbons) that can be used to replace substances referred to in subparagraph (i) and the use of which:
(A)is contrary to the terms of another international agreement to which Australia is a party; or

(B)makes it more difficult to abide by the terms of an international agreement to which Australia is a party than it would be if the first mentioned substances (for example hydroflourocarbons) were not used; and".

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 1, pages 3 and 4, item 4, insert the following definiations in alphabetical order:
"`global warming potential means the global warming potential of a specific substance as stated in Schedule 1.
"`ozone depleting potential means the ozone depleting potential of a specific substance as stated in Schedule 1.".
Schedule 1, page 3, item 4, insert the following definition in alphabetical order:
"HCFs means a hydroflourocarbon referred to in Part VIII of Schedule 1 whether existing alone or in a mixture.".
Schedule 1, page 25, item 50, after proposed Part Vii, add the following Part:
"PART VIII—HFCs
Column 1 Column 2
Substance Global Warming Potential
CHF(3)
CHF(2)CHF(2)
CH(2)FCF(3)
CHF(2)CH(2)F
CF(3)CH(3)

These amendments are important because they create a limited extension of the act to cover replacements for ozone depleting substances which may be the specific or general subject of another international agreement. The amendment only extends Commonwealth powers to replacements for ozone depleting substances and only where another international agreement applies. It is taking the act a little further, but it is not taking it outside what we believe to be the general understanding of the spirit of the act.

PARA.TAB: The act in its current form only allows regulation of ozone depleting substances. While generally this is appropriate, where a non-ozone depleting substance is currently subject to specific restrictions under another convention or is currently subject to general restrictions, it is foolish to allow these substances to be used as a replacement for ozone depleting substances.

The classic example is the case of the hydrofluorocarbons. These are significant greenhouse gases with a global warming potential of several thousand. General use of these substances in an unregulated way will have serious implications on our ability to meet our obligations under climate change conventions—obligations which we are already struggling to meet and are unlikely to meet.

In addition, several European nations are pushing for the European Union to adopt a policy of phase-out of HFCs and they are likely to succeed. They have also indicated that they will push for the inclusion of a phase-out under international climate change implementation agreements. Currently, hydrocarbons are available for many applications, and ammonia and other replacement substances are also beginning to be widely available and commercially adopted as standard. In such a case it would be foolish to allow industry to blindly adopt HFC technology at considerable cost when it may be subject to international restrictions.

The outcome will have environmental implications if the agreement is an environmental one, but is liable to have commercial and trade implications in any case. So to allow industry or consumers to replace one substance with a second substance which will be phased out, especially when commercial alternatives are available, is foolish. To allow manufacturers to produce products using replacements that will lead those products to be banned in other countries will impose serious consequences on export industries.

Amendment No. 2 is a technical amendment to add two definitions: global warming potential and ozone depleting potential. With our proposed inclusion of a schedule for HFCs there is a need to define global warming potential since various figures or methods have been used internationally at various times. This establishes clearly the global warming potential as the figures given in the act. The figures are those provided by the CSIRO Division of Atmospheric Science and should be considered the best currently available figures for a 20-year time horizon.

There is no definition for ozone depleting potential, and various figures or methods have been used in a similar way at various times. So this will clearly establish the ozone depleting potential as those figures—which are generally at the high end of the range in the Montreal protocol—contained in schedule 3 to the act.

So given the variation between the ozone depleting potential in part 5 of schedule 1 and the ODP, or ozone depleting potential, as given in the Montreal protocol in schedule 3 and the lack of specific reference to ODP use under proposed section 10 for the calculation of ODP tonnes, it seems important to clarify that definition.

For example, the ODP for HCFC 121 on page 21 is given as 0.04. Yet the ODP for the same substance on page 51 is given as 0.01 to 0.04. Adoption of the 0.01 figure would allow four times as much substance to be used, and an average figure would allow roughly double.

Amendment No. 14 simply refers to the HFCs which are set out as part of schedule 1. Amendment No. 3 on the same page relates to HFCs being consistent with other definitions such as HCFCs, CFCs and so on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my speech during the second reading debate I laid a great deal of emphasis on this very point: that, while this legislation is dealing with ozone depleting substances, many ozone depleting substances are also significant greenhouse gases. It is very important that we do not jump out of the frying pan into the fire and seek to solve one problem while we make another problem worse.

PARA.TAB: There are two reasons for that. Firstly, of course, one does not want to exacerbate the environmental problems of greenhouse by using substitute gases which are certainly less ozone depleting but which are greenhouse causing, then to discover down the track that we need to control those in yet some other legislation. Secondly, very importantly for industry and for the economy as a whole, it is quite silly to go down a track which involves vast investment in equipment, vast investment in literally millions of domestic refrigerators or large commercial airconditioning units or whatever, using technology which, in a few short years—because of developments in our understanding of greenhouse which are coming to light very quickly now—we will need to undo. That does represent a vast waste of the resources of the community. We simply should try to head those things off as far as possible.

So the amendments which have been put by Senator Chamarette are designed to do that. The first one, as she said, is to recognise that there are other criteria which need to be taken into account, even though this legislation is dealing with ozone protection. The second one provides some definition. I notice that there is an amendment to amendment No. 14, and I hope that has been circulated. At the bottom of that table, which is part VIII of schedule 1, it should state:

SPEECH.PARA: Note: GWP figures are only for direct effects, and are based on a 20 year time horizon. The GWP for CO(2) is taken as 1
I hope Senator Kemp—

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Reynolds)—Senator Coulter, that has not yet been circulated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to pick that up. When we are talking about ozone depleting potential, my understanding is that—and it is given in some of the tables—CFC-12, which is one of the standard ones, is given a rating of 1.
—Senator, I just want to clarify something. The amendment that you are discussing has not yet been circulated and, as I understand it, is not yet with the attendants.

—This is the explanation to go at the bottom of the table which is in Senator Chamarette's amendment No. 14. I think it is even more important that I give some explanation to that table which appears there. As it stands, the global warming potential figures may well be somewhat meaningless to some people in the chamber.

PARA.TAB: Going back to the ozone depleting potential, the Montreal protocol took the ozone depleting potential of CFC-12 as 1 and then related other substances to that. What that meant was that molecule for molecule, taking into account the resonance time in the atmosphere, other substances had a greater or less ozone depleting potential than CFC-1, so one could directly compare one substance with another with respect to its ozone depleting potential. So you could say that CFC-22, freon-22, if I recall, had an ozone depleting potential of 0.03—three per cent. In other words, if you are looking for the effect on the ozone of a release of freon-22, you could say that roughly 300 tonnes of that would have the same ozone depleting potential as the release of one tonne of CFC-12.

In a similar way, one needs to recognise that the CFCs the HCFCs and the various other related substances are very potent greenhouse gases. The importance of this table lies in the fact that, while the concentrations in the atmosphere may be small, molecule for molecule they are very potent. I draw Senator Kemp's attention to the first one in that table, the CHF(3), or HFC-23, with a greenhouse warming potential of 9,200. What that means, Senator Kemp, is that one molecule of that substance in the atmosphere has a global warming potential 9,200 times greater than a molecule of carbon dioxide.

Therefore, even though the concentration may be significantly lower, there is still the potential for it to be a global warming substance if the technology using these substances develops along similar lines to the way in which the CFC technology developed from the mid-1930s through until the late 1980s—namely, when equipment leaked the material was simply let off into the atmosphere. Yesterday, in your speech on the second reading, I think you yourself pointed to the enormous expansion of refrigeration in China which has 60 times Australia's population. If they use the wasteful technology that we have used over the last 40 or 50 years, then we are setting ourselves up for a very serious greenhouse warming situation. We should try to head that off as far as we can.

These amendments are designed to recognise that we are looking at problems which go beyond ozone depletion. We are also looking at substances that have significant greenhouse effects, and they should be taken into account in this legislation. I understand that my further amendment is being circulated now. It simply identifies that, when talking about global warming potential—the words at the top of column 2 in that table, which is amendment No. 14—that takes carbon dioxide as unit one. It tells you that those substances have much higher degrees of global warming potential. The Democrats will also be supporting this group of amendments. I formally move this additional amendment, which is really a clarification of that table. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed Part VIII, after Table add the following note:
"Note: Global Warming Potential (GWP) figures are only for direct effects, and are based on a 20-year time horizon. The GWP for CO(2) is taken as 1.".

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to indicate that I am very happy to accept that amendment. I apologise if Senator Coulter had any understanding that I was going to circulate it. I think he made a very good point, and we accepted it as an amendment to our amendment. But at that stage we had circulated all our amendments in bulk, so it was difficult to add that amendment in. I indicate that we are happy to take that on board.

PARA.TAB: I just want to say it might look as though—because of my way of handling this—these amendments are less serious than they actually are, because there has been this toing-and-froing over numbers. But I would stress that this whole series of amendments is consistent. The amendments work together and are very valuable additions to the bill.

I would encourage support for them in the chamber. They do not extend the spirit of the bill. They just extend its usefulness and the wisdom of the way in which it will be applied in industry and trade, as well as for its benefits to the environment and to our ozone protection commitments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly on the amendments that have been moved. I do not want to revisit old territory but, again, it would certainly assist the discussion if we actually have the amendments before us and are rapidly able to refer to the tables. The bill is about trying to protect the ozone layer and making sure that Australia takes appropriate steps in this regard. I think we are all in fulsome agreement that this bill does that and that Australia goes beyond the international obligations which it has.

PARA.TAB: I have only just seen the amendments, so Senator Coulter and Senator Chamarette will have to excuse me if I am not as precise as I would want to be. I would have liked a chance to discuss them. I have listened very carefully to the arguments of Senator Coulter. The issue of greenhouse gas and Australia's response to it is certainly a very big issue. Again, a bit like the previous amendment, it seems to me that we are putting onto this bill another debate which—

TALK.START.PARA: —Another bandwagon!

—It is another very important debate, one for which Senator Faulkner has shown a remarkable lack of enthusiasm; and I can understand that. He got sort of belted around at Berlin and, fair enough, it took some time to recover; but do you need all these months to recover before you get moving again? That is a debate for another day. It took seven months to release—
—You were there; did you have a good time?
—No. I worked very hard, Senator Faulkner, unlike you. But I found it very instructive. One could not help but feel some sympathy for you.
—You congratulated me. It was a lovely letter you wrote to me.

—I would like you to table it. I would like to see it myself—would you mind tabling the letter? I am sure I did not write you a letter. You may have felt I congratulated you but that was to the extent that you remained standing after being so hopelessly bloodied. I think you have to give some credit to a man who at least remains standing after the pounding that you received. I am happy to say that in the chamber if that makes you happy. You have been awfully laggardly in the greenhouse response and I know you are making a statement—you should be somewhere now making a statement, I understand—
—I am giving priority to you.

—Thanks very much. Even things which one would not have thought were so difficult, such as getting the terms of reference for an energy white paper, for instance, seem to take so long—in this case, seven months to work out the terms of reference.
—That is something you will have to address, Senator.

—We can address that at a later stage. Senator Coulter, getting back to your issue, you have raised some very technical points. You have raised some points which, as a non-scientist, I would have welcomed the chance to further explore with you and to seek some advice. This relates, as well, to the amendments that have been moved by Senator Chamarette. My understanding of the amendments that we have before us is that they concern the issue of HFCs and HCFCs and how this bill should be dealing with those.

PARA.TAB: I will raise this issue and perhaps one of the senators who has spoken on this will address this particular matter. My understanding is that the use of HFCs and HCFCs is viewed as an interim strategy to maintain the air conditioning and refrigeration equipment following the removal of CFCs as a refrigerant option. I think that is the government's strategy—and Senator Faulkner is nodding. I think that is a strategy which most people felt at least provided an interim solution and dealt with a larger problem quite effectively.

If, in fact, these amendments are passed, does this mean—and I understand that it would—that we would have to replace HFCs and HCFCs with hydrocarbons? In other words, we would have to find alternatives for the uses for which they were going to be used. This is the advice that I have and I would like you to address it. The key alternatives to HFCs and HCFCs today are hydrocarbons, which are inflammable. Should hydrocarbons leak from the refrigeration system and a spark be present, explosion and fire may follow. Significant safety concerns exist over hydrocarbon replacements for this reason. HCFCs and HFCs—according to the advice I have, and I listened to your response—are the best technology at the moment as an alternative to CFCs. The implementation of the amendments would, in fact, remove this option. If that option was removed, would we be forced into alternatives which would pose an even greater threat to life and limb? Senator Coulter, perhaps you could address that concern.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I read these amendments, that is not quite the intention. I think you have pushed the amendments further than they intend to go. Two of the possible gases which would be substitutes—hydrocarbons and pneumonia—are both flammable. If you had a massive leak, you could have a fire. That is not the reason we are not going down that road. We have seen the development of substances which can be used within existing equipment. Compression ratios and various other things in refrigeration and airconditioning units can use some of these substitutes in existing equipment. It is the convenience reasons. I think I am right in saying there are 180 grams of working fluid in a typical domestic refrigerator. A slow rate of leakage would be extremely unlikely to cause any fire or hazard, even if all of it were to come out at once.

PARA.TAB: One of the advantages of ammonia is that it has such a horrible smell, unlike the CFCs and the HCFCs. Immediately it leaks, it is so pungent that one identifies the leak very quickly. Certainly with ammonia, which I mentioned yesterday, there is no possibility of slotting it into existing equipment. The intention, as I understand Senator Chamarette's amendments, is to recognise this other dimension to the problem and to head off the possibility that, given we are in a transitional phase, we do not go down a blind alley. We want to recognise that we are faced with another large problem. As far as we are capable of doing so, we want to head that off. It is sensible economic policy to try to recognise the options which are available to you in the future and make your investments in those areas in which you are not going to then have to pull back from those investments and make further investments. That is how I read the intention here.

It may well be that we should be going back to the old ammonia technology with modern equipment. It was used prior to the 1930s and can be made extremely efficient. As I mentioned yesterday, the Peltier effect has been used in some small 12-volt refrigerators for cars and caravans. That has now been developed to a very high degree. It would give one the opportunity to have a domestic refrigerator work on a solar panel on one's roof, thereby creating zero greenhouse gas emissions. There would be no moving parts; it would be very efficient technology. Recognising that there are problems, let us not invest in technology from which we then have to pull back and make further investments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will answer Senator Kemp's question by going a little more directly to the amendments. The amendments we are currently moving only empower the government to regulate. They do not say anything about what the regulation is; that is in later amendments. Those later amendments do not demand specific alternatives. They only say no to HCFCs and HFCs in certain applications. It is basically doing exactly what Senator Coulter has said; it is preventing us from being so blinkered in our desire to look at ozone depleting substances that we put in replacements that have other complicating factors. Basically, the amendments we are discussing at the moment simply empower the government to regulate in that fairly sensible way. The amendments later say what that way will need to be.

—As we wish to bring this matter to a fairly swift conclusion, I will be brief. It is a very important debate. It is about time we had in this chamber a good debate on greenhouse issues, looked very carefully at what is happening there and how those promises under 21C are going. It would be a useful debate, and it would certainly be useful to get Senator Faulkner's views on the many commitments made under 21C.

PARA.TAB: This is a complex amendment. I have listened very carefully to the debate. I understand Senator Coulter's expressed concerns. I do not say that those concerns are not real. The question is about weighing up the balance. If we pass this amendment would we produce a result which would give effect to community concerns about the materials which are being used in refrigeration systems? Would this lead to problems for life and limb?

I understand the intention. I do not dispute it. There may be some arguments over the science you have raised. It seems to me that we should deal with this issue. Let us deal with it in relation to the greenhouse gas issues.You say that if we phase out HFCs and HCFCs we can use technology to make sure that the potential dangers from hydrocarbons are removed. I am not convinced that that is the case. That may or may not be the case. I am not a scientist. I find it difficult to evaluate that.

You have been specific. You have given very clear assurances that the technology is available, is being used and would not lead to dangerous substances being used in refrigeration systems. I find it difficult to support the amendment. We should look at some of these issues and any of the wider issues you have raised about greenhouse gases in relation to that issue and not try to load that issue onto this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make one further point to Senator Kemp. The history of the way in which the ozone depletion debate has gone and the way in which industry has responded to that provides a very good object lesson for us in the matter we are debating here. I pointed out in my speech yesterday that, when the scientific evidence on ozone depletion became in my mind absolutely clear, by 1976 when the National Academy of Science in the US said, `We have a serious problem,' industry resisted that. We all remember the way in which they said, `We have no substitutes for pressure pack cans.' We went to hydrocarbons in pressure pack cans. They had warnings that you were not to use pressure pack cans near fires. That was 1,000 times more dangerous than a couple of ounces of hydrocarbon in a refrigeration compressor unit where you might get fractions of a gram leaking.

PARA.TAB: We went down that road. Industry resisted. Government supported industry. That went on for quite a long period of time. When finally government grasped the nettle and said, `We have a problem. Let's legislate and set out the conditions,' industry responded remarkably quickly.

In fact, the government is right. Australia has been very good, since that legislation in 1988 or 1989, in dealing with the problem of ozone depleting substances. We are trying to say there is another emerging problem. If government is prepared to set the parameters or the guidelines, technology and industry are capable of responding. But don't leave industry in a limbo where they might go down a road thinking this technology is acceptable and find a couple of years down the track they have to change their patterns yet again. They have made vast investments. People have bought refrigerators worth $600, $800 or $1,000. They say, `We cannot use these any more. We have to buy another one that uses something different because we have a greenhouse problem.' That fails to recognise that technology and industry can respond.

We have the technology. We have the essential industries established in Australia. Let us set the parameters. Let us be quite clear about it. Industry will respond. We won't waste a lot of money. We won't run into some greenhouse problems. It is as simple as that. The object lesson is already there in the history of how we have dealt with ozone depleting substances. Let us learn from that history. Let us recognise that and accept this amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will not be supporting amendments 1, 2, 3 or 14, as moved by Senator Chamarette. We are not prepared to extend the legislation to controlled substances that are not ozone depleting substances. The purpose of the act is to implement the requirements of the Montreal protocol to regulate ozone depleting substances. Other environmental impacts of replacements for ozone depleting substances, such as the greenhouse warming potential of HFCs, are appropriately managed through other mechanisms. The government has a separate, specifically designed greenhouse gas strategy and to enter into legislative control of these ozone substitutes at this time will create wider difficulties with the program of greenhouse cooperative agreements with industry.

PARA.TAB: Since aspects of the act rely on the external affairs power of the constitution, rather than other heads of power, such as the corporations power, an extension of the act to cover HFCs, which are beyond the controlled substances under the Montreal protocol, may render part of the act in fact unconstitutional or invalid.

Let me say that HCFCs and HFCs are needed to phase out CFCs. They are part of the solution. Ammonia, hydrocarbons and other technologies will also be used. The difference between the government's approach and that which has been suggested by Senator Chamarette and Senator Coulter is that we propose that industry and the owners of equipment decide which alternatives best meet their requirements. Cooperative industry agreements, monitoring and information programs will provide industry and consumers with the knowledge they need to make the best choices which are also environmentally sound from an ozone and a greenhouse perspective.

While HCFCs and HFCs are greenhouse gases, they have global warming potential values less than the CFCs they replace. The emission of these gases has also been substantially reduced due to better maintenance and training of service mechanics. Current emissions of HFCs are small. We can expect this to rise as CFCs are phased out. Equally, I expect the use of ammonia and hydrocarbon refrigerants to increase as more types of refrigerant equipment are developed and manufactured.

I do not want to get into ways of measuring or estimating global warming potentials of various gases. I accept that HCFCs and HFCs are, molecule for molecule, potent greenhouse gases, as Senator Coulter said. However, in the quantity they will be released to the atmosphere, they will not be significant greenhouse contributors and I believe that the approach that the government has outlined is one that has been shown to be effective, has been shown to work, and I commend this approach. It is for those reasons that I will be opposing these four amendments standing in the name of Senator Chamarette.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for his answer. I am glad he acknowledges the capacity of HFCs to increase the greenhouse gas problem and global warming. I also appreciate his relating the other technologies that are available, such as ammonia and hydrocarbons. I reiterate that we are not trying to turn the Ozone Protection Amendment Bill into a greenhouse gas bill or a global warming bill. We just think that these environmental concerns need to be addressed in a holistic manner and that we should not be blind to some of the problems that will arise in other areas.

PARA.TAB: While I am sad that the minister is indicating that there is no support for the amendments, I do value the assurance he has put on the public record. I hope he will put some mechanism in place at some other time which will show us how we can control HFCs. I think we should also make it clear to people who may be simply going for a straight replacement into HFCs that hydrocarbons are commercially available and safe options now in many applications. They are almost standard in Europe and all developed countries. We need to allow our industry to be well informed in that regard. These things should not be diluted by specific regulation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a different point. I was reminded of this point by the minister reminding us that the act contains various sections. I am saying this for the benefit of Senator Kemp and other members of the opposition. There is one section of this act which draws its power fairly and squarely under the corporations powers which, I have argued in this place, the government should use far more widely to protect the environment. I remind the chamber that, as far as I am aware, those powers were included under a separate section so that, should they be challenged, the rest of the act would not fail. To my knowledge they have never been challenged. I think this is a good example of the use of those corporations powers by the Commonwealth.

PARA.TAB: Amendment (Senator Coulter's) negatived.
Amendments (Senator Chamarette's) negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate to my colleagues that I do not intend to call divisions on this matter. I would appreciate it if people could record their views in relation to the amendments. In that way there will be an understanding on the public record of the way in which the support for these measures is going. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 4.Schedule 1, page 8, after item 22, insert the following item:
"22A. Paragraphs 20(2)(a), (b) and (c):
Add at the end `and'.".

This is a technical amendment. While it bears some relationship to amendment No. 2 in the definition of ozone depleting potential, it is a purely technical amendment to make paragraphs (a),(b) and (c) of clause 20(2) consistent with paragraphs (a),(b) and (c) of clause 16(5), as amended by the government amendment No. 22. The wording in both of these paragraphs is currently exactly the same. We believe it is the intention of the government that they should retain an identical meaning when one of them is changed. To change one without changing the other creates an impression that there is a difference. I am anticipating some support from the government on this amendment—or at least an explanation as to why it is changed in one paragraph and not in another.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chamarette is right: it is a technical amendment. But there is no necessity for it. I think it is likely that we would just hold this up and have to go back to the House of Representatives. It is hard for me to get incredibly emotional about it. It is not necessary, and for that reason the government will be opposing it.

PARA.TAB: Amendment (Senator Chamarette's) negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 5.Schedule 1, page 17, item 28, omit "50", substitute "500".
6.Schedule 1, page 17, item 29, omit "100", substitute "500".
7.Schedule 1, page 17, item 30, omit "100", substitute "500".
8.Schedule 1. page 17, item 31, omit "100", substitute "500".
9.Schedule 1, page 17, item 32, omit "100", substitute "500".
10.Schedule 1, page 17, item 33, omit "100", substitute "500".

These amendments relate to penalties for contravention of conditions of licences. In proposed new section 18(7), on page nine of the bill, the penalty for contravention of a condition of a licence is 500 penalty units, as are the penalties in general for the manufacture or import in excess of the quota in the existing act. Yet the penalty for import or manufacture of products containing these substances is only 50 penalty units and the penalty for the importation of such products from non-protocol nations is only 100 penalty units. We believe there should be consistency between violation of licence on the import of substances and the illegal and unlicensed import of products containing these substances and products coming from non-protocol countries.

PARA.TAB: Amendment No. 5 relates to the manufacture or import of products containing banned substances. Amendments Nos 6 and 7 relate to the import of substances from non-protocol countries. Amendment No. 8 relates to the export of substances to non-protocol countries. Amendment No. 9 relates to the import of products containing substances from non-protocol countries and amendment No. 10 relates to the import of products using scheduled substances in manufacture.

There are no licences governing import or manufacture of products. Schedule 4 simply says what products are legal and what are not. No products containing certain substances should be exported to, or imported from, non-protocol countries. We believe that this would be a far more consistent approach. To do any of these events is illegal and in violation of both domestic federal law and the international protocol.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —In principle the government is not implacably opposed to what Senator Chamarette has put forward in her amendments, but certainly would be obliged to consult with other government departments before supporting such an increase in the penalties. In particular, under the Commonwealth's Criminal Code Act 1995, with which all legislation must be brought into conformity within the next five years, the offence may need to specifically incorporate an element of intention in order to sustain a penalty of the suggested magnitude. So for those reasons the government cannot support the amendments without having undertaken a significant amount of further consultation.

—Senator Faulkner—and I listened to the arguments—does raise a dilemma with some of these amendments which has weighed more heavily with me than on this current one but nonetheless I think is important—that is, that the implications and the ramifications of some of these amendments are far more widespread.

PARA.TAB: I have been in this chamber, gone through various bills and sought advice, and it never ceases to amaze me how extensive the ramifications can be of what often seems to be a simple amendment. Senator Faulkner in relation to an earlier amendment mentioned the heads of power issue and how that would be affected. In relation to this issue, he has mentioned other procedures and other consultative arrangements.

The penalties are important, and no-one is arguing that. There will always be arguments about the appropriate level of penalties. Having listened to the debate and to the arguments which have been put, if this appeared to be a problem which was occurring in relation to this bill, it would certainly be one we would revisit. In the absence of any more weighty arguments, we will not support the amendments which have been proposed.
Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 11.Schedule 1, page 17, after item 28, insert the following item:

PARA.TAB: "28A. Subsection 38(1):
After `uses scheduled substances', insert `, or was designed to use scheduled substances'.".

SPEECH.PARA: 12.Schedule 1, page 17, after item 28, insert the following item:
"28B. Subsection 38(2):

PARA.TAB: After `uses scheduled substances', insert `, or was designed to use scheduled substances'.".

SPEECH.PARA: 13.Schedule 1, page 17, after item 28, insert the following item:
"28C. Subsection 39(1):
After `contain scheduled substances', insert `, or were designed to use such substances,'.".

These amendments concern the manufacture and import of products. The current wording is `for products that contain or use scheduled substances'. While it is testable whether a product contains a substance, it is difficult to determine whether it uses a substance, especially in the case where there are various products, some scheduled and some not, designed to replace each with other with little or no modification of equipment. These amendments are intended to pick up those which, it might be argued, could use an unscheduled substance but have design features tailored to scheduled substances.

That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the last decade this federal Labor government has progressively squeezed the states through reduced grants. The bill before us today does nothing to change that. The States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill 1995 amends the States Grants (General Purposes) Act 1994, and gives effect to agreements made at the Premiers Conference held on 11 April 1995. This was an historical meeting, as honourable senators may recall, in that this agreement coincided with agreement by the state Premiers on the implementation of national competition policy. Competition policy reforms were a central theme of that conference. The government in its budget paper No. 3 for 1995-96, at page 4, states:

SPEECH.PARA: The provision of the real per capita guarantee reflected the Commonwealth's desire to foster cooperative Commonwealth-State relations which would in turn offer a sound basis for working together to progress micro-economic reform.

It is worth remembering that the additional general purpose payments to be made by the Commonwealth to the states for the competition policy reforms will depend very much on satisfactory progress on implementation. Failure to do so will result in the per capita payment being retained by the Commonwealth. It will be the role of the recently established National Competition Council to determine whether the required conditions have been met by the states.

PARA.TAB: The payments, which are due to commence in July 1997, will be paid on a quarterly basis and indexed annually to maintain their real value, structured at $200 million in July 1997, increasing to $400 million in July 1999 and to $600 million in July 2001, all at 1994-95 prices, and therefore adjusted for inflation over that period. The payments will form a pool separate from the financial assistance grants pool and will be distributed on a per capita basis.

One may ask the relevance of these payments in the context of the bill before us. The point is simple. It is another example of the centralist Keating federal government creating conditions for the states whereby states are reliant on the goodwill and generosity of the federal government for their funding. This has an all too familiar ring about it. As I said at the outset, the last 10 years have seen a decline in assistance to the states in real terms. In marked contrast, the Commonwealth government's own purpose outlays have increased in all but three years, 1986 to 1989.

A secure revenue stream is critical for the states. The Liberal and National parties believe that a fixed share of Commonwealth taxation revenue should be agreed upon, free of conditions, to restore autonomy to the states. The net effect should be much improved financial relations between the Commonwealth and the states.

This is not a new issue. It was flagged during the prime ministership of Mr Hawke but taken off the agenda by the present incumbent, Mr Keating. Each year when the bills for payments to the states come before this parliament, the Liberal and National parties raise with the government the problem known widely as vertical fiscal imbalance. The calls have, sadly, fallen on deaf ears. Mr Keating has shown absolutely no sympathy for the almost untenable situation in which the states find themselves, their funding squeezed by the Keating government, forced to cut some services given the insufficient funding provided and then blamed for an inability to provide an adequate level of service.

The reason for the imbalance is quite simple: the Commonwealth has collected income tax revenue since the states handed over their income taxing powers during World War II to assist the war effort. Prime Minister Fraser attempted to redress the imbalance and introduced income tax sharing between the federal and state governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which would have been a disaster for South Australia on a per capita basis.
—It was very effective. He introduced it and it worked very effectively.
—No, it would have ended up meaning South Australia and the smaller states getting a lot less than the bigger states.

—What rubbish. This is the failed centre left of the South Australian Labor Party. The Centre Left in South Australia has been decimated recently. Senator Schacht is now a straw man and he comes in here and interjects on these matters about which he has absolutely no knowledge whatsoever. This poor pathetic creature was decimated by his own colleagues in South Australia at their recent annual conference.
—You wish you were right, don't you?
—Here he is parroting off this nonsense in this chamber.
—You want to give the bigger states more money at the expense of the smaller states.
—That is not true, and you know that, Senator Schacht.
—That is what you are on about if you go down the line that Fraser was about.
—That is not true, and you know very well that that did not happen under the Fraser government.
—You are selling out the smaller states.
—Stop parroting your nonsense, straw man.
—Gotcha!

—Prime Minister Hawke repealed the legislation in 1989. Later, recognising the inequities in the existing arrangements, Mr Hawke as Prime Minister also attempted to redress the imbalance that resulted from the repeal of that legislation, Senator Schacht, and to reduce the inefficient, costly and wasteful duplication of administration. However, this initiative was quashed as he bowed to pressure from his centralist opponent, Paul Keating, in the race for the prime ministership and the Labor leadership in 1991.

PARA.TAB: The constitutional basis on which the federal Labor Party depends for tying the revenue to the states is section 96, which states:

During a period of ten years after the establishment of the Commonwealth and thereafter until the Parliament otherwise provides, the Parliament may grant financial assistance to any State on such terms and conditions as the Parliament thinks fit.

SPEECH.PARA: The usual arguments relating to interpretation of constitutional clauses apply. They turn on the word `parliament', interpreted by this Labor government to mean the executive arm of government since it is the Prime Minister who undertakes the negotiations with the states, not as a result of any decision of this parliament.

PARA.TAB: There may be a serious question here as to whether there is an abuse of section 96 of the constitution, particularly since tied grants have increased by over 37 per cent from 38.8 per cent of all states grants in 1983-84, when this government came to office, to an estimated 53.3 per cent in 1995-96. Even more significant and relevant, figures on this issue are an increase in Commonwealth taxation revenue of $13.957 billion in 1995-96.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you want to do—reduce state taxation now? You are a gem. You want to reduce personal taxes at the state level. You are a real genius!
—I have not mentioned anything about that, Senator Schacht.
—But that is what you are implying.

—I am talking about income tax sharing arrangements, not a state income tax, minister. Why don't you listen? Why don't you go back and sort out the Labor Party in South Australia? That is where your troubles are.
—You are selling South Australia out.

—I will continue with my remarks and ignore this rabbiting nonsense that we are hearing from the other side. Even more significant and relevant figures on this issue, as I said, are an increase in Commonwealth taxation revenue of $13.957 billion in 1995-96, of which increase the states are given a meagre 9.88 per cent. Of this 9.88 per cent, 65 per cent is in the form of tied grants—that is, with strings attached—which equates to federal government meddling and reduced flexibility for the states in determining their policy related spending.

PARA.TAB: That 65 per cent of the increase compared with 53 per cent of the total grants for 1995-96 being tied compared with just 39 per cent 10 years ago is a very clear demonstration of the unhealthy trend against genuine federalism under this centralist Labor government. Furthermore, total payments to the states have fallen from 33.1 per cent of total Commonwealth spending to 25.6 per cent of total Commonwealth spending since Labor came to office—a reduction of more than one-fifth.

There are two issues involved. Firstly, the amount provided to the states is insufficient given the revenue increases available to the federal government. The states are being squeezed while the federal government undertakes an uncontrolled spending spree. Secondly, by increasing the level of tied grants, the flexibility available to the states is reduced and the Commonwealth steadily but surely tightens its control.

This state of affairs makes a mockery of state government mandates, with perhaps the exception of Queensland following the last state election—that is a government without a mandate if ever there was one. It shows contempt for the checks and balances of a federal system against centralised power. It denies regional flexibility and permits centralist interference in hospitals, schools, law and order functions, housing, roads—and now with the advent of national competition policy reforms—power and water.

Nowhere is this more apparent than in section 15 of the States Grants (General Purposes) Act 1994. This section allows for funding to be recouped from states which have repealed laws proscribing compulsory student unionism. Not for the first time will the Liberal and National parties attempt to delete section 15 from the act. As I mentioned at length in the debate in this chamber on the Higher Education Funding (Student Organisations) Amendment Bill 1994 in December last year, the concept of compulsory student unionism is anathema to the Liberal and National parties and we will not resile from this position. These terms and conditions are incongruous with general purpose funding and section 15 should be deleted. The federal government relies on the Commonwealth Grants Commission to make recommendations on the provision of state government funding. The Commonwealth Grants Commission goes to extraordinary lengths, using some formidable formulae, to determine its recommendations and I have little complaint with that. The following statement is made in the main findings section of the Commonwealth Grants Commission's report on general revenue grant relativities 1995 update:

SPEECH.PARA: The main role of the Commonwealth Grants Commission is to advise Governments on `per capita relativities'—the measure of the relative needs of States and Territories for financial assistance from the Commonwealth.

Per capita relativities will be applied to untied financial assistance grants and hospital funding grants. Similarly, a method of distribution of arterial road grants, which will increase in line with the consumer price index and population growth, will be applied.

PARA.TAB: Untied road grants are a step in the right direction, but again only a small percentage of the funds collected by this federal Labor government in the form of fuel excise levies are returned to the states for road funding. When Labor came to office in 1983 some 60 per cent of levies were returned for this purpose. It has continually and persistently shrunk ever since that time.

Mr Stuart Hicks, Director General of the Western Australian Department of Transport, earlier this year referred to our roads as an `asset worth about $1 billion'. He went on to ask and answer the following question: `Do we treat these road assets as a national treasure? No way.' To do so becomes exceedingly difficult for state governments are forced to make choices between competing portfolios—health, education, law and order and infrastructure.

Mr Hicks's point that transport is central to our economic prosperity should ring loudly in the government's collective ears. There is very little in the economy which is not in some way affected by transportation costs. The Western Australian task force on road funding in 1981 identified a serious under-investment problem with our roads. Again, the federal Labor government is too blinkered to see the potential problems created by its neglect.

I would like to put on the record some of the figures applicable to my own state of South Australia. General purpose payments to South Australia for 1995-96 will be $1,528.1 million compared with $1,486.1 million for 1994-95. These estimates as final figures will depend on the actual increase in the consumer price index for the four quarters to March 1996. The 1995-96 figure represents an annual increase for South Australia of $42 million, or 2.8 per cent. In addition, there is a $17.4 million payment for better cities funding, taking the total general purpose payments to South Australia to $1,545.5 million.

Specific purpose payments to the states are estimated at $1,086.4 million and specific purpose payments to South Australian local government are estimated at $572.4 million. There is an additional direct payment of $6.6 million to local government. The total gross payment to South Australia will be $3,210.9 million and, after repayment to the Commonwealth of a debt of $109.3 million, the net figure is $3,101.6 million. This equates to a net dollar per capita funding level for South Australians of $2,095.80.

According to the government's Budget Paper No. 3, state governments raised around 58 per cent of their total revenue from their own sources. This amount compares with 90 per cent for Canada, 100 per cent for Germany and 120 per cent for the United States. In the United States, the states actually give revenue to the national account.

In comparison with these other federations, to quote Queensland Labor Premier, Wayne Goss, in a paper delivered to the 2020 Vision Forum in September 1994, Australia's states are `the dependent relations'. Goss supports the proposal that the Commonwealth continue to administer a national personal income tax with the states receiving a fixed share of Commonwealth tax revenue. In support of this proposal—

TALK.START.PARA: —Fixed! Again South Australia would lose.
—We are talking about a fixed gross share. There are still relativities to be adjusted between the states, quite obviously.
—Ha, ha! Oh, yes!

—But what has happened under your government, minister, is that the share has continually diminished, as I pointed out quite clearly earlier in my remarks. The Commonwealth is grabbing more and more of the tax revenue and returning less and less to the states.
—You would be selling South Australia out.
—What we need is a fixed share so that the states have a guaranteed revenue—
—You don't know what you are doing!

—So that they can fulfil their responsibilities. We are not talking about a fixed share between each state; we are talking about a fixed share for the states in total. Don't you understand this? No wonder you have lost control of the South Australian Labor Party, Senator Schacht. You can't even sort out these simple facts.
—And that would ultimately lead to a per capita based allocation.
—What nonsense!
—That is what the big states want.
—To quote your Labor colleague, Premier Goss—

—I raise a point of order. I have been listening to the speech but it is very hard to concentrate on it when there are continual interjections from Senator Schacht. I ask for a ruling on whether his interjections are disorderly. If your opinion is that they are not disorderly, perhaps in your function as a professional doctor you might prescribe something for Senator Schacht for verbal diarrhoea.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Herron)—I would remind Senator Schacht that interruptions are unparliamentary and I suggest to Senator Chapman that he disregard them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to admit that they are not worth responding to, but sometimes I am provoked. As I was saying, Senator Schacht's Labor colleague, the Premier of Queensland, Mr Goss, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Despite protests which come from the Commonwealth, I do not believe that this proposal would compromise the Commonwealth's flexibility to achieve its macro-economic policy through the use of fiscal policy. If Canada and Germany can manage, I am sure Australia can.
Mr Goss also criticises tied grants as being:

governed by agreements which are all too often excessively rigid and overly focussed on operational controls . . . the smallest change in spending arrangements has to be referred to the Commonwealth for approval.

I quote from a member of Labor's own ranks merely to make the point that it is not only those of us on this side who believe that the time for review has come. Clearly, the current arrangements have outlived their usefulness.

PARA.TAB: Along with my colleagues, I urge the government to address the imbalance for the states and to put some genuine reform in place for the benefit of regional Australians in general and South Australians in particular. This proposal to untie the strings attaching to states grants by providing a fixed share of Commonwealth tax revenue in untied grants would certainly give states greater independence within their areas of constitutional jurisdiction. Even more than this, there needs to be consideration given to the states having their own adequate sources of revenue which are quite independent of the Commonwealth coffers.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —The States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill 1995 is not controversial and both sides agree to it. However, the philosophical arguments that Senator Chapman entered into would indicate that there may be some differences of opinion—as one would expect—as indicated by my interjections to some of the philosophies he was talking about in the allocation of federal tax moneys to the states. I think we can accept the fact that the actual bill itself on the allocation of funds is agreed to by both sides.

PARA.TAB: I do want to make one brief comment about the philosophical argument that affects the small states. I am not surprised that Senator Chapman quotes Premier Goss from Queensland. Most premiers, whether they are Labor or Liberal, from the eastern states, the big states, are in one form or another consistently arguing that the grants money from the federal government, in any of its forms, should be distributed on a per capita basis. Ultimately, that would obviously assist them because they have a bigger population.

Under this bill, I am advised by my officials, that the general revenue assistance on a per capita basis to New South Wales is $731.10 per person; to South Australia—my state—it is $1,032.60 per person; and the average is $864.90. Clearly, under the grants arrangements there has always been a recognition of states' needs, and this government and Prime Minister have been extremely strong in ensuring that there is a balance and the regional needs of the smaller states are taken into account in the allocation of funds to the states. I see Senator Calvert in the chamber. Under this bill, on a per capita basis Tasmania gets $1,393.80 per person, which is considerably more—over $600 per person more—than New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the needs base?
—I strongly endorse, as I am sure Senator Calvert does, the fact that the grants money does have to take into account the special needs of the smaller states.
—And everybody else.

—Yes, and the other disabilities. That is why you need a strong federal government in charge of the allocation of funds to the states. If the smaller states allow it—as I hope never happens—that we end up with a weak federal government that gives in to the pressure of the big, powerful eastern states, the three biggest states, over the allocation, I know the ultimate consequences will be less money for the smaller states as it is distributed on an even basis per capita at $864 per person, as in this bill. That would mean a loss in South Australia, in this bill, of $230 per person multiplied by 1.4 million. You can soon work out what we would lose.

PARA.TAB: Senator Chapman talks about what the Fraser government proposals were and about tying a share back to the states. As soon as you give that pot back to the states there will be one almighty blue over the big states' demand that it be distributed on a per capita basis and the smaller states saying no, quite rightly—regional differences in needs in Australia for even development mean there will have to be more money per capita going to the smaller states.

I do not think Senator Chapman understands that, whether it is a Labor or Liberal state premier in the big states, they have the same view. They want this restructured so they get more money on a per capita basis, at the expense of the smaller states. Before any federal government, whether it is Labor or Liberal, wanders down this track, they ought to realise the consequences in that the smaller states, particularly South Australia, Western Australia and Tasmania, and the territories, will end up a lot worse off.

I strongly support the fact and I am very pleased that the federal government does have this power to allocate funds according to needs of the various states, and does have the power to make decisions about the allocation. As Senator Calvert would know, whether it is a Labor or a Liberal government at a state level over the last decade, on a number of occasions none of them have exactly covered themselves with glory in the way they have handled their state finances.

TALK.START.PARA: —It depends on the level of taxes.

—The public is probably pretty happy that we are now putting more money into the states in tied grants, that it is going to spend to an outcome for the community and not be wasted on some of the grandiose schemes of various state governments in the 1980s around the place, and going back into the 1970s.
—It is different now. You have more Liberal governments—Western Australia, Victoria, South Australia.

—I remember, back in the 1970s, when various states—Liberal states as well—got into the business of allowing their statutory authorities to borrow large amounts of money to get into power generation and so on. It was all added to the state debt. They were given that power by Fraser to go out and get that money to invest. I just make those points because I think the philosophy of Senator Chapman would lead ultimately to something contrary to what is in this bill. But I accept and am pleased that both sides support this bill, and the allocation of funds as outlined in the bill is agreed to by all the parliament. I commend the bill to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
Debate resumed from 16 October, on motion by Senator Crowley:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Governor-General Amendment Bill 1995 is a very brief and simple bill which reduces the salary of the Governor-General. The reduction is being made at the request of Sir William Deane, who asked that the sum set for his salary as Governor-General take into account the fact that he will be receiving a non-contributory pension under the Judges' Pensions Act upon his retirement from the High Court. We support the bill and commend his initiative. I also take the opportunity to congratulate him on his appointment. We think it was an excellent choice and he will do a very good job.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for its support for the Governor-General Amendment Bill 1995 and acknowledge that it is introduced at the request of Sir William Deane, who will make an excellent Governor-General. Without wishing to sound partisan in any way, I would acknowledge that, as the appointment expires on 1 January 2001, there is every likelihood he will be the last excellent Governor-General of Australia before the appointment of our first president. I commend the bill to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: VETERANS' AFFAIRS (1995-96 BUDGET MEASURES) LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 17 October, on motion by Senator Schacht:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition does not oppose the Veterans' Affairs (1995-96 Budget Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill 1995. The bill contains 14 measures in all: five measures have no financial impact; five will cost additional money; and five will result in savings. Overall, the net savings in 1995-96 will be around $3.4 million and $8.6 million by 1998-99.

PARA.TAB: The government has already identified some of the main measures in the bill. The bill extends the eligibility for a defence service home loan for full-time members of World War II women's services; it increases flexibility in the use of the housing loan to accommodate the changing need for veterans as they grow older; and it extends the option to insure under the defence services homes insurance scheme to all persons eligible under the Defence Service Homes Act. There are a number of other changes.

The bottom line is that this bill is keeping the legislation up to date in ensuring that the changing circumstances of veterans are accommodated, and this is welcomed as the needs of our veterans are kept in the spotlight. Remembering the changing circumstances of veterans, it was mentioned in the other place by the relevant shadow minister that there is a concern that the bill does not incorporate the concerns of Vietnam veterans. Most of the Vietnam veterans are 50 years of age or thereabouts, but the bill does not cover some of their concerns.

It is interesting also, and it should be recorded, that yesterday the government put in place recognition of the three surviving Victoria Cross winners—Sir Roden Cutler, Mr Keith Payne and Mr Edward (Ted) Kenna—by their eligibility for gold passes for domestic fares. We on this side commend the government's action and we welcome the recognition of the surviving Victoria Cross winners.

One of the other things that I should allude to in this bill, of course, is that the privatisation of the repatriation hospitals—Hollywood, and Greenslopes in Brisbane—is a success and that the effect of privatisation has been welcomed by veterans. However, the privatisation of the hospitals again brings home the hypocrisy of the government. On the one hand, the government says that Medicare provides the ultimate in provision of hospital services. The government also says that all is rosy and that we should all salute and give alleluias for the benefits that privatisation dispenses. On the other hand, of course, the government is privatising repatriation hospitals and talking about the marvellous benefits privatising brings to veterans. The government is also saying that this is a highlight of the changes in the legislation. Once again, it demonstrates the total hypocrisy of the government and this hypocrisy is worth bringing to light in this debate.
As I mentioned previously, the coalition is not opposing the legislation and we on this side believe that the benefits that it will bring to veterans are worthwhile.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank Senator Herron—other than for his remark at the end about Medicare—and the coalition for their support for the Veterans' Affairs (1995-96 Budget Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill 1995. As Senator Herron said and as was outlined in the minister's second reading speech, the bill is like an omnibus bill in bringing up to date a number of measures in veteran's affairs. The bill extends a number of benefits which I think the community will welcome, particularly in this year, the 50th commemoration of the end of the Second World War.

PARA.TAB: As a colleague of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Sciacca), I place on record my congratulations for the successful, nonpartisan and community spirited celebrations that occurred across Australia. What is particularly pleasing is the way in which so many young people—two generations away from the events of the Second World War—participated in and responded to the celebrations in so many different ways.

It is interesting to note today that Mr Sciacca has announced that our three remaining Victoria Cross winners, Sir Roden Cutler, Mr Edward Kenna and Mr Keith Payne have now been granted a gold pass equivalent to 25 free flights per year to travel around Australia. As federal members of parliament, we may occasionally be criticised because of our entitlement to fly around Australia on parliamentary business.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not held in the same respect.

—With all due respect to both of us, Senator Herron, I do not think we can equate ourselves with a Victoria Cross winner. I cannot imagine anybody in the community saying anything other than that this is an excellent recognition of these three obviously courageous people who served their country: two in the Second World War and one in the Vietnam War. It shows the strong desire in our community to recognise our history and the contribution of many hundreds of thousands of service people in all wars who have served this country so well. It is appropriate that we make that comment about those three VC winners today when we are now putting this bill through the parliament. I commend the bill to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate)

If not, it clearly causes inconvenience for those senators who might have had it in mind to put some questions to her.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate)

If it has not arrived, I apologise; but I signed it off some time yesterday morning, so it should have come through the internal processes. When I get back to my office, I will check to make sure it was dispatched expeditiously, but I think it was.

—My question is directed to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the unprecedented intervention of Mr Bill Kelty in the Coles Myer saga by taking action which could only be designed to assist the interests of trucking magnate Lindsay Fox and his fellow Reserve Bank board member Mr Solomon Lew in questioning the basis for concerns expressed by the AMP Society.
