Given that Mr Kelty claims to represent the interests of at least some of the battlers, although clearly not the 760,000 unemployed, will the government indicate why Mr Peter Sams, the Secretary of the New South Wales Trades and Labour Council, is not absolutely right in saying that Mr Kelty's actions have nothing to do with the trade union movement? Are you happy to condone trade union supremos swanning around at Toorak dinner parties and running errands for the mega-rich rather than looking after the real interests of all those who are forced to pay membership fees to the ACTU?

—When I woke up this morning, I do not know that I noticed a change in the executive council arrangements so that I have responsibility as spokesman for Bill Kelty. If you have any questions or any statements about Mr Kelty, you can go outside and say them and maybe he will avail himself of the same means as he has against other people.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I know you are new in the job, but one of your responsibilities is to state government policy and government attitudes to issues of the day. Here you have someone who is a de facto cabinet minister and with whom you have just signed on for a seventh accord. So don't let's just pretend he is just another player in the game. He is very much someone with whom you and your government have a daily association. I am simply asking you whether you are going to walk away from him on this occasion, or whether you are perfectly content for your government to be associated with someone who is supposed to represent the working class, supposed to represent those who do not have $2 million homes in Woollahra. Do you see any problems with him intervening on behalf of Mr Fox and Mr Lew? Has Peter Sams not got it absolutely right when he says that Kelty's obligations are to look after those he represents? Are you relaxed about this? Don't you have a view, or don't you really care? (Time expired)

—I do not have a view on every issue in the world. Nor, as I said before, am I a spokesman for Mr Kelty. Senator Alston, of course, refers to the `seventh accord'. Of course, there is an eighth accord. That is how ignorant he is on these particular matters. I do not know whether there is anything on the public record about Mr Kelty's intervention. I do not know that anything has been proved about that, and no doubt some of that will be resolved in the court case where Mr Kelty is suing Mr Costello. They might be able to decide the truth of this matter. But there is nothing on the public record on which I have to comment on this particular matter. I do not have responsibility for the ACTU, no matter how much you, Senator Alston, want to go back to the old class warfare cliches that you are so noted for.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a parliamentary delegation from Ghana, led by Mr Samuel Sallas-Mensah. On behalf of honourable senators, I welcome you to the Senate and to Australia and hope that your stay will be both profitable and rewarding.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, Senator Cook. Minister, I note media reports this week about the escape of the rabbit calicivirus undergoing trials on Wardang Island on South Australia's Yorke Peninsula. Could the minister explain how the CSIRO became involved in this work and whether there is any truth in the claims that there has been political interference in the project?

—I thank Senator Burns for the question. A program such as the Australia and New Zealand rabbit calicivirus program is approved and undertaken only, of course, after significant examination and assessment. This particular program was developed to assess the suitability and effectiveness of rabbit calicivirus disease as a biological control mechanism for rabbits.

PARA.TAB: Rabbits cause very serious environmental damage, as I am sure senators know, and the damage is estimated at $100 million a year in lost primary production in Australia. Therefore, control of rabbits is an urgent priority for both environmental and agricultural reasons. Therefore, ultimate responsibility for the rabbit calicivirus program rests with two ministerial councils. These are the Agriculture and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand, and the Australia and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council.

The program is managed by a committee which has as its members representatives of the two ministerial councils, the Australian Nature Conservation Agency, the CRC for Vertebrate Biocontrol, the CSIRO, the Meat Research Corporation, the International Wool Secretariat, the National Farmers Federation, and the New Zealand Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries. The government Assessment and Facilitation Committee of DPIE is an observer.

Funding for the program is provided by the two ministerial councils, the Meat Research Corporation, the International Wool Secretariat, the New Zealand Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries, and the Bureau of Rural Science. There is no funding provided by the CSIRO. There have been no funding cuts. Allegations of funding cuts are contrary to the facts and are not true.

The CSIRO is contracted by the management committee to provide quite specific services. These are to undertake strategic research and field trials. A three-year program of laboratory research was completed at the Australian Animal Health Laboratories before field trials began in March 1995 on Wardang Island.

The testing pen on Wardang was the subject of detailed design and safety and security protocols which had been developed by a research management committee and approved by AQIS. It had double rabbit proof fencing around the individual warrens as well as double rabbit proof fencing around the quarantined area. The site was, of course, located on an island.

It is most regrettable that the virus escaped initially from the test site and then from the island. I can, however, assure the Senate that all possible measures are being taken to contain the virus. Indeed, I wish to put on record my appreciation for the work being done by the eradication and surveillance teams of Point Pearce, as well as that being done by the local Aboriginal community who have worked with these teams.

Responsibility for control of the outbreak now lies with the South Australian Department of Primary Industries in conjunction with the Consultative Committee for Exotic Animal Disease and in consultation with the Australia and New Zealand rabbit calicivirus disease program. Surveillance is now being expanded to six eradication units, and they are clearing the warrens within 20 square kilometres of Point Pearce. An information centre has been established in Adelaide, and a hotline has been set up to answer any questions that people may have.Everyone working on this program has been committed and professional—which is more than can be said for the media, who are seeking to make political capital out of what is a serious issue.

The scientific evidence is that there is no danger to species other than the European rabbit. Containment at Point Pearce has been undertaken not because CSIRO believes that there is any risk to other species but because the approval to release the virus has not yet been agreed; and, if the virus is released, it would be in a controlled way to ensure its effectiveness. A decision for release has not been made and could only be made after the experiment is complete and following proper community consultation.

There has been no political interference in the research project, as was wrongly alleged on the ABC news last night. The coordinator of the RCD program, Mr Nicholas Newland, has today publicly refuted this allegation. Funding—particularly CSIRO funding—is not, and never has been, an issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Cook representing the Treasurer. Yesterday a major report confirmed that your government's regressive indirect and company taxes have contributed to income inequality, that the relative earnings of the lowest-paid full-time workers have declined and that the richest 20 per cent of families earn up to 13 times as much as the lowest 20 per cent and five times as much when government cash transfers are included. In the light of these findings, how can you have the gall to be party to the barefaced misrepresentation in your latest propaganda, which should have been called `Destroying the nation', that under your government inequality in earnings has not declined. The question is, Minister: isn't it a fact that, despite your propaganda, there is a widening gap between the rich and the poor?

—Senator Patterson asked me a question referring to a report unnamed, unsourced and unreferenced. The description of that report unnamed, unsourced and unreferenced bears no comparison to reports that I know have recently been released on this issue. Until she designates what particular report she is referring to, I frankly do not know what she is talking about because the facts do not resemble anything that she has described in this chamber.

PARA.TAB: From that unnamed, unreferenced and unsourced report Senator Patterson draws a number of conclusions about the people in Australia, particularly the wealthy and the poor. I can say categorically that the evidence is quite clear on this subject: the rich are not getting richer and the poor are not getting poorer in Australia. That is the fact under this government.

When the coalition was in power it was not true because, in fact, the rich got richer and the poor got poorer. The attempts by the previous government to abolish a safety net, to do damage to the welfare structure in Australia, ensured that those in a position in society least able to protect themselves were the victims. The government of the day, the Fraser government—of which Mr Howard, now Leader of the Opposition, was then Treasurer—blamed the victims and penalised them for lack of incentive.

That is not an approach that this government has. We have a safety net. We have a properly balanced welfare program. We adjust that program to protect individuals in a position in society not to protect themselves. Any allegation that the rich have got richer and the poor have got poorer is not true. Perhaps this extraordinary piece of research referred to by the Senator—unnamed, unsourced and unreferenced—might shed some light on it, if only she had the courage to tell us what she is quoting from and what her references are.

The National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling, which maintains a surveillance of the disparities between wealth and poverty in Australia, has constantly reported on this matter. The key findings of its report, many of which have been reported earlier, include that much of the growing income inequality evident up to 1989-90 was driven by changes in the inequality of market income; that changes made to the social security system during the 1980s—that is, by us—partially offset this market income inequality; and, further, that the change in inequality was again less once income taxes were included, with the income tax system having a greater effect on reducing inequality at the end of the decade than at the beginning. Those are the authoritative findings of this research.

The NATSEM agency undertook further analysis to estimate what happened up to 1994-95 and to take account of the social wage. The result of that analysis included that, in the 1994-95 year, the top 20 per cent of Australian families had market incomes that were about 13 times higher than the bottom 20 per cent of families and that the cash transfer system reduced this gap between the top and the bottom 20 per cent by just under five times. There is nothing in this question that suggests the honourable senator is referring to this authoritative research. It goes on: once the income tax system is included, the ratio between the top and the bottom falls by just under four times and, in NATSEM's estimate of the impact of education, health and housing subsidies, the ratio gets down to just under three times.

I frankly do not know what the senator is talking about, but perhaps if she would address her attention to the authoritative research in this field she would learn something and she would cease this silly political provocation of pretending that a Labor government has no concern for the underprivileged when we have pioneered and built that concern into our welfare system. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I suppose your staff have been on strike for so long that they have not actually drawn your attention to the front page of the Australian today and the report by Ann Harding. That is the report to which I am referring. I also refer to the fact that the Prime Minister has admitted there is an increased gap between rich and poor. I ask you: why was it necessary yesterday for Senator Crowley to announce $2.5 million in additional money for people who are facing a crisis? Isn't that a final admission that your policies have failed and, as a result, there is an increasing number of people struggling to make ends meet?

—I make three important observations. Now that the senator has identified the report, I can say she selectively quoted from it to misrepresent it, and the quotations I have made are accurate and put it into proper context. The second point is that my staff were on strike on Tuesday to participate in a national day of protest in the state of Western Australia, in solidarity with Western Australian workers, in opposition to the state government's anti-worker industrial relations legislation. That is the fact. I frankly endorse them doing that because I too, like them, find that anti-worker legislation repugnant and against the interests of battlers in this economy.

PARA.TAB: The third thing about what Senator Crowley has said is that it only exhibits this government's ongoing concern for people in positions in our society who cannot defend themselves and who need the strong arm of government to help, protect and lift them up in society. What Senator Crowley was saying was how we are doing that in the latest round of attention to that problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. It arises because of the announcement by the United States late last year that it will withdraw its F111 aircraft from service. I expect that this decision could have some consequences for our fleet of F111s. Therefore, can the minister advise the Senate what arrangements have been made to ensure that our F111s are supported through to the end of their service?

—The announcement by the United States Air Force to withdraw their F111 aircraft from service by around 1998 will make the Australian air force the sole operator of F111s in the world. A key priority for Defence has been the development of a strategy for ensuring the continued support of our own fleet. I have had several discussions with the US Defense Secretary, William Perry, firstly at the AUSMIN talks in April. There he indicated a very firm commitment to assisting us in maintaining our F111 capability. Secretary Perry confirmed this again when I met with him in Hawaii in September.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased to announce to and advise the Senate that when I met the US Secretary of the Air Force, Dr Sheila Widnall, yesterday she advised us of the United States Air Force's agreement to the pricing of F111 spares for the Royal Australian Air Force at just 10 per cent of their inventory price. This applies to the great bulk of unique F111 spares which USAF manages. Staff in the Pentagon are also working to achieve similar reductions for other spares managed centrally by the US Defense Logistics Agency. This special arrangement will result in a very significantly reduced cost and will make it much easier to secure the spares needed to support the fleet through its remaining years of service with the Royal Australian Air Force.

It is true that some of the spares—the short life spares—will not be available through this and will be more expensive, but the very massive savings we have made on the more substantial and larger spares will go to funding these short life items. What we have done by purchasing another 15 ex-USAF F111Gs is extend the life of the fleet. We are involved in an avionics upgrade to bring them up to the most modern aircraft possible. The assistance provided by the United States on this matter I think is a further demonstration of the strength and closeness of our relationship.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Has Telstra reached agreement with the Human Rights Commission on how it will provide telephone typewriters, or TTYs, to people with speech and hearing impairments in accordance with the commission's decision that Telstra's failure to provide TTYs amounts to discrimination under the Disability Discrimination Act? Is Telstra planning to appeal, or has it already appealed, the commission's decision? If so, what effect will that have on Telstra's provision of TTYs to people with speech and hearing impediments?

—This is obviously a question of great importance to a small section of Australians. To those to whom it is important, it is very important. I am advised that a Telstra proposal for the provision of telephone typewriters to one individual and to people in the class represented by the other party to the action before the Human Rights Commission was put before the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission on 29 August. I understand that this was in response to an earlier finding by the commission in relation to Telstra's obligation to provide telephone typewriters under the Disability Discrimination Act 1992.

PARA.TAB: I am advised that the Telstra proposal for an equipment program was taken into consideration in the commissioner's determination on this matter, which was published on 6 September. I am further advised by Telstra that Telstra reached a settlement with the individual complainant in this case on 6 September. Telstra has advised that the company is developing an equipment scheme consistent with the proposal put before the commission. Obviously the government would expect Telstra to fully meet its obligations under the Disability Discrimination Act. The Commonwealth has also provided funds for an equipment access program to assist eligible applicants with the purchase of telephone typewriter machines and other communication devices.

With regard to the second question, I am advised that Telstra lodged an appeal in the Federal Court in relation to the Human Rights Commission's original findings regarding the provision of telephone typewriters to people in the class taking the action; that is, the profoundly deaf. This appeal has not yet been heard. Telstra is still considering its further action in relation to the proposed appeal, which we regard as a commercial matter for Telstra.

Telstra has continued to participate in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission processes involved in implementing the original finding regarding the provision of telephone typewriter machines. It is developing an equipment scheme consistent with the proposal put before the commission on 29 August. I am further advised that Telstra is separately preparing a disability action plan which will involve an audit of its products and services to ensure that their provisions comply with the Disability Discrimination Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Is the minister aware of suggestions by the tourism industry that Australia should abandon its universal visa system and introduce a visa free arrangement for certain countries? Is the government interested in a system which, on the basis of people's nationality, demands that some people require visas while others do not? What is the government's rationale for the system we now have in place? Is there any evidence to suggest that visa requirements are having an adverse impact on visits to Australia?

—I have seen claims by Mr Baird about our visa system, its rationale and its operation. I say at the outset that not only are they ill-informed and ill-researched; they are also quite offensive. I do not think they do the Australian tourism industry any good. This is very much an irrational contribution to an important debate. By big-noting himself, Mr Baird is doing merely that in Tokyo at Australia's expense. The Joint Standing Committee on Migration is investigating this area. In the meantime, a number of questions need to be addressed.

PARA.TAB: Our starting point is that it is in the national and economic interest that we check people's health and character, whether they want to stay on, whether they are likely to work illegally and whether they will place an unnecessary burden on our asylum processing if they want to come to Australia. We are not alone in that respect. All countries want to protect their borders. The choice is very much whether they do so by screening before people arrive at a country or whether they do so at arrival at busy airports after long trips, which requires enormous resources.

This country has had a bipartisan approach to visa checking. We have had that approach because we have decided as a parliament that it is smarter to keep criminals, people who abuse and people who have health risks out of Australia than it is to try to get them out once they are here. It is a continuing concern. Only during the last 18 months or so we have had cause, for instance, to deny visas to the Japanese nerve gas sect, the Aum Shinri Kyo sect, or the Supreme Truth, when they have tried on a number of occasions to get visas into the country.

There are good reasons for having a visa processing system. We have been keen to use our resources to ensure that we have a faster and more efficient system. We have the most advanced system of visa processing in the world. We have worked at it with technology and resources. It now takes some 44 seconds, on average, for people to be processed at the border.

We have worked at it by introducing agency arrangements in more than 16 countries, whereby people can get a visa when they apply and pay for their ticket. They can get a visa through an agency arrangement. They do not have to go to the Australian embassy. As Mr Baird should know, such agency arrangements have been operating through Japan and in Japan for some five years now.

Next year we will be introducing electronic travel authorities which will make it even faster. In the course of this year, as I mentioned in this parliament a few weeks ago, we have introduced advanced passenger clearance systems with Customs and Qantas, whereby people spend some 20 seconds when they arrive at our borders.

What has been the impact of our current visa system? Senator McKiernan, if you look at tourism into Australia, we have had to handle a huge increase in demand. For instance, in 1984-85 one million tourists came to Australia. In 1994-95 that figure was up to some three million. From Japan, we are now getting some 720,000 tourists a year, worth $2 billion in export earnings. We expect that figure will increase to 1.2 million, almost double, by the year 2000.

With this massive increase in numbers, we have managed to achieve a massive decrease in the number of illegal overstayers. Now we get 100th of the rate overstaying that we had a number of years ago. We have more efficient systems. I must say that we are doing it with reduced staff numbers. We now have 25 per cent fewer staff who issue 300 per cent more visas.

It is quite clear, with these facts in mind, Mr Baird has gone off half-cocked. He has got an apology to make to immigration officials who, he claimed, were seeking soft, plush postings in Asia. The staff work hard. In Tokyo, for instance, in one month this year 43,000 visas were issued by people who get nothing near the $400,000 per annum that Mr Baird gets paid.
They do so in dangerous circumstances. Just a few years ago, in 1989, one officer died trying to get 3,000 visas out for migrants from Vietnam.

I think he owes them an apology. He also owes Australia an apology because he is guilty of duplicity in this case. We offered to send a senior official to the forum at which he was speaking. Mr Baird's people and he told us there was no need for that because immigration would not be on the agenda. If he was honest about Australia's interests he would have ensured that our representatives were there to put forward Australia's point of view.

At best, he has got no clue. He throws up figures from 50 million to one billion bucks as being the cost of our visa system. He throws up different figures at different times of the day. As I said earlier, he was just big-noting himself in Tokyo at Australia's expense.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I draw your attention to the last part of my question, where I asked you whether there was any evidence to suggest that the visa requirement was having an adverse impact on visits to Australia. The claim has been made about visas impeding and intruding on visitors, but no hard evidence has so far been presented to the committee. Has any evidence been presented to you or your department?

—There are probably two points to take into account in answering that question. We in Australia have actually experienced an explosion in tourism, and that explosion will continue to the year 2000. As I said, we expect almost a doubling out of Japan by that year with our current systems in place.

PARA.TAB: The one place we can compare our system to is, I suppose, New Zealand, where they have a no visa system. Tourism to that country over recent years has increased by about 11 per cent per annum, whereas to Australia it has increased by some 15 per cent per annum.

Mr Baird does not have the facts to support his case. He does not have Australia's broader national interest to support his case. He is the sort of bloke, for instance, who would allow Al Capone into Australia if he thought he could make a tourist dollar out of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, Senator Cook. Yesterday at question time and again just now you said that your electorate staff had been on strike on Tuesday in support of the Western Australian blockade. I ask why the message on your answering machine in your electorate office started with the following words: `Hello, you have reached the office of Senator Peter Cook. Due to industrial action we are unable to answer your call today. Lengthy and unreasonable delays in finalising the electorate officers salary structure have forced this action.' Is it not true that the award your staff are striking over is in fact a federal award and comes directly under your jurisdiction and responsibility? Why then did you mislead the Senate and say that your staff were striking over legislation to do with Western Australia when it is your legislation?

—I did not mislead the Senate. Were Senator Knowles honest enough to simply read the full part of that transcript, because I have heard the full recorded message, it would make that plain. The fact that she has decided not to do that shows clearly that she wants to try and make some sort of manufactured case here to allege misleading when, in fact, misleading did not occur.

PARA.TAB: My staff in my electorate office were on strike on Tuesday of this week because of their abhorrence of the Western Australian government's industrial legislation and because, as the recorded message on the answering machine said, they wanted, in solidarity with their colleagues in the state of Western Australia, to join the protest against the state government's industrial relations legislation, which, as has been canvassed in this chamber many times, is draconian legislation that employers in the state of Western Australia have condemned. That is the clear fact. That is the clear and utter fact. That is what they were on strike about.

Before you start flinging terms such as `misleading' around this chamber, let us go to the precise use of language. That is what they were on strike about. But they are members of the relevant public service union and that union was in negotiation with the Commonwealth government as well over salaries for electorate staff. As a consequence of that union's decision, a ban had been placed on answering telephones. That was industrial action. They have been and remained at work all of the time, other than on Tuesday, when they were on strike.

TALK.START.PARA: —You lied to the Senate, and you know it
—Mr President, that should be withdrawn. That is a disgusting aspersion.
—Order! That should be withdrawn, that reference to a lie.
—In deference to you—
—Withdraw unconditionally.
—I withdraw.

—You see, the conservatives opposite hate unions, hate workers, and never bother to understand industrial legislation or industrial usage. They confuse, as does the Western Australian government, the idea of industrial action, which can contemplate a wide range of bans, limitations and go-slows, with strikes, which is a total withdrawal of labour. I have answered honestly all the questions put to me by Senator Winston Crane and by other senators in this chamber.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order as to relevance. The question asked by my colleague Senator Knowles was with regard to the message that was on Senator Cook's answering machine. It was nothing to do with an answer to any question that Senator Cook may have given to me or anybody else in this chamber. It was directly to do with what he said. I respectfully ask you, Mr President, to bring him back to the substance of the question, which is that he misled the Senate yesterday. Why cannot he be honest enough to stand up and say, `I made a mistake'?
—On the point of order: Senator Crane has extended the point of order into argument on other things.
—If you are dumb enough not to know the right question to ask, it is your fault.
—I do not think the minister has a right to shout across this chamber that I am dumb enough.
—Senator Cook, if you said that, withdraw it for the sake of peace. I do not think that helps things at all.
—I withdraw it unconditionally, Mr President.
—You are a clown.
—That does not help things either, Senator Ian Macdonald.
—He has been doing that all afternoon. You would expect nothing better, Mr President.
—Get him to withdraw that.
—What, that you have been abusive all afternoon, Senator Macdonald. You have been and everyone on your side knows it.
—I think that is an accurate statement.
—You would.
—That's right. Now you contest the chair.
—Order! Senator Ray, get to the point of order, please.

—The point of order raised by Senator Crane was one of relevance and he is entitled to do that. The question asked of Senator Cook concerned what was on the machine and what in fact his staff did. What Senator Cook is going to do is go to the motives of his staff and explain those. He is quite entitled to do so. He is quite entitled, under pressure from the other side and in the face of all sorts of interjections, to go to the truth of his answers both yesterday and the day before yesterday. That is precisely what he has done. That is precisely why he is in order. If you do not want him to answer those sorts of things, do not write and deliver such provocative questions. You just cannot take it when someone delivers something back.

—I do not know whether Senator Ray was listening very carefully, but I thought the nub of that question was: `Is it not true that the award your staff are striking over is a federal award and has nothing to do with the Western Australian legislation?'
—They weren't striking over that—ever.
—Order, Senator Ray!

—I am sorry that Senator Ray is not prepared to let other people have a decent hearing in this place. The fact is that it is not a question of the motives of staff or what they were doing; it is simply a question of what excuse was given on the machine. If the machine was lying, let us hear about it. If Senator Cook wants to explain how his staff gave the wrong reasons, let him do so. It has nothing to do with motive. It has nothing to do with what else they might have had in mind. It is simply a matter of answering the question.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! This is really getting very silly.
—In your view.
—In my view. Senator Cook clearly answered the precise question and he has the right to embellish that if he wishes to.
—Let me conclude by saying that no-one was on strike over the federal award. What people were doing was engaging in industrial action.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —If you don't understand the law, don't blame me. That is why, Mr President, I used the word `dumb'. Let me qualify my word. If the opposition does not know enough about industrial relations to make a distinction, those opposite should not even bother to ask this question or have an industrial relations policy. Under Western Australian industrial law, industrial action—

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Cook, take your seat. We will wait until we get silence again.

—I made the distinction between withdrawal of labour and the placing of bans. The question asked of me in this chamber was about strikes. I answered that accurately. I have not misled the Senate. Allegations like that simply prove the ignorance of the opposition on matters of industrial relations. I conclude by saying this: if those opposite want to debate me on the subject of industrial relations they will make my day. (Time expired)

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Let me make it clear that we do not hate workers but we sure as heck hate liars—any liar. The fact of the matter is that this same message was on your answering machine 13 days ago and your staff were not answering the telephone. The blockade was on Tuesday. They have not been at work. Why have you misled the Senate? They have been on strike for that length of time purely and simply because you cannot manage industrial relations with your own staff. How many more of your offices have been closed due to such action? Why are they not working and still being paid?

—It is a matter of fact and fact at law that there has been no strike over this award. That is a matter of fact—let us get that clear. Second, I appreciate the admission of Senator Knowles that she hates liars, and I take that as a reflection of the indulgence of the Liberal Party in self-loathing.

—My question is to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Senator Faulkner. Is it true, as reported in the Daily Commercial News, that you have reissued a licence to Pasminco Metals EZ to dump approximately 170,000 tonnes per year of jarosite, the by-product of the company's Tasmanian zinc smelter, at sea 60 nautical miles from Hobart? What action has the government taken to assess the environmental impact of the operation? Given that when dumping at sea commenced in 1973 this was only intended as an interim measure until land-based disposable arrangements had been researched, why are you still allowing this dumping of jarosite slurry to continue? Is it not true that your predecessor, Mrs Kelly, wrote to Pasminco informing it that no future extensions of the licence would occur?

—I have granted Pasminco Australia Ltd a sea dumping permit for its jarosite waste in order to allow time for Pasminco to develop the co-treatment option which it has announced that it intends to use. Co-treatment will eliminate the production of jarosite at the Pasminco Metals EZ plant in Hobart and also eliminate the need to dump at sea. The government last year notified the Secretariat of the London Dumping Convention that Australia reserves the right to continue sea dumping of jarosite until the end of 1997. In issuing the permit, I have told Pasminco Australia Ltd it must stop dumping jarosite waste at sea by the end of 1997.

PARA.TAB: Clearly, sea dumping of jarosite is environmentally unacceptable to the Australian community and internationally, and it must stop. Under no circumstances will there be an extension of the permit for sea dumping of jarosite beyond the end of 1997. From 1 January 1998, the London convention will impose an obligation on Australia to prohibit the dumping of jarosite and it will not be possible for Pasminco to obtain a permit. The government will be complying absolutely with that obligation.

Senator Chamarette asked about the level of assessment. In granting the permit I took into account the results of the public environment report and a five-volume CSIRO report of a comprehensive investigation of Pasminco's jarosite dumping at sea. I can also say that the CSIRO study did not find any evidence that the disposal of jarosite has had an adverse impact on the marine environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister, but is it not true that the EIS undertaken by the CSIRO was sponsored by Pasminco? Does that not entirely compromise the integrity of the statement? What action will you take to ensure an objective assessment is undertaken? Will you please undertake to table all correspondence between Minister Kelly and Pasminco Metals regarding the dumping licence in view of the fact that they will have known for 25 years that their licence would not be extended to continue dumping off the coast?

—First of all, the level of assessment was a public environment report. I do not want to take Senator Chamarette right through the process of environmental impact assessment in Australia but I am sure she would be aware that it is not an unusual thing for a company to fund the assessment process in this way. In relation to the issue of the correspondence between Minister Kelly and Pasminco that she asked me to table, I am happy to have a look at that. I have to be very frank with you and say I have not carried that correspondence with me down to the chamber. I will look at that and, if I am able to, I am happy to table it in the future for your consideration if that is appropriate. Of course, it would have to be correspondence that is not subject to commercial-in-confidence considerations. Apart from that, I am happy to reply at the appropriate time. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. The minister may be aware of renewed complaints about kickbacks, that is, demands for bribes to tour guides and companies to gain business which have emerged in the tourism industry in North Queensland. At any rate he would know that many of these tour guides are holders of working holiday visas. Is the minister aware that many foreign tour companies are rorting the working holiday visa arrangements by employing guides for more than three months or using associated companies to employ a person to do the same job beyond the three-month limit? As the use of working holiday visas is the key to kickbacks in the tourism industry, what is he going to do to solve the problem?

—Senator O'Chee raises one aspect of Mr Baird's contribution that I did not touch on earlier, and that was his very enthusiastic support for total deregulation in this area and to allow people to stay here virtually endlessly. What we are concerned about from this side is that we need to ensure that Australians benefit from migration and from tourism as much as possible. In doing so, we are concerned also to ensure that, for instance, those in Australia of non-English speaking background can also play a role in providing services for tourists who come into Australia with no English language.

PARA.TAB: For instance, this year is the first year in our history where a majority of tourists coming into Australia have come here without English as their language. We are working with the Inbound Tourism Organisation to try to maximise the opportunities for them to use Australian citizens and Australian permanent residents in this industry. In that context I found Mr Baird's comments once again quite irresponsible.

You raise questions of kickbacks. Please give us evidence of that and that evidence will be investigated by the department. The working holiday maker program has been important for Australia in a number of ways. We have had an assessment of that done recently by the Bureau of Immigration, Multicultural and Population Research. It is a program that is also under evaluation at the moment. So if you have any thoughts that you want to put to me on that, please write to me and I will take those into account as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his offer to examine the evidence that I may have of rorts. In that case I invite him to peruse these work records of a foreign-owned tour company which clearly show Japanese working holiday visa workers performing the same job for a period of six months or more. Will the minister cause an urgent audit to be made of such companies to ascertain the level of rorting which is involved, and will he then take urgent steps to ensure that this does not continue and that the appropriately qualified Australian people who cannot get a job in this industry do get a job because they are not pushed out by people who are breaching or circumventing the visa conditions? I seek leave to table the documents.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not an area which comes up anew. The department has always kept a monitoring interest in this area. Whenever instances of rorts come up, breaches of migration law, obviously they have been investigated in the past and they will be in the future. This is a bit of a political stunt, coming in here with a bundle of documents and giving them to me as you are asking the question. I will do with these documents what I should do—pass them on to the relevant people to look into them to see whether there is anything to follow up and, if there is, I am sure they will.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Is the minister aware that land clearing and vegetation removal are still continuing in key habitat areas in northern Queensland and that this is threatening the survival of species such as the mahogany glider, the southern cassowary, the red goshawk and the rufous owl? What concrete action is the government going to take to address this problem and protect these threatened and endangered species? I remind the minister that I asked him back in June to consider providing funding to help protect habitat areas in accordance with the wishes of many of the land-holders. As time is running out, I ask again: will the Commonwealth government be providing money to ensure sufficient habitat is preserved, or will it continue to stand by and watch the inevitable destruction of these species?

—I can say again to Senator Woodley that the clearing of mahogany glider habitats in North Queensland is a matter of great concern to the Commonwealth government. There is a range of factors that are leading to this clearing, but the important point is that the Commonwealth government is working closely with the Queensland government to find a solution.

PARA.TAB: As I did explain to you previously, Senator Woodley, a Commonwealth-state working group has been established to identify priorities and develop an appropriate response to the protection of lowland forest habitats, including those of the mahogany glider. The working group is addressing the likely budgetary implications, the timing and the mechanisms of proposed actions.

I can say, and I am pleased to say, that the working group has made good progress. I expect that the Commonwealth government and the Queensland government will shortly be in a position to consider a package of measures which will effectively deal with what I accept is a very important environmental issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I ask: why has your government allowed federal taxpayers' funds to be used for the printing of a guide on how to shoplift in Judy's punch, a publication produced and distributed to students by the Melbourne University student union, earlier this month?

—I am completely unaware of such a publication. If Senator Hill cares to give us details, I will check with the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, or the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, to see whether there was any involvement from the federal government.

—Minister, are you telling the Senate that you are unaware that your government has paid $1.2 million to the Melbourne University student union, that it has published this shoplifting guide in a student magazine and that it acknowledged that the publication would not have been possible without your federal government funding? Is this not just another example of an irresponsible abuse of taxpayers' money by an arrogant government out of touch with mainstream Australia?

—This supplementary question is just a further joke. Is that the best you can do? If you are suggesting that $1.2 million has gone from the federal government to publish a student magazine, that is absurd. You, Senator Hill, know as well as I do that students also pay fees into their student unions. As I said, I am unaware of it. I will refer it to the minister and come back to you with an answer. But, I have to say, it is an absolutely inconsequential issue.
—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Has the government's work with industry had any effect, and if so what, on the level of greenhouse gas emissions?

—I am pleased to say that more than 50 major Australian companies and industry associations have committed themselves to developing action plans to mitigate their greenhouse gas emissions by joining the greenhouse challenge program. These companies represent a significant proportion of Australia's key energy users and producers. This announcement is an important step forward in meeting the challenge to reduce the level of greenhouse gas emissions in Australia. Our response demands a cooperative approach and I welcome the level of cooperation that industry has shown right from the commencement of this program.

PARA.TAB: The greenhouse challenge program of cooperative agreements follows industry's undertaking to join government in a partnership to tackle the greenhouse gas issue during the development of the Commonwealth's greenhouse 21C package. Cooperative agreements formed the major element of the package and it was estimated that they could yield in the order of 15 million tonnes of greenhouse gas emission reductions by the year 2000.

The companies who have committed to the greenhouse challenge will be known as the founding participants in the program and they have formalised this commitment by lodging a letter of intent. These companies and industry associations have shown leadership and I think they deserve recognition for the commitment they have made.

I can illustrate the range and strength of the commitments given by Australian industries by perhaps just mentioning some of the broad cross-section that have joined up. The participants include the Business Council of Australia, the membership of which includes over 90 of Australia's largest companies; the Metal Trades Industry Association, representing 7,000 companies in the manufacturing, engineering and construction industries; and companies such as BHP, Goodman Fielder, James Hardie Industries Ltd, Shell and BHP.

All these participants have agreed to develop inventories of their greenhouse gas emissions and set out action plans for measures to reduce emissions. I expect that these plans will help firms and industries to make continuous improvements in energy efficiency. This will deliver cost savings to the companies and, at the same time, reduce greenhouse emissions.

I expect that participation in the program will continue to grow with the benefit of the leadership that has been provided by these companies and organisations and also as the program gathers further momentum. My department has also submitted a letter of intent covering its participation in the greenhouse challenge program. With this level of participation, I am confident that Australia will be able to maintain a credible and effective response on greenhouse issues and ensure that we meet our obligations in reducing the level of greenhouse gas emissions in Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is the minister aware that the South Australian employee ombudsman, Mr Gary Collis, a person with a strong trade union leadership background, in his first annual report, which was tabled in the state parliament yesterday, was highly critical of the federal government's industrial relations law, including in the following terms:

QUESTION.PARA: In many cases . . . achieving an Enterprise Agreement has been seriously delayed by the decision of some unions to seek Federal award coverage . . .

In . . . some cases there are no signs of membership approval being sought for such steps and where agreements under the Federal jurisdiction have been obtained it is often hard to see how the members are better off than . . . under the state system.
He states further that the tendency by unions to attempt `template' agreements is:
indistinguishable from an industry award and a complete contradiction of what enterprise bargaining is meant to be.
When will the government legislate to ensure genuine enterprise agreements are fostered rather than hindered? (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the first part of the question from Senator Chapman on whether my attention has been drawn to this is no. Therefore, I cannot confirm or deny what he might have said.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. I understand that the data on Australia's export performance in Asia during the last financial year is now available. In the light of this region's importance as a trade destination, could the minister comment on the major trends that have been observed in our trade with the region and the prospects for further increasing Australia's exports to Asia.

—I thank Senator Chris Evans for that very serious question. It is true that some data has been released recently on our exports to Asia which show, as you would expect, that over the last financial year our exports to this region have continued to grow despite the effects of the drought and despite the sluggish economic performance of our largest trading partner, Japan.

PARA.TAB: Overall, Australian exports to Asia increased by six per cent in the 12 months to June 1995, which made our total exports to Asia now $43.4 billion. To put that in perspective, 10 years ago it was $16.8 billion—$16.8 billion to $43.4 billion over the 10-year period. In the last year, the most important thing to note is that the growth has been across a range of sectors.

In particular, I want to emphasise the growth in elaborately transformed manufactures, which increased by 10 per cent. They now account for 16 per cent of total merchandise exports. People always tend to say, `But off a very low base.' Going back to 1984-85, it was a low base. When we came into office, the base for elaborately transformed manufactured exports was less than $1 billion. But in 1994-95, they were $6.8 billion—a rise of 700 per cent, which is not a bad effort. We have almost made up for the years of the Fraser government.

A recent Reserve Bank report noted that Australian manufactured exports to non-Japan Asia grew at an annual rate of 23 per cent in the decade 1985-94 and, in particular, in the area of processed food. The fastest growing area is in South East Asia where exports grew by 15 per cent to reach $10.5 billion, up from $2.2 billion in 1984-85. In North East Asia, despite the sluggishness in Japan, where our exports grew by only five per cent, in China and Korea they grew in both cases by a satisfactory 15 per cent. This is not a recent or an isolated event; it is part of a consistent pattern of growth which has been established since this government first came into office.

The five-year trend of exports to Asia shows a growth rate of 9.4 per cent. This is one of the reasons why Australians can have confidence that the Australian economy can continue to grow, building on the climate of competitiveness and the export oriented industrial base and the export culture which has developed and which creates the opportunity for continued growth and, therefore, continued employment generation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—Mr President, pursuant to standing order 73(4), I draw to your attention the remark you made at question time that `the minister is entitled to embellish his answer'. I draw your attention to the Concise Oxford Dictionary definition of `embellish', which is `to heighten with fictitious additions'. As standing order 73(4) says, `In answering a question, a Senator shall not debate it', I further draw your attention to previous presidents having repeatedly ruled that issues are not to be debated in ministerial answers and there are certainly not to be any fictitious additions.

—I draw your attention, Mr President, to the fact that questions cannot be asked on matters on the Notice Paper, that you cannot have hypothetical questions and a whole range of other things which sensible presidents ignore—and I suggest you ignore Senator Baume at the same time.
—Your points are noted.
—Mr President, with respect, when you say that the point is noted, I take it that you are saying to us that it was incorrect to welcome fictitious additions to a question by a minister.
—That is not what I said, and that is not what I meant either.

—Mr President, it would be helpful to us if we did know what you meant, because the specific statement you made was that ministers are entitled to embellish their answers. The interpretation given by Senator Baume is clearly correct—that `embellish' means to add a `fictional addition'. If that is not what you intended, would you please clarify that so that when we ask questions in future we will understand under what rules ministers are supposed to answer.

—Perhaps I should have been more careful about the wording. I certainly did not mean anything about `fictitious'. I did mean to say that, once an answer has been given to the precise question asked and a minister wants to explain that further, he or she has a right to do so.

—Mr President, can I suggest that it might be helpful to all concerned if you considered the answer to this matter, because it is clearly a matter of ongoing contention. There have been a number of other occasions when issues of relevance have arisen and presidents have given considered rulings. It would seem to me that you should not be leaving the position so that it is possible for a minister to simply add to an answer because he feels like it, to elaborate because he wants to pad it out.

PARA.TAB: If the standing order relating to relevance is to mean anything, then it means that answers generally should be kept fairly tight and concise and to the point. Therefore, I would ask you to consider the precedents on the matter. Certainly I am sure that you would concede on reflection that the word `embellish' or anything like it is not the appropriate term. We do not, I think, feel much more comfortable with the notion that ministers are allowed to simply go on and add to their answers. They are only allowed to do that within the constraints of the standing orders.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a very short point to make. Can I just point out that, even in the extremely small Concise Oxford Dictionary, the definition given by Senator Baume is in here. It is not the first definition, however. May I suggest, if you are looking at definitions of the word `embellish', that you look at, first of all, the first and second definitions in the Concise Oxford Dictionary and then, after that, you go to the Macquarie Dictionary. You should look at all definitions of the word `embellish' before you rule on it.

—Mr President, can I just draw your attention further to standing order 73. I note that it states that questions shall not contain arguments, inferences, imputations, epithets or ironical expressions. Wouldn't that mean that every question Senator Baume has ever asked would not be in order?

—Mr President, Senator Bourne deliberately then misrepresented me totally by claiming that a dictionary definition relating to buildings and beautifying was, in fact, relating to narrative. The definition I gave is the only definition relating to narrative, and what I took to be Senator Cook's activity was in narrative. I do not think he was building anything except digging a grave for himself.
—Order! There have been numerous rulings given on this by my predecessors, and by me for that matter, but I am happy to make another statement if you want me to. I will take that on notice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a brief personal explanation on the grounds as I claim to have been misrepresented.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night on the ABC TV 7 p.m. News an item was aired on the calicivirus. The report was by Mr James Schofield, the ABC's science reporter. In the news item an edited version of an interview I gave live yesterday to the ABC's World at Noon program was used. On the World at Noon, I said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there is a strong body of opinion—not one that I subscribe to, but nonetheless respectable scientific opinion—that maybe the best thing the Government can do is let the virus run, because it will then meet the need that farmers cry out for in this country of dealing with the rabbit plague.

I draw attention to the words in that quote `not one that I subscribe to'. I also said towards the end of this interview, in response to another question and in relation to putting into context the possible danger to humans and other species of this virus:
But, again, I put against, that, a respectable body of scientific opinion is, `Well, now that it's out, why don't you let it go?'

The ABC TV News used this quote out of context. The point I made on the World at Noon is similar to what I told the Senate in question time yesterday when, in answer to a question from Senator Ferguson, I said:

. . . that there is a body of respectable scientific opinion that says that the best thing that can happen now is to let the virus run. That is not my preferred position; I am certainly not in favour of that.

I also said this on the Murray McNicol program on radio 5AN in Adelaide yesterday. The James Schofield piece on the ABC TV News last night edited the World at Noon quote. What was put to air on the 7 p.m. News was:
A respectable body of scientific opinion is, `Well, now that it's out, why don't you let it go?'

The reference was to part of what I said—and that was the only thing that was aired—not my view opposing the alleged respectable body of opinion nor any clear contextual meaning of what I said or what I believed about that opinion. The editing in the James Schofield piece made it sound to the innocent viewer as though I favoured `letting the virus run'. I do not. My view is, and I quote my words on radio 5AN yesterday:

. . . now that it has escaped there is also a respectable body of scientific evidence and farmer opinion that argues for let it run, because it doesn't harm humans, it doesn't harm other species. It deals with rabbits, they're the number one pest, and let it run. That's not my view. My view is let's complete the experiment in the proper way, give the results, make a decision, authorise its release.

My office has drawn this issue to the attention of the ABC TV News. Reporter Schofield agrees that the tape had been edited and my complete view had been omitted. But he also advised my office that he will not correct it.

PARA.TAB: I have caused this matter to be taken to a higher level of responsibility within the ABC and requested a response by question time. Just now, I have received a response. I am advised that the ABC's initial response states:

SPEECH.PARA: The ABC did not mean to imply in its 7.00 pm news story that the Minister supported the views of some scientists that the virus should be released. However, if the use of the briefer version of the Minister's description of that view led to an interpretation that the Minister supported this particular view, then that was not the ABC's intention.
The ABC has not confirmed any intention to make a correction on air about what it has broadcast. In the same item last night, Mr Nicholas Newland and I were reported as follows:
Schofield:"Science Minister, Peter Cook, pitched in to rebut suggestions that the problems were caused by underfunding."
Cook: "This particular program has not been cut back, and so no-one can blame a lack of funding for this particular program as the reason for the escape."
Schofield:"But it later emerged that even if the funding was sufficient, the research has been cut back and subjected to political pressure."
Newland: "The sort of thing that can happen is that, if . . . if governments are, for example, coming up to elections, then they may well be looking for some positive result.
All we've had is people say, `Well, do you really need to do this . . . this much research? Why can't you release it earlier?'"

This program has not been subject to funding cuts. I answered a detailed question on that in question time today from Senator Burns. It is funded by the Agricultural and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand, the Australia and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council, the Meat Research Corporation, the International Wool Secretariat, the New Zealand Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries, and the Bureau of Resource Science. None of this funding has been reduced since the original budget was struck.

PARA.TAB: I also point out that Mr Nicholas Newland, quoted in the program, today reaffirmed that no political pressure had been applied to the RCD program. He said he told the ABC that suggestions that the program had been subjected to any political interference were unfounded and that a quote from him had subsequently been used out of context in the ABC News story. He said that in the release he put out.

This is a sorry incident. The only fair conclusion is that the ABC's science reporter, James Schofield, invented and reported a story that did not exist. Tapes from interviews were edited to suit the invention and not the facts. While admitting as much, no correction or retraction at this time appears intended. This suggests that a serious national story in which precision is necessary for factual and accurate reporting was deliberately and wilfully misrepresented. It is a misrepresentation of me and of Mr Newland.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement in respect of a matter about which I claim to have been misrepresented. There have been 800 in the past four months but there is just one in particular that I would like to refer to at the moment.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not go through the details. I seek the leave of the Senate to have incorporated in Hansard an article by Kookaburra which has the normal slimy, dishonest, untruthful garbage which seems to come from people such as Seccombe, together with a response from the person to whom it referred. It relates to an alleged incident at a restaurant at which I had the pleasure of the company of one Laurie Oakes. It is symptomatic of what we are seeing today in the Sydney Morning Herald and I will say more about Mr Seccombe and his personal life in due course. But for the time being, I wish to have both documents incorporated.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—On the matter raised by Senator Crichton-Browne: ordinarily, as Senator Crichton-Browne is aware, the normal courtesy if a matter is to be incorporated in Hansard, is for the document to be shown to the minister on duty. I do not know what the arrangements of the opposition are. You have not done that, Senator. I doubt that I would have a problem with the documents but I am not willing to grant leave until I have at least seen what you are referring to.

—by leave—With your indulgence, Madam Deputy President, can I make a brief statement? I would have thought, the way the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has been complaining about the Sydney Morning Herald, you, Senator Faulkner, would have been clapping, not complaining, but I am very happy to read out both documents. I was seeking not to do that because, quite frankly, it lowers the standard of this chamber. You are welcome to hear both but you do make a valid point. I have not approached you because until a few minutes ago when I received a response from the restaurant owner I was not in a position to consult anybody. But you make a very sensible point, and I apologise.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I was not making a partisan point. It is a strong matter of principle that government ministers in this chamber—I do not know the arrangements of the opposition and other senators—do not grant leave for the incorporation in Hansard of documents unless they have been sighted by the minister. Everyone in this chamber knows that is the case. There are no special arrangements. I am not intending to insult you, Senator Crichton-Browne, but I think you are aware of those procedures. As soon as I have sighted them, if there is no problem I will certainly grant leave for them to be incorporated.
—by leave—Through you, Madam Deputy President, I do not know when that is going to be.
—I'll do it now. Just hand them over.

—I am not going to break into a jog and run around and give them to you. Can I say, Minister, with respect, that for once you have the chance of being on the front foot. I would not have thought you would make a big deal of it.
—I am not making a deal of it; I am just drawing attention to a process you are well aware of.
—Senator Faulkner, address your remarks through the chair, please.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) to a question without notice asked by Senator Patterson this day, relating to the economy.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cook said this in answer to a question I asked about the increasing gap between the rich and the poor:
I can say categorically that the evidence is quite clear on this subject: the rich are not getting richer and the poor are not getting poorer in Australia.
He went on with some more gabble. He then said:
Any allegation that the rich have got richer and the poor have got poorer is not true.

I do not know who to believe. I do not believe either the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) or Senator Cook. But the Prime Minister admitted earlier this month that the gap between the rich and the poor has widened.

PARA.TAB: Somebody has to be wrong. Senator Cook says that it has not become wider. He said categorically that the rich are not getting richer and the poor are not getting poorer. He also said that any allegation that the rich have become richer and the poor have become poorer is not true. His Prime Minister has told the Australian public that there has been an increased gap between the rich and the poor.

You do not have to be very bright to realise that there is a huge discrepancy between what Senator Cook said here in the chamber today and what the Prime Minister has said. I do not know where Senator Cook has been. All you have to do is go out into the community to find that, after the recession we had to have, Australians do not feel any better off. There is a widening gap between the rich and the poor.

Over the past 12 months, a report from the Australian Bureau of Statistics has found that 24 per cent of all families have no family member employed, that more than 700,000 children under 15 live in families where no-one has a job, and that one in 10 couple families with dependent children has both partners out of work. I know that was in November 1994, but it is very difficult to always have the most up-to-date statistics. Things have not changed that drastically.

The Australian Institute of Health and Welfare has estimated that the number of people living under the poverty line over the past 10 years of the Labor government has increased. We have had 13 years of people getting poorer. The Human Rights Commissioner has said similar things. ACOSS has warned about increasing levels of poverty. Professor Ann Harding, in her report, which she released yesterday, and Professor Helen Hughes say the same thing. Over the last 12 months, all these people have come out over and again providing evidence of the increasing gap between the rich and the poor. Senator Cook stood here today saying that there is not an increasing gap. That totally contradicts Prime Minister Keating, who says there is one.

They do not go into the community—I suppose the Prime Minister spreads his time between his mansion in Woollahra and the Lodge—to see that people are finding it more and more difficult to pay their bills. I suppose that on the one hand the government is trying to say that there is not a problem. On the other hand, the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) yesterday had to give another $2.3 million to families in crisis. Why is that? Because the agencies—the Brotherhood of St Lawrence, the Salvation Army, the Smith Family and the Red Cross—are all telling us that there has been no reduction in the number of people who are struggling to make ends meet. They are getting as many calls and demands on their services as they were before.

In the Christmas before the last election, what did the Prime Minister do? He said to the charities, `We will give you one dollar for every dollar that you raise. We will match one dollar for every dollar.' But when they went to sign the fine line, they found that it was every dollar that they had spent over the Christmas period. It meant millions of dollars less than what the charities thought they were going to get.

The government threw money before the people at the last election in a trick way. Again, Senator Crowley yesterday threw $2.3 million at people. That is what they are doing. It is another pre-election promise. The charities did not get any money before last Christmas. Last year, I asked whether the government were going to do anything before last Christmas. They did not do anything. Why are they doing it before Christmas this year? Because there is an election. That is what they are doing. This money was not available last year. About this time last year, I asked whether they would give money like they did before the 1990 election. Senator Crowley said no. Guess what? They have come up with $2.3 million this year. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on the same matter, purely and simply because Senator Cook, in response to Senator Patterson, repeated his claim of yesterday that the staff in his electorate office had not been on strike due to Senator Cook's legislation or industrial award—a federal award—they had been on strike because of the Western Australian blockade. Further to Senator Cook's answer today, it is crystal clear that what has been happening to the people of Australia by staff of Labor senators and members is a massive defrauding of the Australian public. These people have been on strike, getting paid and not serving the constituents, for which they are employed.

PARA.TAB: Through you, Madam Deputy President, I ask Senator Murphy whether his staff have been on strike. I know that Senator McKiernan's staff have been on strike because constituents have said they could not get through on the phone. There are so many of these people. Senator Cook has two offices in Perth. People could not get through to them. Senator Murphy, who is a great interjector at the best of times, when asked a direct question through you, Madam Deputy President, went absolutely blank. The answer is: obviously his staff have been on strike as well.

Minister Lawrence's staff have not been answering the phone. The staff of the President of the Senate in his electorate office have not been answering their phones. Minister Beazley's staff have not been answering their phones. Minister Gear's staff have not either. The staff of another bloke who thinks he is a minister, Mr Smith, have not answered their phones. The staff of ex-minister Fatin have not been answering their phones. Heaven only knows what is happening with the staff of Senators McKiernan and Chris Evans, because they do not answer their phones at the best of times, for this very reason.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's very unfair, Sue.

—I say to Senator McKiernan, through you, Madam Deputy President, that I am talking in relation to this. I am not talking about other times at all. I am talking in relation to this. Your message machine said exactly the same as I read out at question time today.

PARA.TAB: Will those staff get paid? That is the million dollar question. Will those staff get paid for the days that they have not worked? They have not been working because they have not been answering constituents' inquiries. If so, why will they get paid? Under what loophole are you going to pay these people?

How long have they been on strike? How many work days have actually been lost right across the country by Labor senators and members staff? When is the situation going to be resolved? Obviously, the fraud that has been committed by these staff members not working is absolutely and utterly disgraceful. If they are lurking around in the offices and not answering constituents' inquiries, why are they there? They should not be there. If they are on strike, they are on strike.
Minister Cook said today he had heard his own message machine. Obviously he has not been able to get through to his own office, unless in the end he got through—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to pay back the Commonwealth for all the phone calls you have made?

—I am glad you raised that, because it was actually constituents who reported it to us. They first reported it to us 13 days ago. This is the interesting thing: I wonder whether Senator Cook eventually got through on a line into his electorate office that is actually there for the use of the candidate for Stirling. Senator Cook has a line set aside in his electorate office for the candidate for Stirling. That office line was actually being answered on a day when his electorate office phones were not. If that is not just playing Mickey Mouse with taxpayers' money, what is?

PARA.TAB: This minister can come in here and tell us one thing when quite clearly another thing is happening. How dare he say that the only reason they were on strike was the Western Australian blockade when as far back as 13 days ago his staff and the staff of most of these Labor Party people here and in the other chamber were on strike then. It is disgraceful to think that they can commit this fraud on the taxpayer. They should not be allowed to. How you can possibly justify it, I do not know.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is the height of hypocrisy for Senator Patterson to get up and lay claim to our placing any burden upon the Australian people when, as I have said before in this chamber, every wage increase that workers have sought over the last 13 years has been opposed by you people. So do not come in here and read the riot act to us. With regard to people being able to take industrial action, Senator Knowles has used this opportunity to misrepresent and I think mislead the Senate. She said that Senator Cook misled the Senate. I think exactly the opposite has happened. Senator Knowles read a message or part of a message—

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Go ahead, Senator Murphy. I wanted to hear what you were saying.
—Thank you, Madam Deputy President. I would like to read the entire message that is on the answering machine in Senator Cook's office. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: You have called the office of Senator Peter Cook. Due to industrial action we are unable to answer your call today. Lengthy and unreasonable delays in finalising the electorate staff salary restructure have forced this action. Staff have also taken action today in solidarity with other West Australians in protest against the Court Liberal government's regressive industrial laws. Please leave a message and we will get back to you asap.

It is very enlightening to see the opposition taking the position that they have over this issue. I would like to read from yesterday's Hansard the question of Senate Crane to Senator Cook. Senator Crane asked:
Why was your office on strike yesterday, how long have they been on strike and when are they going back to work?
Senator Cook, in answer, stated:

My office was closed down yesterday, Senator Crane, because my staff, along with a lot of other workers in Western Australia, were rallying in support of industrial democracy and fair and proper industrial standards and expressing their solidarity and opposition to the Western Australian draconian industrial relations laws.

That is the fact of the matter. Senator Cook has never misrepresented or misled the Senate. But I would suggest, Senator Knowles, that you have. Regarding the staff pay claim, I am very interested in and very curious about what you people did. Did you round up all your staff in a little corner, threaten them and tell them that they were not allowed to participate in any industrial action to try to negotiate a wage increase? Are you in support of the wage claim that the staff people have had? Do you support the pay claim? Well, do you or not? I cannot hear anything! Do you support it or not?

TALK.START.PARA: —We don't even know anything about it.
—They haven't mentioned it. They are very happy with what they have.
—So you do not think they should get a pay increase? Is that what you are saying? Is that what you are telling your staff?
—Order! Senator Murphy, please address your remarks through the chair.
—Thank you, Madam Deputy President. I think it is very curious that those opposite seem to have a view that their staff are not entitled to a pay increase.

PARA.TAB: What is more enlightening for the people of Australia is the fact that this highlights very clearly the opposition's position on industrial relations. If workers take one iota of industrial action to pursue their interests, to pursue their rights and the conditions that they believe they ought to be entitled to, the opposition will never support it.
