The opposition will seek to remove all forms of law that entitle employees to do that. That is what the Australian people have to be able to see. It is becoming very clear to them again. It was clear to them before. They thought they would give the opposition a second chance. However, unfortunately, as I said yesterday, the leopard never changes its spots. Certainly the opposition's spots have not changed. In fact, they have become further ingrained.

SPEECH.PARA: Embargoed until 1700 EAST, 18/10/95
Australia Media Release
18 October 1995
AUSTRALIA-JAPAN TOURISM LEADERS AGREE TO FUTURE STRATEGY

PARA.TAB: Australian and Japanese tourism leaders today called for action to improve Australia's hotel and tourism infrastructure and for a review of Australia's price competitiveness in a joint communique following the first Japan-Australia tourism summit.

The Tokyo summit, attended by 63 tourism industry leaders, was chaired by Mr Jon Hutchison, Managing Director of the Australian Tourist Commission, and Mr Isao Matsuhashi, President of the Japan Travel Bureau.

The summit agreed to a range of measures, including a call for the abolition of visas for Japanese tourists and a relaxation of the conditions governing working visas for Japanese tour guides. It also identified the need to improve the marketing and distribution of Australian travel products and to have competitive pricing.
For the first time, we have the industry leaders from both countries sitting down to reach agreement in the marketplace on a strategy for the future, Mr Hutchison said.

The summit was organised by the Australian Tourist Commission following concern about the future growth of tourism from Japan, Australia's single largest visitor source. More than 720,000 Japanese visited Australia in l994, generating more than $2 billion in export earnings annually. Japanese visitor arrivals are expected to grow to nearly 1.2 million by the year 2000.

SPEECH.PARA: A copy of the summit communique is attached.
AUSTRALIA-JAPAN TOURISM SUMMIT

The following is the text of co-chairmen's statement issued by the members of the Australia-Japan Tourism Summit held in Tokyo on 18 October l995 in association with the 33rd Australia Japan Business Cooperation Committee.

PARA.TAB: This year, the 31st since overseas leisure travel was liberalised in l964, the number of Japanese travelling abroad is showing a favourable increase, and is poised to exceed the corresponding number last year, despite continuing economic uncertainties and the damage inflicted by the Great Hanshin Earthquake. There is also a favourable increase in the number of Japanese travelling to Australia and Japan is expected to retain its status as Australia's No.1 tourism source into the 21st century.

Australia recognises the importance of Japan as its largest tourism source market, while Japan recognises that Australia, with more than 21 times its own surface area, has ample capacity to provide additional international tourism infrastructure in order to sustain healthy growth in the future. In this regard it was agreed that tourism industries in both countries should act in close collaboration with each other.
Australia wishes to maintain its current level of popularity as the most desirable long-haul destination among Japanese tourists.

Since the opening of the new Kansai International Airport in Osaka last year, five airlines have been operating 75 scheduled services per week between Japan and Australia, providing a total of 1.35 million passenger seats per annum.
Tourism is Australia's single most important export, generating well over A$11 billion in export revenue in calendar year 1994.
Growth in the recent past has been very strong with Japanese arrivals to Australia increasing over seven times in the last 10 years.

In l994, 720,000 Japanese visited Australia, consuming between A$1.8-2.0 billion worth of goods and services during their visits. The total value of Japanese tourism to the Australia economy is even greater still, as the above estimate excludes the significant contribution of expenditure on international airfares purchased in Japan.

However, we note that there was a fall in the growth rate of Japanese tourist arrivals in Australia in l994 to about half the rate of growth in the total number of Japanese travelling overseas. In order to bring about a recovery in this growth and to increase Australia's share of arrivals to a level that more reasonably equates to Australia's popularity and to establish a sound foundation for future growth, we believe that the following matters require examination:
Changing economic, cultural, and demographic circumstances in Japan and impact on Japanese travel habits.
A maturing of the Australian tourism destination as perceived by and presented to the Japanese public
Increasing international competition.
The pressure on infrastructure and service needs created by the growth in importance and popularity of Australia as a tourist destination.
A relatively low market share for Australia in relation to its popularity.

The Australia-Japan Tourism Summit was convened to assist in the process of assessing the current and future environment and potential strategies emanating from this review with the purpose of achieving a commitment to work towards the following objectives:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.The improvement and development of tourism infrastructure.

PARA.TAB: Increased infrastructure development in major tourism centres, particularly international standard hotel accommodation in Sydney, Gold Coast, Cairns, Brisbane, Perth and the Northern Territory.

To maximise the use of existing infrastructure by spreading activities and locations. The ATC, state and territory tourist commissions and transport organisations will research new destination options and prepare suggested itineraries for appropriate market segments.

SPEECH.PARA: 2.Marketing and distribution.

PARA.TAB: The development and distribution of highly competitive travel products appropriate to a broader market in Japan.

More coordinated destination promotion by the Australian Tourist Commission (ATC) , state and territory tourist commissions, airlines, travel agencies, hoteliers, inbound operators and the like, with an emphasis on converting strong demand into actual travel.
Facilitate the inclusion of new product.
More concerted promotion of affordable FIT travel.
More coordinated effort by Australian product suppliers to communicate new product development through destination promotion missions.
The improvement of travel agent knowledge and skills about Australia through specific training, educational and familiarisation programs.
Create and communicate to the consumer a clearer image of Australia.
Share more consumer and visitor satisfaction research with Japanese industry suppliers.
Proactively communicate ATC's 5 year marketing plan in order to generate a better understanding by the Australian and Japanese industries of ATC's marketing objectives.

SPEECH.PARA: 3.Product pricing.

PARA.TAB: Pricing at levels that are competitive relative to other destinations, while ensuring that reasonable profits are earned by the parties involved.
A review of pricing competitiveness by concerned parties following the Summit is recommended.

SPEECH.PARA: 4.Access-airline services.

PARA.TAB: The establishment of airline services which are closely attuned to the needs of the market and which will maximise the efficient usage of limited accommodation capacity in key tourist centres.

SPEECH.PARA: 5.Visas.

PARA.TAB: The abolition of visa requirements for bona fide Japanese tourists entering Australia and the relaxation of current stringent conditions governing working visas for Japanese tour guides.

DEBATE.SUB2.TITLE: Australian National Audit Office: Annual Report 1994-95

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General:

SPEECH.PARA: This is the first annual report presented by Mr P.J. Barrett, the new Auditor-General. Can I say how pleased I am Mr Barrett chose in his first report to refer to his predecessor, Mr John Taylor, who retired as Auditor-General on 13 January 1995 and who was replaced by Mr Bill Nelson, who acted in the position until Mr Barrett commenced on 2 May.

PARA.TAB: In particular, I think the whole parliament will be pleased to acknowledge that the new Auditor-General has spoken in a very warm way about Mr Taylor's period as Auditor-General. He states in the report:

SPEECH.PARA: John Taylor devoted himself to the duties of this Office with skill and energy. John was responsible for guiding the strategic direction of the ANAO during a period of considerable change and for raising the public profile of the Office in many forums. We wish him well in his retirement.

The Senate has already expressed that view, but I would simply like to reinforce it. However, I do hope that there will be no diminution in the sorts of objectives that Mr Taylor had set for the audit office, in particular the hopes that many of us had about the extent of the reform that was to be undertaken following some years of obvious dispute between the audit office and this government relating to, if you like, the audit office's intrusive involvement in—some might call it quite proper examination of—various matters such as the sports rorts, whiteboard scandal when the Auditor-General examined complaints that I and some other senators, particularly Senator Campbell, had raised relating to this shonky deal that the then minister for sport was undertaking. Without the Auditor-General's strong support, I believe that matter would not have reached its proper conclusion as it did. The Auditor-General said:

The evolving reform environment over the last twelve years is now to be reflected in the bills which are to replace the current Audit Act, and the proposed replacement of the Public Service Act. When enacted, this legislation should provide a robust and flexible legislative framework for public management into the next millennium.

I think we must all recognise that that is not the ideal solution. There are still matters which the previous Auditor-General raised that have not been entirely and satisfactorily resolved. I hope there will still be pressure to ultimately make a better set of reforms. I commend the new Auditor-General for the statement:

We have decided as a policy position that the conduct of financial statement core activities will be undertaken by ANAO office, provided we have the necessary professional capability and demonstrated performance.
He goes on to say:
Our recruitment and personal development policies are being progressively designed to ensure we do.
The ANAO also needs adequate resources. The government has an obligation to ensure that those resources are provided. The Auditor-General goes on:
On the hand, non-core financial statement audits will be undertaken utilising, if cost-effective and appropriate, private sector expertise.

I have discovered that some very substantial private sector accounts which come before the parliament have been dealt with through this exercise of getting private sector accountants to undertake audit office work. The Auditor-General states:

The point I would like to emphasise is that the ANAO's aim, by allocating its own resources mainly to the audits of core government, is to consolidate its expertise and experience in that particular area of public sector activity.

I am glad to see that the area of greatest controversy in which the ANAO has been involved—that is, performance auditing of government bodies—is one area of activity that it is going to retain. I commend the Auditor-General for a comment in the report which states:

The ANAO regards performance auditing as core business and, as such, these audits will be delivered primarily using ANAO staff. Importantly, however, this resource is, and will continue to be, supplemented on a needs basis by specialist external expertise.

I hope that the ANAO will cover as much of this area as possible because I think its objective examinations in the performance auditing area have been exemplary and I commend it for that. The Auditor-General says that there is considerable mutual interest in the outcomes of communication between the ANAO and agencies on performance audits. He stated:

Confidence needs to be promoted in those outcomes for all stakeholders including, importantly, the Parliament. Performance audits offer considerable scope for adding real value to public administration, and in 1994-95 reports tabled made recommendations estimated to realise one-time savings of $96 million (up from $73 million in 1993-94).

That is a one reason the audit office ought to receive adequate funding. There is a good financial reason for that, but there is a greater reason which involves the principle of accountability to the parliament. In my view, that is the major role of the Auditor-General. The Auditor-General says in relation to that topic:
In dealings with the Parliament, as with public sector agencies, the ANAO has an obligation and indeed a responsibility to act in an apolitical, impartial and objective manner.
Under Mr Taylor it certainly did that. I hope it will continue to do that.

PARA.TAB: There is a table on page 46 which makes interesting reading because it demonstrates just how these estimated potential savings from performance audits were arrived at. Interestingly, in the latest financial year the number of recommendations made in efficiency audit reports was only 251—less than half that of the previous year. The number of recommendations made in project performance and follow-up audits was only 82 as against 232 in the previous year. The number of recommendations made in performance reports accepted by the auditee towards estimated efficiency savings, accountability and effectiveness was 297 in 1994-95—less than half the 628 of the year before. And so on.

The number of audits tabled in addition to the ANAO tabling program was only 13 compared to 33 in the previous year and the number of reports tabled within budget in accordance with the ANAO tabling program was only 20 as against 33. However, the result of that apparently much reduced activity was a much greater potential saving arising from these performance audits from $73 million to $96.7 million.

While I certainly commend the improved outcome in money terms, I think many of us in this parliament would not like to see a diminution of energy in the spread of examinations or in the number of recommendations. I am glad to see that the number of performance audit staff as at 30 June 1995 was up to 82 as against 61 in the previous year. I hope that that will encourage greater activity and also, I might say, greater care by the departments being examined.

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Commonwealth funding for the vocational education and training sector for the years 1995 and 1996 has already been appropriated under the Vocational Education and Training Funding Act 1992.
This bill would provide for the supplementation to these amounts in line with price movements.

In 1996 the commonwealth's funding would enable further growth in the number of student places, continue the level of infrastructure support in real terms, and would enable an expansion in funding for national projects in areas of strategic national importance.

The bill would also appropriate funding for 1997, in accordance with the commonwealth's undertaking in the Heads of Government Agreement that established the Australian National Training Authority (ANTA) to provide triennial funding for the vocational education and training sector.

1997 also sees further evidence of the government's commitment to expansion of the vocational education and training sector through the provision of a further $70m in growth funds. This would bring the total growth funding provided by the commonwealth government over the period 1993 to 1997 to $1.55 billion. The commonwealth, in turn, expects states and territories to honour their undertakings in the ANTA agreement including maintaining their own effort in vocational education and training.
The additional growth funding is expected to result in an additional 35,000 student places being made available in 1997.

The Vocational Education and Training Funding Act 1992 allows for the responsible minister to make determinations as to the actual level of funding to ANTA within the annual amounts appropriated under the act. This bill also contains a technical amendment which would clarify that the responsible minister can vary previous determinations made under the act.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill and commend the bill to the Senate.

The matter of substance that I do want to raise is peripheral, I suppose, to the department but it has to do with page 133 of the financial statements. It reveals that there are guarantees and undertakings by the Commonwealth relating to various borrowers. One of them is Telstra Corporation Ltd. Under the Telecommunications Act 1991 there are 28 loans and the total principal amount covered by Commonwealth guarantee is $704 million.

What intrigues me is that Telstra recently wrote to the Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Legislation Committee, expressing the view that it should not be required to come before Senate estimates committees for examination because it was not requiring an appropriation. But here we have the Commonwealth with a massive contingent liability. There is no guarantee to us as senators that that contingent liability will not be called upon in the current financial year. I hope it would not be but there is the potential for it to be called upon. There is a potential expenditure, a capacity for expenditure.

To me it is an absolute nonsense that any organisation like Telstra which has the support of such a guarantee should assert that it is not required to come before an estimates committee. In fact, we have decided to call Telstra before another committee of that same committee, and it will deal with the annual report. I suppose the only significant change that will take place is that instead of the minister or the minister's representative being there to, if you like, guide the senior management of Telstra at the estimates committee meeting, there will be no such minister. There will simply be the chairman and the committee, and the representatives of Telstra will be obliged—and I underline that for Telstra executives—to answer questions; they will be obliged to be responsible; they will be obliged to tell the truth to this committee without the sort of obfuscation we had at the last estimates hearings from some senior executives of Telstra. I found that to be totally unsatisfactory. I think Senator Calvert would endorse the view that some of the answers we got from Telstra at the last estimates committee hearings were far from satisfactory.

TALK.START.PARA: —They always have been.

—Yes. I must say I am interested in this section of the Department of Communications and the Arts annual report which outlines the volume of Commonwealth government guarantee to the Telstra Corporation. I look forward to full and effective answers to all our questions when we have Telstra before our meeting of the committee which will, in its different form, deal with the annual report. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The commission's regulatory powers prior to the superannuation industry supervision legislation were largely limited to checking the compliance status of funds claiming taxation concessions. Since then, particularly with the passage of the SIS legislation, its role has increased exponentially.

PARA.TAB: The commission nowadays places great importance on informing trustees about their prudential management responsibilities. It also checks that funds are well managed. It conducts a series of audits and reviews. If there are weaknesses in funds, the commission points them out and requires trustees to rectify them. On some occasions, the commission uses its stronger SIS powers to take action against particular funds and their auditors. However, I use this opportunity at the tabling of this document to raise several other related matters.

The first is the draft report involving the licensing review of investment advisory services. This draft report is said by the Financial Planning Association of Australia to be built on a framework to regulate the securities industry of the 1980s, where the giving of advice was embraced under the umbrella of a dealer's licence. `To deal' was defined as involving activities designed to induce persons to enter into security transactions.

Today the industry has a far wider role: advice on superannuation, risk insurance, estate planning, savings strategies, retirement planning and social security, et cetera. However, a range of regulators cause problems covering the activities of financial planners: the ASC, ISC, RBA, AFIC, TPC and BBCA. Arising from the statutory requirements of these regulators, it is inevitable that there is a lot of duplication and costly compliance. There have been calls in recent times for the bringing together of the offices of the ASC and the ISC. While I believe that such a merger proposal may be somewhat premature, I call on both the ASC and the ISC to prioritise the need for common definitions and standards, uniform complaint handling, contractual restrictions and particularly the levels of disclosure to overcome all the different levels of compliance required by these five or six regulators.

Honourable senators may recall that historically the ASC and its predecessor were not all that successful in stopping the corporate cowboys literally ripping millions of dollars off shareholders during the 1980s. I do not entirely blame the regulator, because the courts and the wider community have to carry some of the blame. However, we must remember that this was in an environment where these sorts of corporate cowboys were regarded as national heroes. One regulator went so far as to say to me when I raised the question with him, `Not a jury today would convict such local money heroes.' It is a national disgrace that people such as Skase are still living a life of luxury overseas and defying Australian law.

It was into this environment of the late 1980s that the ISC was born. Very quickly, it stopped several potential frauds, including that of Occidental Regal Life, where one of the perpetrators only a few weeks ago received something like a four-year gaol sentence. The commissioner at the time, Richard Beetham, has to take much of the credit for such intervention. Despite these successes and its huge workload, there is still a constant trickle of criticism about the cost of compliance from accountants, superannuation fund administrators and trustees, about the lateness of delivery of annual statutory forms and about a poor educational campaign, which has had some prominence recently, involving $3 million.

With almost $200 billion under investment, naturally the ISC has a wide range of supervisory functions involving four general insurance pieces of legislation as well as regulating insurance intermediaries. For example, there are 988 general insurance brokers, 61 life insurance brokers and over 100,000 different sorts of superannuation funds.

I also take this opportunity to mention a couple of features that the government will have to address in relation to superannuation fairly quickly. They cover award superannuation contributions and the payment of what I term compulsory member contributions and the government matching contributions. Ideally, these should go into a single fund.

There are some problems with the self-employed. Currently, a section 82AAT notice from a member advises the amount of contributions for which a tax has been levied. This continues unchanged under the rules from 1 July 1997. However, an education campaign will be necessary to explain the new arrangements, as up to 25 per cent of a self-employed person's contributions can be nominated as a single non-deductible and eligible for matching government contribution subject to the income test. Later I would like the opportunity to raise other issues that have to be treated as a matter of some priority. (Time expired)
