SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that the Government proposes `to run on its record' at the next federal election;
(b)notes that this record includes:

TAB.TAB: (i)an eight-fold increase in Australia's foreign debt,
(ii)an external account deficit of approximately 6 per cent of gross domestic product,
(iii)record job losses during the Government's self-induced recession in the early 1990s,
(iv)the creation of an unprecedented number of new battlers, as middle Australia was decimated by the Government's economic policies,
(v)unprecedented opportunism in appointments, without regard for Australia's national interest, and
(vi)an inability to control its own expenditure or to exercise due diligence over waste;

PARA.TAB: (c)condemns the Government for this appalling record; and
(d)welcomes the opportunity to expose the Government for this appalling record between now and the forthcoming federal election.

SPEECH.PARA: On 17 October, a couple of days ago, I was interested to read in the Sydney Morning Herald an article by Andrew Darby in Hobart which stated:

PARA.TAB: Australia's biggest union yesterday joined the fight over the "battlers", warning the Keating government these voters would want new policies from Labor at the election.

The Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Beazley, was told bluntly that many people were in pain in the present economic climate and Labor must come up with changes to address the demands of single-income families, in particular.
He accepted what he described as a "barb" from Mr Jim Maher—

SPEECH.PARA: a very noted trade unionist—
who is retiring after 25 years as president of the 235,000-member Shop Distributive and Allied Employees' Association.

PARA.TAB: Mr Maher told the union's annual conference: "There are many people in Australia today who are suffering, and suffering hard. Families trying to bring up children, rear them and educate them in the current environment is not easy. They can truly be described as battlers.
"I would . . . hope for the future that the government will, whatever other promises it makes, attempt to look after those genuine Australian families that are today struggling."

SPEECH.PARA: To my amazement, the response of Mr Beazley, the Deputy Prime Minister, to Mr Maher was that the government `would be standing first and foremost on its record' at the next election. Yesterday it was reported in the media that Mr Beazley would be releasing a detailed defence of that record, which would be a key element of the government's strategy for re-election.

PARA.TAB: It was that in particular which prompted me, on behalf of the coalition, to give notice of motion yesterday of the fact that the government did propose to run on its record at the next federal election; to condemn the government for that appalling record; and to welcome the opportunity to expose the government for this appalling record between now and the forthcoming federal election. That is what I and some of my colleagues wish to do in the course of this debate.

No government in the living memory of this country, with the possible exception, of course, of the Whitlam government between 1972 and 1975—the last Labor government, but it was a relatively short lived government—has produced such an appalling record. Of course, in the case of the Hawke and Keating governments, that has been an appalling record that has extended over 13 long, hard and bitter years.

The record which we are very happy to see the government fight the next election on is one of a litany of broken promises. It is a litany of record levels of debt in the Australian economy, of record levels of unemployment, interest rates, family breakdowns, bankruptcies—you name the problems you can think of in an economy and if you look at the record of this government over 13 long, hard years, it is impossible to surpass it. Just have a look, for example, at the question of foreign debt. The total debt that Australia owes to the rest of the world has risen from $23 billion net when this government came to office in 1983 to today's figure of $180 billion. That is $180,000 million. It is equivalent to $10,000 for every man, woman and child in Australia. It is an eight-fold increase during the life of this government.

It is, of course, a consequence of the huge current account deficits run by this government and it means that Australian families and businesses are paying higher interest rates than they otherwise ought. In fact, and I will come back to this later, they are paying amongst the highest interest rates in the world. I am sure that all Australians were absolutely flabbergasted to hear the Treasurer and other leading members of the government, including, although he did not know which way to go from one day to the other, the Prime Minister, assert that the current account problems that we have in Australia, which are the greatest of any western nation, are indeed not a contributing cause to Australia's very high interest rate regime.

I will quote the views of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, a very respected industry organisation, in its July 1995 newsletter. It puts the problem in a very clear perspective. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia has a possible nightmare facing it in the not too distant future as a result of its balance of payments situation. The current account is a long-term problem which is undermining every aspect of Australia's economic life.
Therefore, I interpose, the social fabric of this country as well. The article goes on, rightly:

It is keeping interest rates high, which is slowing growth. It is preventing real incomes from rising. It is putting upward pressure on the consumer price index and creating additional pressure on non-productivity related wage increases. The prospect of further rises in interest rates is making the business community, especially small business, highly tentative about taking on additional investment projects.

It goes on to elaborate on the other problems that arise from all of that. Foreign debt is a huge problem. The current account deficit is indeed a huge problem. At almost six per cent of gross domestic product, the current account deficit has, for the third time under this Labor government, left Australia with banana republicesque external account imbalances. It puts us worst in the industrial world, worse even than Mexico that we used to laugh at. Mexico, in fact, is improving to such an extent that it probably will be in current account surplus next year. It reflects an inability of this government to get its economic policies in order after 12 years so that Australia can compete internationally and actually afford the consumption that we enjoy and want to continue to enjoy in this country.

PARA.TAB: The current account deficit, our external accounts, is the achilles heel of our nation. The underlying problems that cause the lack of competitiveness have gone from bad to worse under this government. Indeed, it was this scenario of a high current account deficit leading to the crippling record interest rates in 1989-90 which sent Australia into the worst recession in 60 years—a recession which, of course, was, on his own admission, deliberately engineered by the now Prime Minister and then Treasurer, Paul Keating.

That recession tore apart the fibre of Australian society. It produced one million people unemployed. When the knives were out for former Prime Minister Hawke by putative Prime Minister Keating, I remember you, Mr Acting Deputy President, in your capacity as a senator from Western Australia, saying that there were 999,000 reasons—it subsequently went over one million—why Paul Keating should never be Prime Minister of this country. Whilst I disagree with you on occasions on matters of policy, Mr Acting Deputy President, on that one you were absolutely spot on.

The fact is that we have a major unemployment problem in Australia as well as a major employment problem. We hear much about the government having created all these hundreds of thousands of jobs in the last two or three years. What we do not hear from the government is the comparison of employment now compared with what it was five years ago. Full-time employment in Australia peaked at 6.3 million people in jobs in July 1990—just five years ago. Five years later, after the recession that Prime Minister Keating said that we had to have—and after his much vaunted 16 quarters of growth—total full-time employment today stands at 6.2 million. In other words, Australia today has almost 100,000 fewer people in full-time employment than we did before the recession. That is in the context of a labour force which is another 500,000 larger due to population growth.

That is the legacy of Labor. That is the record on which the Labor Party proposes to stand at the next election. It is a record of record unemployment. It is a record of record bankruptcies. It is a record of record family breakdowns. It is a record of record homelessness in our society. It is a record of record foreign debt. It is a record of broken promises that no-one could have imagined any leader of any nation—particularly this great nation of Australia—would deliver during his period in office.

The most striking broken promise, of course, was the one on which he arguably won the last election—the l-a-w law tax cuts. In that case he promised Australians $8 billion of tax cuts if they re-elected the government. Within one week of taking office he admitted that he and then Treasurer Dawkins were working out how to get out of the second tranche—the larger tranche consisting of two-thirds of the tax cuts—on which they had won the election. Not only did they break their promise, which was a legislated promise, but they also went through a whole raft of tax increases that they had promised they would not make. Those taxes were in the areas of cars, general sales tax, wines, petrol and the like. We have had a record of record broken promises.

We have had a great and growing divide between the rich and the poor in our country. We now have a situation where many Australians are saying, `This was the land of the fair go. It no longer is the land of the fair go because of what this government had done for us.' Under this government we now have a record of greater inequality with an entrenched underclass locked out of opportunities. We have amongst the highest income taxes in the world. From this government we presently have amongst the highest real interest rates in the industrial world. As of today we have amongst the highest inflation rates in the industrialised world. We have this great tragedy of being amongst the highest youth suicides in the world. That is a figure that ought to stun every Australian.

We have had a record of manipulation of political appointments and government appointments that is beyond belief. I must say that the return of the Australian Ambassador to the United States to head the Prime Minister's attempt to survive at the next election and all the events surrounding that, in my view, produce the ultimate cynicism that people face about these matters.

These are matters of great concern. We have a government which has lowered the standards of propriety and honesty in government to the lowest level that, I think, any of us can ever remember. We have a government which willingly, as I said, lied and deceived its way back into office with a subsequent record of broken promises that has never been contemplated before in this country. We have a government that promised $14 billion of tax cuts at the last election only to deliver $18 billion of tax rises.

If there were a good prospect of economic recovery in the period ahead, one might view these matters in a different light, although the government stands on those records anyway. We on this side of the chamber welcome the opportunity to fight the next election on the government's own record because it is a record that stands in the starkest possible way and will be condemned by each and every Australian.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—Before calling Senator McGauran, I am advised that an informal arrangement has been entered into by honourable senators on speaking times. The arrangements are that Senators Short and West will speak for 15 minutes each and all other senators on the speakers list will speak for eight minutes each. I ask the clerks to set the clocks accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Beazley) of this country released a major statement to advance the government's cause. Yesterday, in the confines of Canberra at the National Press Club, he released a document entitled Shaping the Nation.

PARA.TAB: I know the Australian public have stopped listening to this government, but I really had not thought the Australian press had. This morning when I was flicking through the papers to try to get some information on this major statement the government had released yesterday, by the Deputy Prime Minister no less, I could barely find a comment on it. Buried deep on page 6 of the Australian and the Financial Review—not big circulating papers—were some side comments regarding this major statement by the government.

The truth is that this is just part of a very desperate campaign by the government to attempt to rein back the gap in the polls that has so widened. They know they have to rein that back by Christmas. They know that the public will have solidified their opinions if they do not do that in some way by Christmas. If we can get past the next—

TALK.START.PARA: —What happened at the last election?

—You have got no chance because even the most informed commentators have signalled to the government that that gap in the polls now is unbreachable. But the government has put in place certain stages.

PARA.TAB: The first stage of its campaign to attempt to rein back that gap in the polls was a campaign to discredit John Howard and to produce fear. Well, that failed. We know that failed in the Queensland election quite smartly where Wayne Goss and his cohorts put out the well-known faux postcards which stated that the coalition in Queensland was going to privatise the four hospitals. That completely failed, and we now know that fear campaigns do not work in the federal sphere either.
So the government is into stage two now—to run on its record. That is doomed to failure. What stage three will be is anyone's guess—probably to throw itself at the mercy of the electorate.

I was thumbing through Shaping the Nation—Achievements of the Labor Party, wanting to be fair to the government. I thought that after 13 years of government I was sure to find one or two good achievements to give the government credit where credit is due. No government could possibly be in power for 13 years and not have achieved some good. So I looked at the health and community services section and I saw the heading, `Breast Cancer'. I thought, `Yes, there has been greater awareness in the area of breast cancer, and even perhaps some more expenditure.' Then I remembered that it was Senator Jocelyn Newman who first brought the issue into this chamber and forced the government into making changes. So that cannot be put down as a government initiative.

I looked at the environment section and saw the heading `Whaling'. I thought, `Whaling is a very honourable cause.' Then I remembered that the policy the government is carrying out is no more than a continuation of the Fraser government's enforcement of the banning of whaling and drift-netting. So that is not an achievement at all.

In this bulky blue document called Shaping the Nation I could hardly find one credible achievement in the government's 13 years. But, to give credit where credit is due, there was one achievement, and that was in the veterans' affairs area—the Australia Remembers campaign. We all know that was well done. Congratulations to the minister. But that is about it. Every other area is a statement of failed administration and, worse than failed administration, lost opportunities. When we look back over the 13 years of this government we see that it will be declared a government of lost opportunities.

Even as recently as last night the government was making changes to what it considers to be its most shining initiative, Working Nation. Up until two days ago Working Nation was a document dead in the water. The latest unemployment figures showed that Working Nation was not working. Long-term unemployment had jumped by some 6,000. The trend for unemployment was back up again and all the initiatives were failing. That hurriedly cobbled together cabinet meeting last night was to resuscitate and attempt new initiatives for Working Nation, like the employee subsidy scheme. From the start the government was told that this was full of complexities and difficulties and would never be taken up by the employers, and that is exactly what has happened.

Working Nation in its very first instance was never seriously going to address the unemployment problem. Deep within that document is the evidence. One of the major tenets of Working Nation is that the very best this government could do was to reduce unemployment to the figure of five per cent by the year 2000. That is some 750,000 to 800,000 Australians, which is absolutely no improvement on the unemployment figure as it stands today—763,000. That statement alone in Working Nation enshrines the hopelessness that so many unemployed Australians feel.

If that admission is not bad enough, within Working Nation the statement had a qualifier. To reach that figure of some five per cent unemployment by the year 2000, we needed a growth rate of between 4.5 per cent and five per cent for every year to the year 2000. What is the growth rate at the moment that the government is so proud of? The growth rate has slowed down to 3.5 per cent and we cannot expect any better in 1996.

There have been equally stunning failures—just like Working Nation, all wrapped up in glossy pages—such as Creative Nation. One year on from all the fanfare of Creative Nation, what do we have? Buried within Creative Nation under the additional outlays summary table the government committed itself to some $62 million for the 1994-95 financial year. This was broken up into $45 million for the Australian Multi-media Enterprise and some $17 million for a range of other initiatives. The Multi-media Enterprise initiative has not received a cent in the last 12 months. The other initiatives, totalling some $17 million, have received only $10 million. So that was hollow rhetoric from the very beginning. Creative Nation is now starting to fall over, just like Working Nation.

Then there is the Better Cities program. That has all the hallmarks of sports rorts. It has so many of the hallmarks of sports rorts that it has been referred to the Auditor-General of late and I am sure that that inquiry will come to the same conclusion as with sports rorts. Not one cent of that billion dollars—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President—
—What about National Party policy? What happened to that?

—There is no policy, Senator Sherry. That is why they have to come in here and be destructive, be critical and offer no solutions. I have just raced into the chamber after having the privilege of spending some time—nearly the last three quarters of the hour—in discussion with the Senate rural and regional affairs and transport committee and a delegation from the LDP, the Japanese Diet, about APEC. That would have been a much more constructive discussion to have had here.
—An initiative of the Labor government.

—An initiative of the Labor government. But these discussions showed that a very bipartisan approach was being put and that we do have very serious concerns about any potential threats to erode the agreement that was made in Bogor by all members of APEC. After having very interesting and fulfilling discussions about the importance of this, I have now come down here to listen to the empty rhetoric from the opposition. They offer absolutely no future for this country. They offer no policies. We are becoming used to the fact that they do not have a policy to bless themselves with.
—A recycled leader.
—They have recycled leaders. They do not have any policies. They just want to be negative, be critical and carp as usual. They fail to understand some very basic facts also.

PARA.TAB: They talk about the eightfold increase in Australia's foreign debt. What they do not of course say is that most of it is owned by the private sector and that four per cent of it is owned by the Commonwealth government. They in fact have taken to running around, I hasten to add, in an imported vehicle with flash gimmicky signs on it saying how much the debt is. But we all know that the imported truck broke down and could not get across the Great Dividing Range. It speaks volumes for the Liberal Party's policies that they do not know how to get across the Great Dividing Range. Their truck breaks down when they try to get there.

I would suggest that the National Party actually take a few of them out there and introduce them. I would really like Senator Sandy Macdonald and Senator McGauran to have a talk to the Liberal Party because it has actually set up a committee to look at regional Australia and has not put any members of the National Party on it.

TALK.START.PARA: —You had better give them that.

—We will probably have to give them that. There are no members of the National Party on that committee, and we do know that the National Party people are west of the Great Dividing Range. Also, no shadow spokesperson is on it either, and they would be the appropriate people. So it raises a few questions about the ability of the spokespeople—and it would be a nasty thing for me to criticise or comment on that—but they are obviously making their own comments.

PARA.TAB: They could not get their truck west of the Great Dividing Range. They eventually did, but they failed to tell people that four per cent of the foreign debt is Commonwealth government owned. Over 60 per cent of the debt is owned by the private sector. Therefore, the private sector is responsible for the debt, the repayments of the debt and the interest rates.

What does investment in this country mean? Investment in this country means that business and industry is able to upgrade, update and keep up with the technological and mechanical changes that are absolutely essential for industry in this country. They fail to recognise that manufacturing in this country has increased and is becoming an important export commodity. But, no, they have no policies. They do not think people should be borrowing. So one wonders what they think should happen to our industry. It is pretty obvious they do not think industry in this country is very important. I guess a few of them would like to go back to Mr McEwen's day.

TALK.START.PARA: —Too right.
—They want to go back to Mr McEwen's day. That is wonderful. They would cripple manufacturing and cripple exports. There would be no value adding and lots of imports.
—Agrarian socialism.

—Agrarian socialism. That is the sort of thing that they wish to go back to. That fits in with the Leader of the Opposition's desire to go back to incentivation, which I think is one word that they have referred to. They also want to go back to the white picket fences and their concern for families.

PARA.TAB: They talk about their concern for families. You would think that they are the only ones who are part of a family. We are all part of families. We all share a concern and love for our families. Anybody listening to or reading this debate should not think that the opposition has a monopoly on families. This government has introduced a number of packages which are of great assistance and very important to families.

What does the opposition say about these packages? Senator Minchin said in here several weeks ago that a number of these packages are categorised as expenditure. They class as expenditure the assistance this government provides to families. We all know that the opposition keeps saying that we have to cut government expenditure. We all know, even though they have not announced a policy, that they are planning to cut the expenditure on assistance to families that this government provides. That is what they want to get into. They have no understanding of these issues.

When Mr Howard was in Nyngan he said that the best social welfare system that any country can have is a stable functioning family. He said that the blow-out in the social welfare bill was the result of family breakdown and an ageing population. I am sure the ageing population of this country would like to know that it is responsible for what is alleged to be a welfare blow-out. When you hear the opposition talk about welfare blow-outs and blow-outs in expenditure, it means that they plan to cut expenditure in certain areas. The opposition has a great problem. They will cut expenditure to families.

I note from today's Financial Review that the opposition is not quite sure what it is going to do with Telstra. Senator Alston, the opposition's communications spokesman, said that it would be sold as a going concern. That means the lot gets sold. However, we now have Mr Abbott saying in the other place that perhaps we need to break up Telstra. That is a really good idea!

One would have to ask with the sale and flogging off of Telstra: what is going to happen to the community service obligation that Telstra has? What is the opposition going to do about providing a service to rural and remote areas? Telstra provides a very good service to those areas. What is going to happen to people's communication services in those areas if the Liberals sell off Telstra?

A foreign company would have to buy Telstra because of the amount involved. Therefore, that would mean that our communications system would end up under foreign control. That would result in more foreign debt because they will have to get the borrowings from overseas. They do not talk about that. They talk about the level of foreign debt, but they ignore the fact that this sort of policy would increase the foreign debt. We have also had this week the proposal to resurrect sometime in the future the GST. The opposition is going back to Fightback in terms of their industrial relations policies. They never invent anything. All they are capable of doing is reinventing the wheel.

TALK.START.PARA: —They find new ways of getting beaten.
—That is very true.

PARA.TAB: Senator Forshaw interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Your interjections are very good, Senator Forshaw, but please let me concentrate.
—It is looking like he will get on the front bench.

—Senator Forshaw will be on the front bench in government long before many of those opposite will be. Let us compare the education retention rates between the coalition when it was in power and the Labor government. Education is vitally important because it does not just teach people how to read and write. Education prepares people for life. The more education you can have the better prepared you are. When the coalition left power in 1983, the retention rate for year 12 was 36.3 per cent. In 1995, we now see the retention rate at 74.6 per cent.

PARA.TAB: In some of the conservative held states like Victoria, the retention rate is actually dropping. People are being forced out of school; they are being disencouraged to stay at school and encouraged to leave school. That is a really sad reflection upon the needs of this community.

In 1983, the school participation rate per 1,000 persons aged 15 to 19 was 383—it is now 491. In higher education, there were 250,000 full-time equivalent places—there are now 411,000. The participation rate per 1,000 persons aged 17 to 64 was 36—it is now 51. This means that more people are availing themselves of the opportunity for re-education, for continuing education. These are the sorts of policies that this government has implemented to assist people to get an education and to stay on to get further qualifications.

We have also been working very hard at meshing in the education system, of interlinking so that people can start their education in TAFE and work through and have recognition of that prior learning and those qualifications for their university courses and the like. This is vitally important, because many people who may leave school early, who may drop out, discover later in life that they would like to do some study. They feel that going to university is perhaps beyond them at this stage and they do not have the confidence. By doing some accredited TAFE courses they find that, yes, they can study and they are not `dummies' as they have been told they were for dropping out of school early. They can study and they are motivated to get good results. They are able then to use their TAFE courses to go on to university to do diplomas and degrees.

These improvements to the education system are a vital improvement to the welfare of this country. Whatever we do to this country, we have to ensure that we have an educated community and that people are not just told, `You have not got a job. You are no good, you will not get a job, you do not need any training.' That is what is happening in other countries and, as we come out of this recession, that is what makes us different from other Western developed countries.

In the US you have a very major underclass of poor. There are no programs, no incentives in that country operating to assist those people who have lost jobs, who might never have had a job, to get some skills, to get some education, to get some self-respect and self-esteem and therefore re-enter the work force.

Reading some of Robert Reicht's work, you find that in some other countries people are given financial assistance but they are still not given the training, the jobs and the skills. That is what is so different about Australia. What is so caring about this country is that we are providing these people with financial support, but we are also providing them with skills, with qualifications that they can actually use when they enter the marketplace—and that is vitally important.

As I keep saying, this government does care. We do not have policies from the opposition. How can people make a decision about who should govern this country if only one side is working or has policies and there is an opposition with no policies and obviously no ideas? All they can do is sit and carp and be critical and repetitive. This is a very stark contrast that is available to people in the community to look at. We are a government that is actually working and caring; we have an opposition that will not show us their policies. I guess they are scared their policies are going to be like Jeff Kennett's and Richard Court's. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to support the motion put forward by my colleague Senator Short this afternoon, highlighting the wastefulness of this government. I refer in particular to part (vi) of part (b) of the motion. It states:

PARA.TAB: (b)notes that this record includes: . . .

TAB.TAB: (vi)an inability to control its own expenditure or to exercise due diligence over waste;

SPEECH.PARA: We know that this government will say and do anything to stay in office. We know that there is simply no end to the waste of taxpayers' money and the amount of taxpayers' money that this government is prepared to spend to keep itself in office. We know that this is a government which is obsessed with wasting taxpayers' money in order to look after its special interest groups. This was highlighted today by a question from Senator Hill. We find that this government is funding the student union at Melbourne University to the tune of $1.2 million. We find that that money is going towards funding a book or a periodical that is instructing people on how to shoplift. I think that is an absolutely disgraceful waste of taxpayers' money.

PARA.TAB: Similarly, I found through my waste watch committee that another group called SIC was using government funds to promote male prostitution as a way of working your way through university, and that was highlighted. I must say that at least in that case, when it was highlighted by myself, the minister at the time, Mr Howe, had the decency to cut off their funding. In this particular case, the university has been threatened with loss of funding. But what has happened to the student union? Here they go again running this article on how to shoplift. I think that is another example of how this government allows its special interest groups to waste money.

It is a government that cannot control its wasteful spending. It is a government that is now trying to hide its wasteful spending, just like it is hiding the true youth unemployment figures. For instance, in the way it has changed its Senate estimates committees in terms of what is now open to scrutiny, the government is trying to hide where it is wasting money. Similarly, the way it presents its annual reports is another way of hiding where the waste is.

Recently, it was pointed out that with the arts grants it is very difficult to find out where the money is going—more waste. We had it highlighted in the House of Representatives. At least Ros Kelly had the right idea: she used to put her grants down on a whiteboard. She could wipe them off afterwards, so there was no trace of where her money went.

Chief amongst those people hiding the money is the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) himself. When you try to find out the true facts, what happens? Recently the Prime Minister hosted a party for 100 Labor Party members and hangers-on up at the Lodge. He has refused to answer my questions on how much it cost. I know it cost $7,000 just to hire the crockery and a few chairs, so goodness knows how much they spent on the food and drink they had up there. But no, the Prime Minister has refused to answer those questions.

The same situation arose when I put questions on notice, because I was concerned—as all my colleagues would be and members of the government should be—about the amount of money that seems to be spent on computer hardware and software. We are forever having our computers changed and our programs changed, and I thought it would be a good idea to find out from the government departments just how much taxpayers' money is going on computer software and hardware. One department had the decency to answer very quickly—it was the environment department, one of the smaller departments in the government—and they admitted to spending $43 million on new hardware and software over the last 12 months.

What happened to the rest of the departments? The Prime Minister said, `No, it is too hard to find out.' If these computers are as good as people reckon they are, I would have thought you would only have to press a button to find out how much money the government spent on computer hardware and software for the year. But the Prime Minister refused to let that button be pressed and I could not find out—nor can the taxpayers of Australia know—just how much money has been spent by this government on all this new equipment.

There is no doubt that this government believes it is beyond judgment and beyond accountability. It is an arrogant government. I think that was shown pretty well today when Senator Schacht, in answer to a question, said that the $1.2 million being spent on a magazine that has not only disgusting language all through it but also an article on shoplifting was inconsequential. That is the typical arrogance that we get from this government. They are so blatant about it.

The government has taken jobs for the boys to a new art form. You have got mates like Neville Wran, Malcolm Turnbull and John Spark who have received over $800,000 from the government to act as consultants in the sale of ANL. What a waste of money that was! Former Queensland ALP backbencher Brian Courtice, who by coincidence just happens to have been endorsed for the next federal election, is going to receive over $300,000 in publicly funded consultancies by February 1996. What about our former mate in here, Senator Loosley, who left this place only a short time ago? He does not appear to have taken too long to get his nose into the old Labor Party trough. He is now swanning around the United Nations receiving hundreds of dollars a day to sing the praises of Gareth Evans—no doubt so that Gareth will have somewhere to go when this government is thrown out of office.

This year the government is going to waste over $1.5 million of taxpayers' money on the National Media Liaison Service, the propaganda arm of this government. We also know that $14.5 million has recently been spent on promoting the government's superannuation ideas. Just to give another example: why did the government have to spend $1 million promoting the $20 note? For goodness sake, you have to spend $1 million promoting a $20 note when we all have to use it. I suppose you will spend another $1 million promoting the $50 note. If there is any money left in the bin, you will probably spend another $1 million promoting the $100 note—if you ever get around to making it into plastic.

Anyway, we estimate that, by the time we reach the next election, this government will have spent $50 million of taxpayers' money on promoting itself. Today we hear about them running on their record. The Attorney-General's Department spent over $3 million in developing a law enforcement access network called LEAN. This was intended to be a massive computer link-up of people's various records so that the department would have a very nice record of everybody. The Privacy Commissioner and I raised doubts about whether this would work but, no, the department would not take any notice of us. However, eventually, the department scrapped the whole idea, and therefore wasted $3 million.

We could go on forever talking about the waste of money with this particular government. It is not only the big ticket items but also the small ticket items that we should be concerned about. Just the other week $700,000 was spent on the relocation of a proposed building because they found a legless lizard and an earless dragon. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —If ever you want a reason why the opposition is never going to achieve success at the election, you have just seen it. When it comes to talking about the big issues that face this country and that concern the Australian people, what do we get? We get student newspapers, we get computers and we get appointments. That is what we get from Senator Calvert.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that this government has a proud record. This spurious motion moved by Senator Short says that the government proposes to run on its record. Yes, we will run on our record and we will win on our record, because it is a great record. No amount of running around the countryside by the opposition sanctimoniously pontificating about things like computers will divert the Australian people from examining our record and from comparing it not only with your atrocious record when you were last in government but also with your complete absence of policies about the future of this country.

Let us have a look at the record. Let us first deal with the economy and the period we have enjoyed of unparalleled economic growth—16 consecutive quarters of economic growth. We have an economy today which is internationalised, not like the economy we were left with in 1983 with a huge budget deficit, an economy that had gone to sleep for the 30 years that the government was controlled by the coalition forces. In this time exports in this country nearly doubled as a share of GDP. We have put manufacturing industry on its feet and we have provided the incentives and the investment climate for manufacturing industry and manufacturing exports in this country to grow.

We no longer rely or seek to rely on digging our exports out of the ground or taking them off the back of the sheep and shipping them off overseas as they did back in the McEwen days, as Senator West pointed out. We have restructured this nation's economy. We took on the hard tasks, the tasks that your predecessors—the government that Mr John Howard was the Treasurer of—shirked from ever tackling; that is, doing something about putting this economy and this nation into the rest of the world so that we can compete with the rest of the world.

We all know that restructuring as it has taken place in this country and throughout the world has been at times a painful and a difficult process. That is understood. But it has also been a necessary process. What we have been able to do is bring those changes about in industry at the same time as maintaining a social justice system which protects ordinary Australians. If we are to be criticised for taking those tough decisions then that is a criticism we will happily take on the chin because the Australian people will recognise that we have had the courage to tackle those issues. Those issues include how we coped with the massive rate of technological change and its impact upon industry; and how we tackled bringing about economic and industrial reforms while our commodity prices were collapsing on international markets, while we had one of the most sustained periods of drought in this country and while we had to compete with the protectionist policies of the European Community and the US.

These are very difficult economic times throughout the world yet we in this government have managed to improve the economic position of this country so that we are expanding our trade in Asia and expanding our manufacturing exports. We have one of the best economic records of any country in the OECD. We have one of the lowest inflation rates, yet we also have the economic growth rate being sustained. We have been able to do that and achieve, at the same time—

TALK.START.PARA: —In a drought!

—Yes, in a drought period where so much of our economy is always dependent on our commodity exports. We were able to do that and have stable interest rates at the same time. So because of our government's policies we are doing far better than are most other countries in the world.

PARA.TAB: Let us move to the long list of items which typify the great record of this government and which we could go on about if we had a lot longer. Let us look at superannuation. As Senator Sherry has pointed out, one of the greatest advances in this country is the introduction of superannuation. Now we have over 90 per cent of Australian workers enjoying superannuation. It is an initiative that was opposed all the way by the opposition and by their supporters in the Industrial Relations Commission.

As I pointed out before, whenever we took that issue to the Industrial Relations Commission most of the employers supported your party and were opposing superannuation. Yet superannuation fund assets today are approaching $200 billion. They are already greater than the foreign debt level and they will double within the next five years. So we are building the massive savings and investment base that this country will need into the future and, at the same time, provide the retirement incomes policy that we desperately need to deal with an ageing population. This is an issue on which your party has an absolutely atrocious record. You never did a thing about superannuation in all the years you were in office. It was a privilege to be handed out to the wealthy and the few.

We have reformed taxation by reducing income tax levels to a point where we now have the second lowest tax levels in the OECD. We have lower corporate tax rates. We have rid the country of the only industry that was going forward when you were last in government, which is the tax evasion industry.

Under Working Nation and those great labour market programs, 670,000 jobs have been created since April 1993. We are on track to reduce the unemployment rate, as indicated in the Working Nation program. But what do we get from you? We get whingeing, carping and complaints about these programs, but we do not get any indication of what you would do. You have no policies on how to deal with this important issue concerning the future of young people in this country.

Senator West mentioned education and training. This government is proud of its record in education and training. We now spend $5 billion per year on higher education, and $768 million on direct vocational education and training. Our retention rate has increased. Eighty per cent of people now go on to finish year 12 or gain post-schooling qualifications. That will increase to 95 per cent by the year 2001.

It goes on with social justice, Medicare, health, and family allowances. The list is endless. It is contained in this bulky document, Shaping the Nation, which is a record of achievements of the Labor government. It was launched yesterday by our deputy leader. It is a proud record. It is a bulky document—240 pages—summarising our achievements. There is not even a single picture in it. It is all facts, and it is the record. It stands in stark contrast to the publication that you brought out before the last election, which is the now discredited Fightback document. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion moved by my colleague Senator Short. There are two aspects in this debate that I would particularly like to address: record job losses; and the creation of an unprecedented number of new battlers. You will notice that I am focusing my argument, unlike Senator West and Senator Forshaw, who went into empty, tired rhetoric of the sort that is increasingly produced by this government.

PARA.TAB: We analysed what Senator West said during the 15 minutes that she had to address the substantive issues in this debate. She talked about a delegation that she met with today, the debt truck and a proposed Liberal-National split. She gave a very naive analysis of the foreign debt problem, the GST, John Howard, Mr Abbott and education in Australian states, which she used as an opportunity to attack state Liberal premiers.

Senator Forshaw added to the very cogent government argument by trying to tell us that all of the government's economic policies present a very attractive proposition to the 700,000 unemployed who are still trying to find a job in Australia today. He also clouded the issue by talking about superannuation, which I cannot really see being a topic for debate. It is obvious that he had to resort to talking about total irrelevancies.

Under this government, since 1983, real average weekly earnings have fallen by 0.4 per cent. Under the Labor government, a single income family is $27 per week worse off today in real terms, even taking into account transfer payments. In March 1983, average monthly home loan repayments were around 19 per cent of the median monthly family income. Figures up to May this year suggest that the proportion is now 27 per cent. I presume that the government will not dispute the findings of the Gregory-Hunter study recently announced, which found that, since the mid-1970s, the average real household income of the poorest five per cent of suburbs dropped 23 per cent while the richest five per cent increased their incomes by 23 per cent. The income gap has widened 92 per cent, or $20,000, in 1995 dollars.

According to a recent study, Australia's record of inequality has been worse than that of most other countries in the OECD. By 1990 the wealthiest one per cent of Australians owned 20 per cent of everything; the wealthiest 10 per cent owned 52 per cent; the top 20 per cent owned 72 per cent; and the bottom 50 per cent owned 1.5 per cent of the nation's total wealth. In the developed world only Germany and America are more unequal.

I do not know why Dr Don Russell is bothering to come home from New York because the situation created by his Prime Minister (Mr Keating) here in Australia is already nearly as bad as that which he categorises as `not suitable for human beings' in the United States. He might just as well stay in America rather than come home to assist the government's election effort.
Bob Gregory and Boyd Hunter reported that between 1976 and 1991:

SPEECH.PARA: income distribution has become more unequal and the change is extraordinary. There is a significant increase in the geographic polarisation of household income across Australia.
Professor Gregory, who is head of economics and politics at the Research School of Social Sciences at the ANU, was interviewed earlier this year by Kerry O'Brien. Kerry O'Brien asked:

PARA.TAB: So do we assume readily from that that things got worse after 1991?

SPEECH.PARA: Bob Gregory replied:

PARA.TAB: I think that's probably right. We can check to some degree by using Social Security data, but I think that also confirms that the neighbourhoods are drifting further apart, and you know the rich half of Australia is increasingly disconnected to the poor half of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: What more damning evidence than that could you get?

TALK.START.PARA: —What a proud record!

—That is right. An international study by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation ranked Australia fourth behind Norway, New Zealand and Britain in the growth of inequality in the 13 years from 1979 to 1992. All of this is very damning evidence, but there can be no more damning evidence provided than growth in the unemployment figures. Almost every week figures come out which show that the drop in unemployment is not that which is portrayed by the government and that there is an enormous amount of hidden unemployment, of underemployed people who would like more work and of people who have given up trying to look for work because they know that the jobs are not available. Not only that, the government claims that over 500,000 new jobs have been created since the last election. The actual number of available jobs is only 236,000, a factor which reflects the destruction of employment during the depths of the recession.

PARA.TAB: Many people, once they undertake more than one hour of study or training per week, go off the unemployment figures. This provides a totally distorted figure of the real nature of unemployment. Working Nation could be re-entitled `Queuing Nation', in the sense that people are queuing for jobs, queuing for training and queuing for education. When they come out at the other end and look for a job, what do they find? They get shuffled into another queue to do yet another training program.

We are now well into the fourth year of the economic recovery and unemployment remains at a higher level than what it was at the last point in the last recovery. We have seen a ratcheting up of unemployment which will not be easily removed. This government has failed Australians. It has failed to help unemployed Australians and it has forced those in work to live a life of economic fear and uncertainty because they can see their living standards dropping.

In the very brief time available I would also mention the very damaging social effects of unemployment. It creates further pressure for those people whom we have described as an unprecedented number of new battlers. These people, because of the neighbourhoods they live in, which have been totally neglected by the Labor government, have very little hope of getting a job. That often plays an increasing role in family breakdown and family violence. Unemployment destroys individual wellbeing and self-esteem. Unless it is urgently addressed, we will see an intransigent underclass of exactly the same type mentioned by Dr Russell, which he maintains exists in America and which the coalition maintains is starting to exist in Australia today. The blame should be laid fairly and squarely at the door of the present Keating Labor government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen J.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government can run on its record at the next federal election—and do so successfully. Let me first address Senator Short's contribution regarding the comments of the retiring national president of the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees Association—a large and significant union representing over 200,000 shop assistants within Australia. Senator Short referred to Mr Maher's comments that they were many people suffering and suffering hard in Australia. Yes, the government can acknowledge this. And the government should attempt to look after such families—that is, single income families and other families battling in the current climate.

PARA.TAB: However, the government's record of social reform is ongoing. It has an agenda; it has something to work towards. Part of that is acknowledging where achievements have been made and what areas still need to be addressed. The SDAEA have contributed to this agenda and obviously seek to continue to contribute to this agenda. They have worked for improvements for low income families. They have achieved improvements in family assistance, which is part of this government's record. They have achieved the introduction of the parenting allowance, the impact of which we have yet to see in inequality statistics. They lobbied for and, with the government, improved the situation of many pensioners in Australia by bringing about indexation, a policy which had not been supported in the past by the coalition.

Professor Ann Harding's research report was referred to in question time today by Senator Patterson. This report, entitled What is happening to income inequality in Australia?, was released last night and provides examples of how the government's agenda for improving the lot of battling Australian families is ongoing. Professor Harding points out that income distribution is a subject in which there is keen interest in Australia, and thank God for that. This is probably why the international trend of a growing gap between rich and poor is diminished in Australia. Unlike other countries with policies that the coalition seeks to mirror, the trend here is diminished. Yes, there is a growing gap. Senator Cook did not deny that earlier today. He did point out, however, that the poor are not getting poorer. The social security safety net, established and improved by this government, has been substantially improved. But the problem is ensuring a fair distribution of Australia's growth, and this is an ongoing issue. This is the issue on which the government can stand on its record.

As pointed out by Professor Harding, a boost in business income has been a major factor in growing income discrepancies. A growth in the wages and salaries of senior executives has also assisted in the growing gap between rich and poor. The government acknowledges these problems as factors to be accounted for in its continuing ongoing social reform agenda—an agenda which the coalition lacks. The government's record is in continuing improvements in government cash transfers and social wage benefits. As acknowledged by Professor Harding, social wage services are a very significant component, especially for families with children and elderly persons. `Social wage benefits should not be ignored in the income distribution debate,' Professor Harding says. When government cash transfers are taken into account, the earnings of the top 20 per cent of income earning families drop significantly from 13 times to five times that of the lowest 20 per cent. But this is not good enough, and the government acknowledges that. Our cash benefit transfers make a significant difference, but so too does the social wage overall.

What is not good enough is that the gap between rich and poor is growing. This is why, as cited in Professor Ann Harding's report last night, the government has commissioned a study of trends in income distribution, including non-cash benefits, to be completed soon. Contrary to Senator Troeth's comments, I refer to the final page of Professor Harding's report where she says:

SPEECH.PARA: At the moment there is no data available to tell us whether the distribution of final income has become more or less unequal since 1980.

There is no data, but this government is looking for such data so that it can continue its agenda of reform. The outcome of this study commissioned by the government will contribute to the government's ongoing agenda.

PARA.TAB: But let me conclude on the coalition's record—or should I say `What record?' It is not only that there is no policy in many areas, but there is also no consistent policy. Will we remove the unemployment benefit after nine months, or won't we? Will we introduce a $3 wage for youth, or won't we? Will we cut expenditure or will we preserve the same social safety net? In this context let me conclude by referring to the recent comments by Mrs Bronwyn Bishop and let the Australian public judge. Answering questions last Friday about the changes a Howard government would make to child support, Mrs Bishop said:

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is an important principle that when you bring children into the world you have to remain responsible for them, and it is not the taxpayers' responsibility to pick up the remnants of a family when it breaks up.

What is the taxpayers' responsibility? We need policies from the coalition in terms of what those opposite think is the taxpayers' responsibility. The Australian public needs to know what sort of policies the opposition has. At least the government can stand on a record of a social reform agenda.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in this debate to say that I am very happy for the government to run on its record. I heard Senator Jacinta Collins say a minute ago that the opposition has no policies and that the policies are not consistent. What a contradiction in terms! Then she said that she was going to conclude her contribution. How can you conclude a contribution when you have not made one? They are just side points.

PARA.TAB: I am very happy for this government to run up to the next election on its record. I am especially happy for the government to run on its record on the unemployed and especially the underemployed in Australia. I am very happy for Mr Keating to run to the next election on the consistent mistruths that he used at the last election. The Australian people will not be fooled by his mistruths and misrepresentation of policies this time. When the election is called, Senator Collins, those policies will be spelled out and you will not have any counter to them. Where are your policies leading up to this election, apart from the policy of misrepresenting the opposition and causing industrial strife to beat something up for the election? The government has nothing else, so let us do Western Australia over. Western Australia is the only state in Australia that has a healthy surplus—$11 billion in 1993-94 and probably rising next year.

The Liberal government of Western Australia has helped this government by keeping its total deficit last year at about $28 billion. If it is less than that, Senator Bolkus, get up and tell me. But it is not, Senator Burns.
Senator Burns interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the best thing you can claim this week—`We tried to belt Western Australia over the head'—the only state that had an $11 billion surplus last year and rising this year.

PARA.TAB: Senator Burns interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You go back and sort Queensland out, Senator Burns. Let us get on to the underemployed. We have heard a lot from the government about what they have achieved. They should tell that to the unemployed and the underemployed because they do not understand it. Those in government say that, if you are employed an hour a week, you are employed. You should explain to them the things you are supposed to have done.

PARA.TAB: But I want to address the underemployed today in the limited time I have got left. The underemployed are defined by the Bureau of Statistics as those part-time employed persons who prefer to work more hours than they are working, plus full-time employed persons who work less than 35 hours in that survey week. That is what they are looking at. I said before that this government rates anyone who works an hour a week as underemployed. They are the ones who are looking for work of some sort and are already working.

To test their true figures, let us step back to 1985. This government always tells us what the Fraser government left it in 1983 but never mentions that 1983 had the worst drought on record. It was recorded in June 1985 that there were 607,600 people unemployed, or 8.4 per cent of the labour force. But it was also recorded in 1985 that there were 225,000 underemployed, or 3.1 per cent of the labour force. This meant that 11.5 per cent of the total work force were either unemployed or underemployed.

The comparable figures for June this year, exactly 10 years later, show that the Bureau of Statistics found 724,800 unemployed, a rise of 117,200 on the number of unemployed at the end of those 10 years. This represents 8.1 per cent of the work force, or a fall of only 0.03 per cent on the 1985 figure.

Now for the underemployed. While all that had happened, the number of underemployed skyrocketed to 597,000, an increase of 200 per cent over the 1985 figure. That is why I want this government to run on its record, especially its record of unemployment and underemployment. There has been a 200 per cent increase from 1985 to 1995—all under the Labor government—with an additional 372,000 forced by Keating-created economic circumstances to accept less than they are prepared to work for. A combined total last June of 14.7 per cent of Australia's labour force—and the latest figures show that that has crept to over 15 per cent—was bearing the brunt of the Keating taxation reforms, or Keating's economic failure, which I am happy for it to run on.

It does not matter how the government interprets these figures—we hear every day in question time what it has done since 1983—or what the government may claim to have done alongside this or anything else; the bottom line is that since 1985 the Keating government has allowed an extra 489,200 workers to fall behind either as unemployed or underemployed. Half a million people have been affected by Mr Keating's policies in those days.

We hear day in day out how this government has improved employment in Australia, but they never mention—you never hear the word—the underemployed. In every month's statistics on employment, unemployment and underemployment they are always there, but Senator Cook never mentions it in answers to questions. It is time the government addressed that. Of course, it is far too late. The election has to be held by roughly March next year and nothing this government can do will do anything, unfortunately, for the underemployed. I am very happy, and I am sure my colleagues are very happy, to run on the government's record. Only when we have a coalition government led by John Howard will we be able to do anything about it.
