PARA.TAB: It is quite clear from all the records that under this government the rich have got much richer and the poor have got poorer. The classic example of it, if you need one, is our current Prime Minister (Mr Keating), a man who has been a PAYE tax earner all of his life and suddenly has ended up as a multimillionaire. One must sometimes ask: where did that all come from? But it is part of this government that the rich have got richer and the poor have got poorer.

Mr Keating said, `If you can't get four per cent growth in an economy, you should give the game away.' We are not going to get four per cent growth, yet they still try to say that somehow the economy is going well. Under their own criteria they stand condemned.

If you look at the Labor Party's record on sales tax, you see it has continually increased. Then you should look at the Labor Party's record on fuel tax. When this government came into power, 7c a litre was being paid as excise; it is now 34c a litre—a tax which impacts most heavily upon the poorer in our society, the underprivileged and those living in remote and rural Australia. That is the sort of record that we want to fight in this next election.

Since this government has been in power, the spending in infrastructure has just about halved. They introduced an infrastructure bond a couple of statements ago. It was supposedly going to fix everything that was wrong with Australia's infrastructure. Today we have a government body recommending that that new initiative be scrapped completely. Where is this government going?

One thing they have done very well in this period is give nice names to all their programs. Fancy calling the last major statement Working Nation. It was all about those in the nation who were not working—the million who were unemployed and, more importantly, as Senator Panizza pointed out, the other million who were underemployed. Again, the Labor Party has been skilful in the way they deceived the Australian public in keeping the focus on the million unemployed. They do not talk about the two million who are seeking more work than they are able to get as a result of this government's mismanagement.

The greatest hoax and tragedy is the government's announcement today about so-called adjustments to the Working Nation program. That is going to put unemployed people on a 26-week job with no prospect at the end of that 26 weeks of getting a permanent job. It is putting them on a 26-week project employment program to get them over the next election, and at the end of that project there will be no jobs.

When is this government going to seriously address what is wrong with the Australian economy and seriously address its impediments on small business so that unemployed people can get a real job, not a make-work job that expires when the money runs out in 26 weeks? I had a lot more to say but because Senator Bolkus, in typical fashion, interrupted me, I have been restricted. It is typical for the Labor Party to restrict free speech. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator West had a major job today: she was given the task of leading the government's defence of 13 years of Labor. From her effort today, she is clearly practising for the front bench in opposition. From her performance today, I have a feeling she will be there for a very long time.

PARA.TAB: She attempts to defend the record of caring government as though Labor had invented compassion. But to assume that a government headed by the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, has a mortgage on caring is a line that really could be used in stand-up comedy. Then we had the contributions from Senator Jacinta Collins and Senator Forshaw. I guess, like Senator West, they are practising for a very long period of navel gazing on this side of the chamber as well.

There can be no doubt that the lasting legacy of the Keating government will be our foreign debt and the level of our current account. The Prime Minister says that he has lifted the economic debate. It is interesting that, in the replies to the newsletter that I send to the people in the electorate of Page, which is on the north coast of New South Wales, the mums and dads of Page list our foreign debt as their major concern. I think that that certainly would not have been the case before the 13 years of Labor government.

The simple fact is that this country's debt in net terms has gone from $23 billion to $180 billion in 13 years. It took 195 years to get $23 billion worth of foreign debt and just 13 years to get another $160 billion worth of foreign debt. There are no statistics that can hide the government's failure in this regard.

The Prime Minister talks about the importance of Australia having a national identity and the importance of a republic. There can be no greater threat to Australia's independence, national identity and the way we think about ourselves than the threat of this financial burden that we are leaving our children and our grandchildren and the threat that in a few short years the IMF will have a greater say in the Australian economy than our national parliaments.

The reality of our debt situation is that we have had an eightfold increase in our debt in 12 years. That is an 800 per cent increase. It is interesting to note that the deficit in 1994-95 will be about $26 billion, which is $16 billion up on last year. The OECD expects Australia to have the highest current account deficit as a percentage of GDP in the developed world in 1995 and 1996. Australia's deficit is expected to be about 5.7 per cent of GDP. That is worse than the US at 2.4 per cent, the UK at 1.1 per cent and Canada at 3.3 percent and close to the banana republic levels of the mid-1980s. Other countries such as Japan, France, Italy, Belgium, Denmark, Norway and Sweden enjoy a current account surplus. That also applies to many of our Asian trading neighbours.

It is no coincidence that our bank prime rates are the highest in world and no coincidence that Australia has the worst current account deficit in the industrialised world. The high interest rates reflect a number of factors, including the reliance of the government on monetary policy to manage the economy and large budget deficits. Higher interest rates are demanded by lenders because of the uncertainties caused by the current account deficit, mounting foreign debt and the lack of confidence in the government's capacity to keep inflation low. The prime rate in Australia is 11.5 per cent, in Germany it is 7.5 per cent, in Japan it is three per cent and in the United States it is nine per cent. On any of those figures we are in a very prejudiced position in terms of investment and long-term planning.

Much as the Treasurer (Mr Willis) likes to think that there is no correlation between foreign debt and interest rates, all the experts tell us otherwise. Not one reputable source or, for that matter, one disreputable source backs Mr Willis on this economic frolic.

TALK.START.PARA: —Except Bernie Fraser.
—He does. For instance, BHP's chief, John Prescott, said in response to the May 1995 current account blow-out:

SPEECH.PARA: It's time the government got the message on its balance of trade and did something to correct it. The May 1995 current account deficit is a horrifying figure, with the savings figure even more alarming.

A major US stock broking firm, Merrill Lynch, has warned Australian share market investors that they should be looking to have more than two-thirds of their portfolio outside the country over at least the next year.

PARA.TAB: Mr Keating dismissed financial market concerns about the record current account deficit at the time of the budget as `hysteria'. He described alternative policy prescriptions as `incantations, voodoo or economic snake oil'. He is a good one to be talking about that—the man who said, `You've never had it so good. This is as good as you get. Droughts are a natural occurrence.' He also said, `We've got the position covered. We're not going to run around like chooks with no heads or in a cold sweat.'

In relation to our current account deficit, I would like to make three fundamental points. Firstly, our current account deficit is structurally too high and that is obvious. We have the highest current account deficit in the Western world as a percentage of GDP. It is caused by a lack of savings, both public and private, which the government said it would solve with its superannuation package that is estimated to provide something like a 1.7 per cent increase in savings by the year 2020. Not much of an answer to an 800 per cent increase in foreign debt over the last 13 years. It is caused by roadblocks on our productivity, failures in our tax system, our industrial relations system and our transport system—which all go to make import replacement unobtainable. The great cry that the J-curve was going to save us has been proven to be a long way off.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an I-curve.

—Yes, it is an I-curve. Secondly, when we have a crisis like the drought that we have had for the last four years and a current account deficit already too high and we cannot pay our way, then we just go further into hock.

PARA.TAB: Australia still has 60 per cent of its exports produced from primary industry or our extractive industries. It is a disgrace that an economy which has the advantages of being the largest producer of wool and the largest producer and exporter of iron ore and a large and important producer of coal, bauxite and natural gas, still has an enormous current account getting bigger and an enormous number of unemployed. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to join in this debate this afternoon to refer to one aspect of the motion before the Senate and that is to talk about record job losses during the period of this government's self-induced recession in the early 1990s, and relate that to the actual impact that it has on a family where the breadwinner loses his job.

PARA.TAB: We could talk about many things under the terms of this motion, but all of it really comes back to people and the impact on their lives and on their children. I am sure many of us have received letters from constituents in recent times. I certainly know that my colleagues have. Perhaps Labor members have not. Perhaps constituents have given up trying to impress them with what has occurred and feel that it just is not worth the stamp anymore because they are so out of touch with what is happening in the world that there is little point in trying to relate to them anymore. But I wish to refer to one letter that I have received in my electorate.

Thinking about the sorts of things you hear on the news, men who are apparently intelligent leaders of our community, ministers of this government, talk about economic issues with such jargon. For example, `The economy is on track'—whatever that might mean. `It seems that we've got the settings about right'—whatever that might mean. And, of course, the other quite incredible statement about `never having had it so good'. I actually cringe when I see this happening on television.

Men with that ability, who are supposed to be ministers running this country, dare insult the people of this country by using that sort of meaningless jargon, instead of explaining what is going on and giving some explanation for their conduct. But, no, month after month as the figures come out we get fed this rubbish language that means nothing, that is supposed to seduce people into believing that what is said is true.
This letter that I referred to starts off by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Senator Reid,

PARA.TAB: My letter addresses the worsening financial status of the pensioners, the unemployed and the low-income earners. As an example of my own situation, I have been unemployed for the past four years with a wife and three young boys who are remarkably bright for their age. They see their father at home every morning when they head off to school and they see him sitting at home when they arrive back after a day at school where they are quick to realise that there is not much use in getting involved too deeply in their school-work when there is going to be no work for them when they leave school.

SPEECH.PARA: What hope has this man got of inspiring his three bright sons to do well at school and have careers, and giving them an aim to do something with their lives? He wants to. He is in his mid-forties and has been out of work for four years. He is trying to maintain a home and family in an environment where he can give his boys some values and some aims for their lives. Yet he is left in this situation.

PARA.TAB: He has been on every training course you could think of and a whole lot more of them. He has done every computer course that goes. He does not mind doing that. If there was a job at the end of it he would be delighted, but so far nothing has happened. He feels as though he has been put on the scrap heap. Taken away from him has been the right to bring up his boys to have a career, to have a life and to have some self-respect. He goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: We attempted to sell our home, pay off the mortgage and move elsewhere, where the children could grow up away from the city and it's associated problems. I guess it is no surprise to you that our property didn't even attract an offer during it's four years on the local market where it dropped some 20% in value over that period.
He goes on to outline other issues and matters and says:

I find it very difficult to swallow the fact that multi-million businesses are booming while my wife, my children and I are literally scratching around for food, and wearing clothes from St Vinnies and the Salvation Army. Thank God for these establishments. . .
In the next paragraph of the letter he concludes:
Mrs Reid, we have just spent a cold winter and it was not pleasant.

What I want to do today is to say to government ministers, and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in particular: can't you hear what these people are saying; can't you comprehend the despair of a man who had worked all his life up until his early forties, when he was thrown out of work through no fault of his own, that he is not able to bring up his family and provide for them as he wants to? He is living on welfare and his wife is going out on such days of the week as she is able to do domestic work for others in an attempt to keep the family together. He went on to say:

I heard Mr Keating on an ABC programme of some months back now, explaining that the ongoing recession is necessary to basically bring down our standard of living to enable us to compete with our Asian trade partners. My kids do not give a damn about Asia or it's largely Third World style of life I can assure you and your adversary Mr Keating. Our children are our future. I cannot feed them on rice every night. I cannot feed them on Republican talk.
He continues:
To strengthen my opinion, the word `recession' is rarely heard now, although most indicators show we are simply becoming worse off.
The PS to the letter says:
I am aware that welfare is increased supposedly in keeping with CPI figures but this system has fallen victim to long term erosion of the dollar's value.

He wrote to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) and has put together the figures which indicate that the actual costs of running his family and his household are very much out of kilter and that the CPI adjustments do not keep up. He had a letter back from the Minister for Social Security indicating that these figures are checked out about every 10 years.

PARA.TAB: It is good that they are checked out, but it is not much consolation to my constituent who mainly has to sit at home. He does not have the money to go out and do the sorts of things that people would regard as normal for a man with three young sons. He is despairing of ever getting a job again, having been on welfare for four years and having been on every training course that has been presented to him.

In this debate we should remember the many families in this country that are in this situation. It is not just one that I am bringing to your attention today. There are many in this city, especially in the country, and in this nation who are suffering from the despair that my constituent is suffering from.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion moved by my colleague Senator Short. I do so with one reservation, however, and that is the first part of the motion:

PARA.TAB: (a)notes that the Government proposes `to run on its record' at the next federal election

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is quite clear from the announcement about the recall of the Ambassador to the United States of America, Dr Russell, that the government clearly intends not to run on its record. We hoped that it would, but clearly the recall of Dr Russell, who has been recalled because the office of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has run out of both political guidance and policy advice and support, tells the Australian people—particularly Labor backbenchers and, I presume, Labor frontbenchers and the press in this place and around Australia—that Mr Keating is really in trouble because the government, if it ever had any policy focus in this term of government, certainly has lost it and is desperately groping around to find it.

PARA.TAB: Of course, this appointment of Dr Russell as Mr Keating's adviser in the policy area comes only a short two or three weeks after the so-called glimmer twins, Mr Smith and Mr Swan, are reported in the media to have led a push against the so-called innovation statement by Senator Cook, which in itself is a bit of an oxymoron. They described that statement, we are told, as a bronze medal strategy, as a pathetic policy document. That is what they are reported as calling it. Mr Keating has taken over that policy development, and not even he is able to come up with an innovation statement, or the housing policy we have been promised, or the youth policy he promised—now something like six or seven weeks ago. He said that we would have a new youth statement from this Labor government within a month. Of course, the deadline for that passed a couple of weeks ago.

So this government is in policy fatigue. The reality is that it is looking more and more likely every day that Mr Keating will not be running to the people of Australia at the next election on his record. What an abysmal record to run on. He is going to, of course, come up with a series of policy announcements. I think the interesting thing about that is that, as you move around Australia, you notice that the people have stuck up their shutters when it comes to policy announcements and statements from this government. We have had so many economic statements, so many statements with the word `nation' in it. We have had Working Nation and—

TALK.START.PARA: —Creative Nation.

—Creative Nation—all this sort of stuff. Quite frankly, when you keep giving people these new glossy covered productions like the Shaping the Nation document—a record of Labor's achievements in power—which was launched at the National Press Club yesterday by Mr Beazley, you really start to wonder.

PARA.TAB: This government claim as some of their great achievements the fact that they have got this sustainable growth, that they have got a good economy. In fact, the Prime Minister has said, `This is as good as it ever gets.' Of course, that must strike fear into the hearts of so many people around Australia because they must think, `If this is as good as it gets, what hope have we got?'

I remind the Senate, as I think it needs to be reminded, that we are told by the Prime Minister or the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) or the Treasurer (Mr Willis) that we have got this economic miracle going on here—only to be reminded by people like Rupert Murdoch on the weekend that, if you look at our economy globally, it is, to quote Mr Murdoch, either `terrible' or a `disgrace'. You only need to look at page 142 of the 14 October edition of the Economist—and I think you would have to say that the Economist is a very independent monitor of economic statistics—to see the achievement of this government.

Although the Prime Minister goes on national television and says, `We've got this great low inflation', what is the record of inflation right now, right here in Australia compared to our trading partners in the OECD? For the three-month figures on consumer prices, I think Australia takes the cake. We are on 5.3 per cent. The next closest is Italy on 3.9 per cent. So for this quarter's figures, Australia actually has the highest inflation in the Western world.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is leading the world.

—It is a great achievement for the Prime Minister. He is leading the world again. The world's greatest Prime Minister and the world's greatest Treasurer have topped the scales of inflation. You go and tell the Australian people that you have got low inflation, that that is your great economic achievement. If the people of Australia bought the Economist magazine—I would not recommend it because it is pretty hard going—they would see that the Prime Minister is misleading them. We have the highest inflation this quarter in the Western world.

PARA.TAB: What is the outlook for the year? For the year it is slightly better. We come in second in terms of inflation in the OECD, just behind Italy. They are on 5.8 per cent and our prediction is 4.5 per cent. If you look into the outyears, you see that the expectations for the next year and the year after are that we will be in the top three in the OECD for inflation. So we have high inflation.

What about interest rates? We are told that interest rates are under control and the record on interest rates is appalling. We have had under Mr Keating, either in his role as Treasurer or Prime Minister, the highest interest rates in the real world. The Economist magazine yet again has us level pegging with Italy with the highest interest rates on prime bank lending rates. If you use the deflator, you note that the interest rates are the highest in real terms.

We had Senator Cook get up in this place and tell Australia that Mr Keating is better at delivering low interest rates than Mr Howard was when he was Treasurer. Of course, that is an absolute misinterpretation of the figures. Real interest rates were actually half during the Fraser-Howard era than they are under Mr Keating—exactly half. The figures are—

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't believe that.

—I will table the figures if the minister wants to have them on the record. I am quite happy to if he would like to see them tabled. The average real prime interest rate under the Fraser years was 4.08 per cent. The average under the Hawke-Keating years, right up to the last financial year, is 8.81 per cent—more than double the real interest rate. That is what the small businesses of Australia have to pay if they want to borrow some money and create some jobs for young Australians. That is what we are required to pay, while many of our trading partners can borrow money and expand their operations at two per cent and three per cent discounts on those rates.

PARA.TAB: Of course, we have this massive youth unemployment crisis. We had this so-called Working Nation statement which Mr Crean says is fixing the problem. The reality on the ground is that I have young people saying to me over and over again, day in day out, `It is just a big con. It is just to hide people from the statistics and it does not create any real jobs.'

The sad thing is that Dr Russell said in Washington last week that they have in America a government that does not care about the underclass. In Australia we have a government, led by Mr Keating, that has created an underclass. That is the record we hope you run on at the next election, Minister and Prime Minister, because you have created an underclass. I can not remember in all of my life, until the last two or three years, being begged in the streets of Perth, our home town, Mr Acting Deputy President. That now occurs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to support the motion moved by Senator Short. The people of Australia ought be made aware that, of the 13 speakers that have participated in this debate, only three have presented on behalf of the Labor Party to try to defend their record. The Labor Party wheeled out a troika of triers who completely failed and, after their failure of a contribution, fled the chamber.

PARA.TAB: There are a host of issues this country needs to address—first of all, the overwhelming debt this country faces, the unemployment problem and the current account deficit. The list goes on and on and it is that record that we on this side of the chamber will be presenting to the Australian people. That is why we are so delighted that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has indicated that the government proposes to run on its record.

In relation to the question of debt, one of the Labor contributions, if I can use that term—I would be using it quite loosely—tried to make fun of the Liberal Party's debt truck, which is travelling around this country promoting our concern about the huge international debt that this country has. Somehow, it was made a matter of some jest by the Labor contribution in that this was in fact a light commercial vehicle that was manufactured overseas.

Let us get to the point. The debt truck is a two-tonne Ford trader four-cylinder diesel assembled in Australia and, like commercial vehicles in that range, it is no longer manufactured in Australia. Why? Because after 13 years of Labor the economy is that shot that that type of vehicle can no longer be produced in Australia. The fact that the debt truck is made out of imported parts highlights to the people of Australia the very real difficulties that our economy is in. If the Labor Party see that as a joke, it is a joke on them because it reflects on them. It indicates how terrible a state our economy is in.

We have a huge debt. We on this side of the house will continue to alert the people of Australia to the danger of that. In fact, some years ago Mr Keating, the Prime Minister, was concerned about our high debt and he was also concerned about the current account deficit. What did Mr Keating recommend? Allow me to quote the following passage:

SPEECH.PARA: We were told that people recognised that they had to suffer for the nation's good. Treasurer Keating told us on countless occasions throughout the 1980s how interest rates must be kept high. `We must dampen down demand, mate,' he said, `otherwise the imports will be sucked in and the balance of payments affected.'

From whom do I quote? None other than the former Labor Premier of Victoria, John Cain, in his book. I ask the people of Australia rhetorically: what has happened since that high interest policy, the recession we had to have and all those other things? Imports are still being sucked in and the balance of payments is being affected adversely. In fact, we are having month after month of record current account deficits. All the pain that was inflicted by the Labor government has brought not a single skerrick of gain. That is the Labor Party's record.

PARA.TAB: If we go to the question of unemployment, as a result of this recession we had to have the government has created a large class of permanently unemployed people. The government, because of its absolute ideological commitment to supporting the moribund trade union movement in this country, has introduced legislation such as the unfair dismissal laws which, of course, applies to parliamentarians. Who is the first person to fall foul of the unfair dismissal laws? None other than the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Sciacca. Whilst the Labor Party will preach to the people of Australia that they are genuinely concerned that there be no unfair dismissal, who is the first parliamentarian to fall foul of it? A Labor minister.

The Labor government says that they are concerned about child poverty. What did former Prime Minister Hawke say? He made a promise—remember?—that no child will live in poverty by a certain year. We have passed that year and the number of children living in poverty has, unfortunately, increased. That is another proud record of the Australian Labor government.

In recent times members of the Labor Party, because they cannot defend themselves, seek to draw on Mr Howard's previous ministerial experience. If the Labor Party wants to play that game, we will embrace them. Firstly, because Mr Howard has an excellent record as a minister and Treasurer of this nation and, secondly, if that is the basis for judging Mr Howard's performance, we will take Mr Keating back to when he was a minister in the Whitlam regime. That was the first time he was a minister. We will judge Mr Keating on the performance of the Whitlam era, with the highest inflation rate this country has seen, burgeoning unemployment and minister after minister being sacked. Remember Cairns and all the others who got sacked?

Remember the scandal of the Khemlani loans—a government absolutely rocked. Of course Mr Keating found himself sacked by the Governor-General, as he should have been sacked. That is not the first time the Prime Minister found himself sacked. There was somebody by the name of Mr John McGuinness, who worked for David Jones at the time, who had the good foresight on 15 July 1967 to sack Mr Keating. He provided a number of reasons. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: He was a very arrogant person and often rude to customers. We had complaints about him all the time. I really don't think he's the man to run the country.

Mr McGuinness is an ordinary fellow who used to work at David Jones, but he made a very appropriate decision in 1967. Sir John Kerr made an appropriate decision on 11 November 1975 to sack Mr Keating, again as a minister. I trust that the people of Australia will make it a trifecta for Mr Keating by ensuring that he is sacked as the Prime Minister of this country at the next election. I look forward to a new era in Australia when John Howard and Peter Costello hold the purse strings and Australia can look to growth in employment, a sustainable and stable economy, when the people of Australia will be able to have a future to be proud of. (Time expired)

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1995

PARA.TAB: Message received from the House of Representatives acquainting the Senate that it had agreed to the amendment requested by the Senate to the bill.
Bill (on motion by Senator Bolkus) read a third time.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts References Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts References Committee on arts education, together with submissions and transcript of the evidence. I indicate to the Senate that there are not yet copies of this report available for general distribution. The printed copies of the report are expected to be available by next Tuesday. In the interim interested senators can obtain a copy of the summary and recommendations from the committee secretariat.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion relating to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to first of all thank the secretariat for the very considerable work it did in the preparation of this report. I took over as the chair of this committee when the reference was already before the committee and a considerable amount of evidence had already been taken.

PARA.TAB: By the very nature of the inquiry, the inquiry was an extraordinarily broad one. There was a massive amount of material presented to the committee, and the secretariat really did a magnificent job in pulling that together, particularly Geoff Dawson, who worked tirelessly on the preparation of several drafts. Robert King, the secretary of the committee, and Frances Michaelis also worked extremely well with this committee through many, many months—in fact, several years—of the taking of evidence and preparation of the report.

I would like to point out to the Senate that the committee was indeed very broad, being one into arts education. It involved a consideration of education in all art forms, although most of our witnesses took this to mean the five art forms listed in the national curriculum—that is, dance, drama, media, music and the visual arts.

The committee faced several general difficulties in the interpretation of the evidence and in the making of conclusions and recommendations. The first difficulty was that many of the submissions carried complaints about the status or resourcing of arts education. This was clearly of great concern to very many people. However, we were aware as a committee that if our inquiry had been into science or maths education we would have been presented with submissions making similar claims for these disciplines. We have therefore avoided making recommendations which may have been modified had we had the benefit of evidence from these other sources. We felt we would be unjustified in drawing rigid comparisons between the support for arts education and these other disciplines, without taking evidence in these other areas.

Secondly, when the submissions were divided between different art forms, the number in each did not provide the committee with enough material to go into detail about each one. We have therefore not sought to make recommendations which relate to the relative merits of music and dance or drama. Furthermore, most of the submissions are dealing with the art and not nearly as many gave contributions towards the educational aspects. The committee's secretariat was required therefore to augment the evidence presented by witnesses in the area of education.

Furthermore, much of the funding and administration of education comes under the jurisdiction of the states. As a Senate committee, we were aware that we had even less force of persuasion with the states than we do have with the Commonwealth. Having said that, the Commonwealth has had a major part in the development of the national curriculum, the introduction of the key competencies and university reform following the introduction of a unified national system of universities in 1988. The committee believes the Commonwealth should play a major role in further improving the quality and direction of education, including arts education, in Australia.

Finally, many of the detrimental features of arts funding and priority infected other areas of education. In my view—I am expressing a personal view—a solution to this deeper issue is fundamental to a solution to the problems facing the arts. Hence, most of what I felt about this was relevant to education in the more general sense, not just to arts education.

Artistic expression is to be found throughout human history and in all people. As a former research scientist with a strong background in the biological sciences, this causes me to believe that artistic expression must have had considerable survival value. The earliest records of human civilisation show highly developed art forms. All extant indigenous people spend a great deal of time and effort in expressing and celebrating cultural identity through art.

Without speculating on what that survival value may be, in attempting the even more difficult and speculative task of relating it to survival in the modern industrial world, I believe that six million years of human evolution would have built the need for and the satisfaction to be derived from artistic expression into our genes. It is against this philosophical background that I view with alarm the growing dominance of what has come to be called economic rationalism.

Arts expression and arts education, like almost every other element of our lives, has become subservient to some degree to this paradigm. Art has become a market commodity; arts education is valued as a training for employment. Art, like science, has been corrupted to serve the needs of the industrial system.

Some of the submissions raised, as a positive, the value of the arts in dollar terms. This may have been because these witnesses felt obliged to use the language of economic rationalism. This saddened me because in many cases one felt that this was not the way the witnesses would prefer to argue their case. Perhaps it is more because giving into this view of the world and using its language serves to reinforce its hegemony.

It should also be noted that the statistics on the economic value of the arts are quite rubbery. The fact that the ABS does not keep better statistics is itself a reflection of the value which economists place on artistic endeavour. For example, $13 billion was mentioned by several witnesses as the ABS value of the `cultural industries'. Yet when this figure is analysed further it is seen that this represents about 1.9 per cent of GDP and that, within this figure, about one-third is media advertising, publishing, architectural services and radio and television services—they made up the bulk. Most of the submissions in our inquiry indicated that only about $1 billion relates to the arts as visual arts. Dollar values are a totally inadequate surrogate for aesthetic value as broadly defined. The rejection of the application of the economic rationalist paradigm to the artistic aspect of our individual and social lives is a message which I hope will come out strongly—and I believe has come out strongly—in our report.

The arts are about the fulfilment of some of our deepest and most atavistic needs. The attempt to reduce artistic endeavour to dollars and cents diminishes the very thing that is being measured. Thus, I believe that we need to reassert the value of a broad liberal education most strongly. We must reject the pressure to redefine education as vocational training lest, as a society, we become merely a human ant colony, each with specified and prearranged tasks.

Humans are more than the flesh and blood cogs of an industrial machine and education is more than the process that takes the raw human material and fashions these flesh and blood cogs. This is not to deny that there is an economic and industrial component to artistic activity, but it is to say that these elements should arise as secondary to the creative and re-creative purpose. I do not draw a distinction between creativity and science and the arts, for the former is also suffering under the assault of economic rationalism.
In The New Industrial State in 1967 Galbraith saw very clearly where we were headed—I have used this quotation in connection with the Hilmer report—when he wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: If we continue to believe that the goals of the industrial system—the expansion of output, the companion increase in consumption, technological advance, the public images that sustain it—are co-ordinate with life, then all our lives will be in the service of these goals. What is consistent with these ends we shall have, or be allowed, all else will be off limits.

The point that I wish to stress out of this report is that we need from this the evidence that was collected and from our analysis of that evidence to take a broader review in relation to education generally, of which arts education just happens to be a part. We came up with a number of quite specific recommendations. I will not deal with those here.

PARA.TAB: I simply conclude by saying that the national curriculum needs to be reviewed in the light of a different role for education. It must clearly state that the role of education is not the vehicle by which human raw material is fashioned to the needs of industry. This must be seen as a secondary and relatively minor object of education. The achievement of a broad, general and liberal education must not become marginalised. Commonwealth special purpose funding should be conditional on this. The education minister should initiate a project of comparable status to the key competencies to clarify the broad purposes of school education and reassert their primary importance alongside employment related purposes.

The application of the key competencies, as currently listed, seems to have damaged the arts relative to other disciplines. It may be that a competency relating to aesthetic awareness needs to be added to the list. However, it may be that the very idea of measured competence in aesthetic awareness does irreparable damage to the very concept of aesthetic awareness. I think I will leave it there and leave it to other members of the committee to make their comments.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts References Committee, the process of writing this report has allowed me to see many things, which I hope members of the public will now be able to see. It brings out a number of aspects of the nation's artistic life, which I think are important and which should be seen to be important.

PARA.TAB: It is very easily dismissed that a child's first creative expression comes when they go to a pre-school and they are asked to paint something—for example, do some finger painting—or make something. That is one of their earliest forms of personal expression. They are the very first things they do to define themselves. Yet too often that form of expression is dismissed and people see it as a time-wasting or childminding exercise. These are the sorts of things that this report goes to. For the first time on the public record it brings them to the wider society's attention.

Also I think that the report quite rightly propounds the need for everyone to see that they have a right to express themselves and, indeed, an ability to express themselves artistically, even though they may not themselves feel that they are gifted or, in the general run of society, they may be seen as people who are artistically gifted. One of the aspects of this report which come out very strongly is that everyone has that right and everyone should be encouraged.

You could go further and say that if we want a society which is intelligent, can cope with change and can be at the forefront of an economic world, we need a society which is flexible and able to take on new ideas and think in new ways. That is very much the essence of an artistic education. That is the sort of thing that this report identifies and, hopefully, will flow through to government decisions and attitudes about educators.

The report also accepts that there are some in society who are genuinely artistically gifted. These people have a particular facility, be it in the visual arts or the performing arts. The report identifies the need for those people to have rigorous training of the very highest standard. That has not been lost in the balance between the right of everyone to express themselves and the ability of the few.

This report also identifies and continues the idea first put in Creative Nation, the government's report on the arts, which is that new technology needs to be harnessed by artists. It has to be the case that people in the artistic community are not left behind with the march of technology and the introduction of new media but are able to harness it themselves, make it their own and go into further areas of creative production.

I do not want to speak for too long tonight because I am conscious of the time pressures on the Senate. I would like to say something particularly about the role of the chairman in this report. It seems incredible that this report has come out after the very early days we spent in a dingy room in state Parliament House in Adelaide on a very cold and wintry day, where we started with the first draft. It is a credit to everyone who had an input into the report that it is now a very different document from the document which appeared in that first draft. Nevertheless, the main ideas that were there are still in the report.

At one point, I have to be honest with the Senate and say that Senator Carr and I thought we may have to bring out a minority report because the differences between us and other members of the committee were so great. But it is a tribute to the chairman's patience and his willingness to see the other side that that eventually was not the case and we were not required to do that. Our ideas were able to be incorporated within the body of the report and yet not threaten the intellectual rigour and structure of the report.

It is a tribute to the chairman that, when it came down to writing the chairman's report, he asked us whether we wanted to submit some ideas to him. The committee members were unanimous in saying that we were more than happy for him to go away and write his own report as he saw it. We felt that he had earned that right, given the work he had put into the committee. I seek leave to continue my remarks later because I am conscious of the time pressures on the Senate.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to this report. This report clearly demonstrates the sort of contribution that Senator John Coulter has made to this chamber. I regret that it will be the last report in which he will be involved in presenting to this chamber in view of his decision, on health grounds, to retire very shortly.

PARA.TAB: Senator Coulter can look back on this report with pride as he leaves the Senate. It very much represents the sort of man he is: a gentle man with a concern for the human condition. The report certainly has his stamp on it, and not only in the chairman's introduction. As Senator Wheelwright said, we were of the unanimous view that there should be a chairman's forward to encapsulate the spirit of this report.

I have particularly enjoyed my association with Senator Coulter in this report. Next to him, I attended the most meetings at which witnesses came before the committee. I suppose that, next to him, I was the senator most involved with this report. I am very pleased with the nature of the report. Obviously, everything is not exactly put as I would say it. Nonetheless, the general thrust of it is outstanding.

The report deals with many difficult problems in arts education that I hope will be taken up in the arts community and will be dealt with by the government. They are far more difficult problems than many people have been prepared to recognise. However, the very large volume of submissions to the committee indicates that there is a level of concern in society about this matter. I also mention that many of these submissions appeared to be in total conflict with each other, which did not help us very much in establishing what would be a reasonable conclusion.

Senator John Coulter's chairmanship of this committee brought with it many problems. The composition of the committee changed overwhelmingly during the time he was trying to steer a rational, coherent course in this inquiry. To that extent, I welcome the fact that there is no minority report. There is an agreed report, even though there were some very strong differences of view, particularly between two late coming members of the committee. They did not have the benefit—if it was a benefit—of listening to so much evidence. Nonetheless, they agreed that there was a reasonable position that they could accept with a few amendments. However, none of those amendments have detracted in any way from the general thrust of what Senator Coulter was about, and I commend him for that.

I would like to make a couple of points about matters that really concern me and which must be resolved. The question of devolution in education where local people are becoming more and more empowered, if you like, to establish what should happen in their schools within the state systems brings with it a huge risk. That huge risk, which is particularly evident in the area of the arts, is that local people may well—and they may well not—take a very materialist view, in that they want to see their school providing what they see as essential training in order for the pupils of those schools to get a job. In other words, the recession and economic hard times invariably put pressure on the school system to prepare people for a tough economic environment rather than to prepare people to be rounded and be able to cope with a total society, a society which is based not simply on materialism but on much more important things. The human condition depends immensely on its fulfilment of its artistic ambitions.

Within everyone, as is pointed out in this report, there is a desire to express oneself, to develop skills and to have an appreciation of the arts—regardless of whether you are going to be a great performer, a potential audience or involved just at a humble level. The point is made in the report that there is even an artistic element involved in making your garden attractive. I would simply hope that devolution of power in terms of what can be done and what will be done at local school levels does not lead to a view that the arts are unnecessary, that the arts are peripheral and that the arts are not something that is central to the education system.

To that extent, I have a conflict of principle. I oppose authoritarian centralism dictating to people what they should do. On the other hand, I do not want devolved arrangements leading to a diminution in arts education. This is a conflict which has to be resolved. I hope this report will bring some sensible discussion of the problem.

I am concerned about what happened under the Dawkins' education arrangements where there have been some enforced linkings of bodies: for example, the Conservatorium of Music in Sydney and the University of Sydney, where there appear to be levels of incompatibility at this stage which have caused problems. I know that in many areas of Australia there are very happy unions between specifically arts oriented bodies—I mean art skills in that practical sense—and the academic approach of universities. The Elder Conservatorium in Adelaide is linked with the University of Adelaide, which is an academic institution. The Melbourne Conservatorium has always been linked with Melbourne University.

There is this serious problem that the one-on-one or the one-on-two educational systems involved in a skill training—for example, in music—are not amenable to the normal academic pursuit where you might have 100 students in one class. When I was at Sydney University there were a couple of hundred people in an English class. When you are fighting for funds within an academic atmosphere, it is very difficult for a skill oriented operation like teaching someone the flute to be seen as a reasonable use of resources, when it is a one-on-one or a one-on-two arrangement as it is, when, for example, you have one teacher to a couple of hundred students.

There have been disputes and difficulties in terms of allocation of resources in this situation. One of the recommendations is that the basis on which funds are allocated within the academic arrangements should be seriously looked at to avoid these conflicts which we hope can be resolved. That is the issue. That is the message in this report. Any conflicts that emerge and that tend to diminish the merit and significance of arts education should be resolved and there should be serious attempts by government to assist in the resolution of those problems.

I commend Senator John Coulter for this report. I commend his enthusiasm in pursuing the subject. I hope I will get another opportunity to wish him well in his retirement. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
Debate resumed from 17 October, on motion by Senator Teague:
That the Senate endorse the finding at paragraph 2.17 of the 57th report of the Committee of Privileges.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Tuesday, as chairman of the Senate Committee of Privileges, I tabled the 57th report of the committee, concerning possible penalty or injury imposed on witnesses before the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation. I outlined the nature of that report, its conclusions and its finding. I then moved that the finding be endorsed by the Senate. I urge that, after senators have spoken on the matter, the motion be put so that it can be determined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very grateful to the Privileges Committee for this report. I know it is a report that members of the committee have agonised over for a long time because they have taken so long to come to a conclusion.

PARA.TAB: Some years ago some of the issues that are still the subject of debate in this report were raised with me by members of the credit union, Mr Lindeberg and Mr O'Neill. I am very sad to see the actions of certain members of this credit union. My support in this place for credit unions has been demonstrated and can be evidenced from Hansard.

I support the whole credit union movement. I support it because of its mutuality principle which, to me, is a very important principle. I opposed the move to treat credit unions harshly, at least from my point of view, in terms of the tax treatment of them by the government a couple of years ago. In the superannuation committee, I supported very strongly the move to have credit unions supply superannuation savings accounts as part of the various products which might be offered.

So it is distressing for me to read in this report of the Privileges Committee the activities of one credit union, the Queensland Professional Credit Union. Although the Standing Committee of Privileges did not determine to make a finding of contempt against the credit union, the committee was certainly critical of some of its activities.

I would like to underline a couple of the things the committee said. In talking about the claim by Mr Kevin Childs of the credit union that a motion concerning the withdrawal of Mr and Mrs Lindeberg's membership and the refusal of Mr O'Neill's membership could not be discussed at a particular meeting, the committee said that it did not know how Mr Childs could have come to this view:

SPEECH.PARA: This, in the Committee's view, was either a misunderstanding or a misuse of a principle which may have application in other circumstances. Although the Committee had advised all persons involved in the matter that submissions made to the Committee were not to be released without the Committee's permission, this in no way precluded the subject-matter being canvassed in another forum.

The only conclusion I can draw is that the administration of the credit union went out of its way to prevent issues being raised which were of significant importance to members of that credit union and used all kinds of disingenuous argument to prevent those matters being raised. I note further that the committee said:

The Committee does not accept the reasons put forward by Mr Lee as Chairman of the QPCU for the withdrawal of Mr Lindeberg's membership. It considers the explanation provided by the QPCU disingenuous and draws attention to the comments made in Mr Lindeberg's submissions to this Committee in respect of them. The Committee has little doubt that such a withdrawal was, as Mr Lindeberg asserts, a reprisal for Mr Lindeberg's attempts to have matters of concern to him aired, notably at the annual general meeting of the QPCU on 28 October 1993. The QPCU's refusal of membership to Mr O'Neill was, in the Committee's view, to ensure that another person with detailed knowledge of the Queensland Professional Officers' Association Superannuation Fund and a supporter of Mr Lindeberg's efforts to call the credit union directors and management to account at that meeting would be prevented from attending and participating in the annual general meeting.

This is a serious matter. I believe that the Privileges Committee has done a service, albeit a very painful one, in drawing to the attention of the Senate and the Australian public at large the need for people who are the holders of office of public institutions, such as credit unions, to act ethically and morally and to be above any suggestion that they have acted in a way detrimental to the members.

PARA.TAB: I thank the committee for its work. I hope that this report will be widely read and become, in a sense, a warning to other people to act with probity and ethically in all matters such as this.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 28 September, on motion by Senator Brownhill:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to this report. I would like to begin by saying that, in my dissenting report, the Australian Democrats would draw attention to the fact that we support the vast majority of the very important recommendations that the committee made in this report. I would like to underline that.

PARA.TAB: There were a couple of areas, however, that I was concerned about, and I would like to concentrate my remarks on those matters today. The most serious of these is the whole area of the age pension because, from the more than 250 submissions received by the inquiry, it was obvious that the areas of greatest concern to farming families were the assets test on Austudy, which was dealt with in the committee's report earlier this year, and the assets test effects on the pension.

The Democrats believe that the inequity the committee found in the Austudy assets test also exists in the assets test that applies to farmers wishing to retire on their farms or to hand on their farms to the next generation. To get the full age pension, a single person can have assets up to $118,000, while a couple can have assets up to $167,500. The pension phases out for asset levels above these thresholds until it cuts out completely when the asset level reaches $225,000 for singles and $347,000 for couples.

To put this in perspective for farming families, we need to realise that figures from the farm surveys report 1995 showed the average value of various types of farms in 1993-94 ranged between $900,000 and $1 million. Quite clearly the owner of the average Australian farm is completely excluded from social security payments by the assets test. People might say that anyone with asset levels that high should not expect to receive any social security payments.

To say this, however, would be to overlook the realities of farming: that is, that farming these days is a very capital intensive business and, further, that in Australia there is a great tradition of family farming whereby the monetary value of the farm is irrelevant because it is only a tool that is destined to be handed down from generation to generation.

The fact that the pension assets test impacts far harder on farmers was clearly shown by the figures that the department presented to the committee. Those figures showed that, whilst only 2.5 per cent of non-farm owning pensioners had their rate of pension determined by the assets test, the pension of 23.75 per cent of farm owning pensioners is decided by the assets test.

Further, while farm owners comprise just 0.65 per cent of those pensioners whose rate of pension is determined by the income test, they constitute around 7.5 per cent of those pensioners whose rate of payment is determined by the assets test. The other way in which pension rates affect farmers is through the operation of what are known as the gifting provisions. Without going into great detail on this, the practical effect of those provisions is that a farmer who retires and passes ownership of a farm on to a son or daughter is precluded from the age pension for five years, regardless of any subsequent lack of income.

The department's view, which was expressed a number of times at the inquiry, is that people should be required to sell assets before public support is provided. A number of submissions to the inquiry spoke of this view and of the way the pension rules have affected farmers. For example, a farmer from Western Australia wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: I own a 193 acre property which has been operated by the same family since 1897. Social Security suggested I should sell off the farm for income. This was out of the question—being my only asset, and my home since 1950.
The Victorian Farmers Federation submitted:

Farm business assets are not readily realisable. Even if it is possible to find a buyer with depressed farm product prices (and with drought in some areas), it is impractical and self-defeating for a farmer to sell off a portion of his land in order to provide income support. Reducing the size of the operational unit reduces the farm's productivity and profitability.

Many submissions talked of families living in hardship or poverty as a result of two or three generations of that family living on the farm, the income from which is simply not sufficient to support the entire family. The Anglican Parish of Junee talked of cases from around their diocese where the social security rules were causing considerable stress and other health related problems, not just for those wanting to retire but for those wanting to take over the full running of the family farm—that is, the next generation. The Churches of Christ in South Australia said:

The tying of age pension to the assets test causes unnecessary hardship, particularly on younger couples as parents do not have the income to survive off the farm. Often the spouse of the younger family has to find work away from the farm to support her/his family as whatever income the farm gains can only maintain the parents. This situation is not just, and also impacts on family situations in other ways. It can be resolved by change of the five year waiting time before pension is available after disposing of assets.
The Rural Counsellors of South Australia said:

In the current circumstances so many farmers are living off their assets while two generations live on the farm in poverty. The older generation not able to retire because they have no income, and the younger generation knowing that the only way the farm can be theirs one day is for them to stay and work on it. Meanwhile the productivity of the farm is going backwards in so many cases, as there is insufficient income to make improvements or even maintain the assets.

And so we could go on. I could quote the recommendation of the Catholic Social Justice Commission, and what the Rural Counsellors of South Australia said. They all had the same story to tell. The Rural Counsellors quoted the words of the AAT in the case of Davey and Secretary to the Department of Social Security. Talking about the intergenerational transfer of farms the AAT said:

We think that these means of passing on farm properties from one generation to another should not be discouraged. We would regard it generally as unreasonable that viable farm properties that are required for the support of one generation should be broken up by sale simply because of the older generation's need for support. It is of no overall benefit to Australia to discourage the concern which families have in maintaining and working farm properties and in passing those properties from generation to generation.

And so on and so on. In order to try to break the nexus which we have been faced with, I have proposed a private senator's bill which builds on many of the recommendations of those who submitted to this inquiry and who are included in the report.

PARA.TAB: The aim of my bill is twofold. Firstly, the bill will exempt the value of the family farm assets, including farm land, plant, articles and livestock, from the age pension assets test. This simply recognises that the inequity faced by students from farming families under the Austudy assets test is felt equally by those farmers wishing to retire from farming but remaining on their properties. In relation to this proposal, the Democrats note the evidence provided by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy in which it is estimated that, if farm assets were exempted from the age pension assets test, at most 577 single broadacre farmers and 4,146 couples may become eligible for the age pension.

Secondly, the bill would allow intergenerational transfer of farms to take place without incurring a social security penalty. I urge anyone interested in this issue to study the document. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.
