PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this evening's adjournment debate I wish to make some statements in relation to comments made last evening by Senator Michael Baume. Senator Baume made a range of wild comments in the Senate last night regarding the Australian Workers Union and, more specifically, its Victorian branch. Regrettably, some of his claims appear to be factual, but many of them create a misleading impression about the current administration of the AWU's Victorian branch.

PARA.TAB: From mid-1989 to early 1992 the secretary of the AWU's Victorian branch was a Mr Bob Smith. This person no longer has any connection with the union, and he has not since 1992. His successor, Victorian secretary Mr Bruce Wilson, similarly ceased to be connected with the union in about August this year.

Some aspects of Mr Smith's and Mr Wilson's administration of their AWU responsibilities appear to have been, at the very least, questionable. The receipt of moneys from some companies and the use to which those moneys may have been put certainly have a cloud hanging over them. However, it must be emphasised that the administration of the Victorian branch of the Australian Workers Union today is entirely different from that which ruled from 1989 until February this year.

Unfortunately, the current secretary of the Victorian branch is also named Bob Smith—Robert Frederick Smith. He is a different person from the former AWU secretary, also named Bob Smith. The current Bob Smith was elected as Victorian secretary of the former Federated Ironworkers Association in 1990. Through the amalgamation of various unions which took place in 1991, 1992 and 1993 and subsequent internal restructuring, the Victorian branch of the Federated Ironworkers Association has since February this year been the core of what now constitutes the Victorian branch of the AWU.

The current Mr Smith and his team of officials, drawn from the old Federated Ironworkers Association, the old Australasian Society of Engineers, and responsible members of the old AWU are in fact the officials who first discovered and then drew attention to the apparent financial maladministration of their predecessors.

It is unfair in the extreme that the current Victorian branch of the AWU and its office-bearers should be associated in any way with the apparent maladministration of people who no longer have any connection whatsoever with the union. I am advised that the current Victorian branch is more than happy to assist any government authorities in seeking that justice be done and that the current interests of AWU members are well and truly safeguarded.

The Federated Ironworkers Association and the other unions which today constitute the AWU all have their own honourable traditions dating back to the past century. I have no doubt that those traditions will successfully assert themselves within the new amalgamated organisation. In the meantime, members of the Senate should be assured that the sources of apparent wrongdoing within the Victorian branch of the AWU have been eradicated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take only a few moments of the Senate's time. I thank the Senate for this opportunity to set down what my intention is for the next few weeks. Some senators may recall that last year I was unable to fulfil my duties for the last few weeks of the year because I was ill and required surgery in hospital. I find I now require further surgery. Consequently, I shall not be in the chamber next week, and I will be formally resigning from the Senate on the first day of the next sitting fortnight—that is, on 13 November.

PARA.TAB: I just want to put on the record that that is what I will be doing. So I will be seeing you all again for a brief time. I feel very sad about having to do this but I think that, in the interests of the people of South Australia who elected me and of the party, that is the best thing to do, and I will make a more adequate response to the Senate at that time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I commence my remarks I simply indicate that I and, I am sure, all of my colleagues wish Senator Coulter well in the weeks and indeed years ahead. We will undoubtedly miss him. There will be, as I understand it, another occasion to develop these remarks.

PARA.TAB: The plight of the families involved with the timber industry in Tasmania is the matter that I wish to address tonight. I indicate as an aside that as I was preparing this speech I noted that `Australian News' was carrying a story which read in part as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Leaders of New South Wales communities reliant on the timber industry fear job losses, major social and economic dislocation, and even the death of their towns will flow from the federal government's forest protection and industry strategy policy.

The sad consequences of the federal government's policy vacuum in this area are reflected in the plea by these leaders of regional New South Wales. My home state of Tasmania has similar fears. If I can quickly recount history, Mr President, you will recall that earlier this year the federal government was in a great state of turmoil in trying to determine what its forest policy ought be. After disaster after disaster, those involved in the industry engaged in a blockade around this Parliament House. During that period, on 27 January this year, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) promised assistance to those businesses disadvantaged by the government's on again, off again forest policy. Major losses were suffered needlessly because of the government's reliance on shonky Green studies which declared replanted airfields of some 20 years as old growth forests. Labor has a lot to answer for.

PARA.TAB: Labor promised through its Prime Minister to compensate those businesses which suffered because of their harebrained approach to forestry. Australians ought be very angry that this policy debacle is yet another impost on Australia's ever growing debt. Those involved in the industry ought be, and are, angrier. Given the promise of compensation, requests were made ever since January 1995 on numerous occasions to Prime Minister and Cabinet and to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy as to what guidelines ought be used or were in place under which compensation could be sought. These family businesses were told to start preparing their submissions, accountants were engaged and verification undertaken.

Finally, without any guidelines, those claims were submitted in July of this year. Seventeen days ago, on 2 October, the Labor member for Franklin (Mr Quick) released the federal government's Interim Hardship Business Eligibility Criteria Guidelines—just the name puts you off—with a great fanfare under the heading `Fair go for forest operators'. Nevertheless, despite all the jargon, the claimants persisted. They were required to resubmit their claims, and they did so with great haste because they were still waiting for compensation for money losses incurred earlier this year. But on the very next day the assistant secretary of the forest branch of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy put out an amended Interim Hardship Business Eligibility Criteria and Guidelines. Within a day the government was already changing its position.

There seems to be no end to this government's indecision and incompetence in this area of forestry, which is so vitally important to my home state and to so many regional areas of Australia. One of the important changes made was to limit the claims to a maximum of $30,000. In my home state of Tasmania a total of claims has been made for $542,000. Out of the nine claims that have been lodged, only three fall under the $30,000 threshold. One is in excess of $188,000. Allow me to read from the letter that I was sent by these contractors, a family business. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: We need the compensation for the following reasons. We lost income, yet we still kept our workmen on and paid them full wages during the period of the shutdown.
I would have thought that sort of a policy of industrial relations ought be supported by this government. The letter goes on:

This depleted our cash reserves. As a result, we were unable to meet our debts as they fell due and consequently we are paying higher bank interest than we would be if we had not been shut down. In the near future we will have to find our workers holiday pay and our own taxation payments, which will further worsen our debt position due to our cash flow problems. Our financial situation will not return to our pre-moratorium position unless we receive full compensation for the loss we suffered. Our claim amounts to $188,288. Limiting a claim to $30,000 will enable the smaller claims to be paid in full, but will leave those who have suffered the most with the hardship that continues to grow.
The Prime Minister stated that full compensation would be made available to those affected by the moratorium.

Undoubtedly, much to the embarrassment of the member for Franklin, this letter is from a contractor who lives and operates his business and employs people in the electorate of Franklin, in my home state of Tasmania. It was the federal member for Franklin who announced with all the fanfare that compensation would be paid and set out the guidelines. The fanfare was: fair go for forest operators.

PARA.TAB: Mr Quick was undoubtedly of the view, `You beauty! I've been able to make representations and be successful for these forest workers and their families'—only to find that the very next day he was overridden in a completely roughshod manner by the assistant secretary for forests in the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. Undoubtedly it indicates the esteem in which the Labor government holds the federal member for Franklin.

It also indicates how out of touch the federal government is with the plight of this industry. Indeed, in my home state of Tasmania, out of the nine claims there is one for $3,000, which will be fully paid—as will the $6,000 claim, the $15,000 claim and the $1,400 claim. But there is a claim for $188,000, two for $90,000, one for $94,000 and one for $55,000. Some of these people drew on their overdraft facilities to keep families and breadwinners in money on the promise that the federal government would compensate them.

On 27 January the Prime Minister made that promise when he was getting into deeper and deeper trouble with the forest strategy. I say as an aside that the Prime Minister will need more than Dr Don Russell to try to fix some of these problems. Indeed, it is an absolute disgrace that the Prime Minister, after having made such disastrous policy decisions in relation to the forest industry, promises compensation and then reneges on those promises.

People have acted in good faith, kept employees on and kept families from incurring hardship. In fact, they have saved the Commonwealth the payment of unemployment benefits for these people. Then what do we have? The government overriding the guidelines that were set out and then putting a ceiling of $30,000. It is indicative of a tired government that has lost direction. I can assure the forest workers of this country, especially of my home state of Tasmania and the electors of Franklin, that under a Liberal government they would get a much better deal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak in the adjournment debate on an issue that I have raised on a number of occasions, and that is the problem that we often encounter over conflict between various land uses. In this case it is a conflict illustrated by a number of releases and articles in the media. The conflict is about a new mine which is proposed for north-west Queensland, an area which I lived and worked in for some years and which I still visit fairly frequently because it has a history and a place in my heart. This mine is the Ernest Henry mine, which is going to be a very huge mine near Cloncurry. It will eventually mine minerals by the open-cut method which, after the mine is completed, will leave a hole in the ground 570 metres deep with a circumference of five kilometres.

PARA.TAB: There has been a lot of conflict over the mine between conservationists, miners and other land-holders. In reading the various press releases and articles, not a lot of light is shed either on the claims and counterclaims or on what the actual facts of the issue are. For instance, this particular press release from `Australian News' states:

SPEECH.PARA: Queensland Conservation Council spokesman Scott Johnston said basic environmental assessment, social studies and planning had not been undertaken, but Minerals and Energy Minister Tony McGrady was due this week to announce whether the Ernest Henry project, 35km north-east of Cloncurry, would go ahead.

PARA.TAB: He called on Mr McGrady to delay approval of the project, owned by mining giant MIM Holdings Ltd, until "reasonable studies" had been done to consider the environmental risks and social impacts of the development.

SPEECH.PARA: The environmental risks are considerable, but it is very hard to get accurate information about just what the state of play is. The article continues:

PARA.TAB: The Office of the Coordinator General had approved the final impact assessment study on virtually the same day as the study was released to referral agencies for comment, Mr Johnston said.

SPEECH.PARA: He goes on:

PARA.TAB: People . . . haven't had a chance to address the potential major environmental impact.

SPEECH.PARA: On the other side of the argument, the mines and energy minister says:
. . . the facts are that a mining lease application requires a lot of due process.
The article goes on:

PARA.TAB: The due process had been followed "without compromise" after an Impact Assessment Study was called for in 1993 and a number of submissions were received from the public.

A spokesman for the minister said although the Mining Warden's office had recommended the project go ahead, the timing of the announcement on Ernest Henry depended on advice from the Department of Primary Industries, after its own assessments were complete.

SPEECH.PARA: So, again, we have these conflicting statements. On the one hand the Minister for Mines and Energy is saying everything is lovely and there are no problems, and on the other hand the Queensland Conservation Council is saying that the studies have not been completed, there are questions to be answered and the project should be delayed.

PARA.TAB: I have been in contact with people in the area for some weeks and visited the area just a couple of weeks ago. In fact, I spent six days in the Cloncurry, Mount Isa, Julia Creek area. I spoke to a lot of pastoral people, miners and conservationists. I visited Fort Constantine and Belinda Downs, which are two of the properties in that area. In fact, I believe the mine will be on the Fort Constantine station. There is a lot of local concern. In fact the community is quite divided. Some see that the project will bring jobs and economic prosperity to the area and others say, `We need a lot of answers yet.'

One of the issues that I think the Senate and Australians ought to be concerned about, and to which I do not believe adequate answers have been given, is that the hole which is to be dug—and remember I said that eventually it would be 570 metres deep, you can imagine just how big a hole that is—will in fact go straight down into the Great Artesian Basin. That ought to be a concern to members of this Senate. It is a concern to the water resources department in Queensland. I think they would say that not all the questions they have asked have been answered.

I understand that eventually the profit from the mine could be in the region of $6.4 billion. An estimate for sealing the aquifer so that the Great Artesian Basin would not be affected is in the vicinity possibly of $20 million—which is a lot of money but, in comparison to the estimated profit, is only a very small percentage.

The people in the area, particularly those like Bood Hickson, whose family own the Melinda Downs property and who is a conservationist and a member of the Cloncurry Landcare committee, say that `if we could simply have the aquifers sealed and have some guarantee of that, then we believe we could support the development'. But he would say that the mining leases should not be signed in a hurry, that the minerals are not going to go away and that they are going to be there for a long time. So it is worth taking time to make sure that all the questions are answered. The project should not be fast tracked, he would say. He would claim that consultation has taken place but it has certainly not been adequate. The local community is divided. But all of those in the local community, I believe, would certainly want to see questions answered.I spoke to people on what is called the `downs area' around Julia Creek. Most of them depend on bores from the Great Artesian Basin. They certainly want a guarantee of their water supply because they absolutely depend upon it.

Again in this place we are faced with these debates about land use, and I do not believe they ought to be the kind of acrimonious debates which they so often are. When I was in the area I visited another mine which is much further along the track: the Century Mine. That mine is up in the area between Mount Isa and Burketown, and there are conflicts over that mine. I understand that questions raised by Aboriginal people still need to be answered, the Burketown Shire has questions, and graziers are concerned about tenure over the pipeline easement that will go through their properties.
So these questions confront us. Surely in Australia we can find better ways to have development but also protect and preserve the environment without which all of us cannot survive on this planet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, as I have mentioned to you, I want to make some comments about the answer which you and the Speaker have given to a question on notice by Senator Margetts—question No. 2392, relating to the Parliamentary Library. There were, I think, eight parts to the question, which arose from the time of the resignation of the previous Parliamentary Librarian, Mr Hillas MacLean in 1991. Part (6) of the question of Senator Margetts was:

PARA.TAB: Do the present Presiding Officers agree that 3 years uncertainty as to their departments' futures is an unwelcome and unnecessary distraction to the corporate focus of officers in both departments; if not, why not.

SPEECH.PARA: The answer which the Presiding Officers have given to the question is no. That, of course, is their opinion, and they are entitled to it.

PARA.TAB: I would say that the answer should be yes, that three years uncertainty as to their departments' futures is an unwelcome and unnecessary distraction to the corporate focus of officers. I feel very much for the people who work in the library who have been left in this situation for four years. The answer, though the `no' is definite, is qualified in the next sentence, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: The delay is regrettable—
I think it most certainly is regrettable but need not have occurred. The answer then goes on to say:
but has been occasioned by the stated intention of the Opposition in the Senate to oppose the Bill . . .

We have before the Senate the Public Service (Parliamentary Departments) Amendment 1993, which was brought in in November 1993. To avoid delay, you would have thought that you would bring a bill on, deal with it, dispose of it and then act in accordance with the decision of the parliament in relation to it. Allowing this to drag on so long exacerbates the uncertainty that the staff of the library have suffered.

PARA.TAB: The answer goes on in relation to the opposition's stated intention to oppose the bill in the Senate to state:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . notwithstanding the endorsement in March 1993 of the proposed single department by the Advisory Committee to the Presiding Officers chaired by Mr Peter Nugent MP, which considered the issue.

The advisory committee was very strange. It was not a parliamentary committee. It was set up by the then Presiding Officers to advise on a particular proposal relating to the amalgamation which would change dramatically the status of the library.

PARA.TAB: I wish to refer to some issue concerning this committee without going into it in detail. It was not a parliamentary committee, so it did not have privilege and was not serviced by the usual secretariats that service committees in this parliament. It just was not conducted in the usual fashion. The chairman was not a government member, which I believe is usually the case with joint committees.

There was a dissenting report from Senator Teague, former Senator Sowada and me in which we gave six reasons for dissenting from that report. I will have a chance to deal with those reasons in more detail when the bill eventually comes before the parliament for resolution. The conduct of the inquiry was the sixth reason we gave for coming to a dissenting view. We annexed as part of our report one of the submissions—and they were not public submissions because of the nature of the inquiry—from the Department of the Senate.

The answer to Senator Margetts's question goes on to indicate that it is expected that the bill will come up this session for debate. If there was a serious endeavour to do something about the library, the bill would have been brought up sooner than this and the matter resolved. I think the answer could have noted that there was a dissenting report. That is not necessary, of course, but I think that fact needs to be placed on the record.

I feel very deeply for the staff of the library for what they have had to put up with in the last four years in the way of uncertainty. I welcome the bill coming before the Senate where it can be dealt with.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In question time on Thursday, 30 August this year I asked the Minister representing the Treasurer a question in relation to the Reserve Bank. I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Can the minister confirm that the Reserve Bank still has an unequivocal policy and resolve of acting as lender of last resort to all Australian trading and savings banks?

At about the time I asked the question there had been some problems with some credit unions, particularly in Japan. I am aware of quite a number of telephone conversations that have transpired between the Reserve Bank and Treasury officials since I asked that question.

PARA.TAB: I find it quite extraordinary that it has taken the government so long to confirm that the Reserve Bank is still the lender of last resort to trading and savings banks. The question really is: does the traditional role of the Reserve Bank—that is, the lender of last resort—still apply today as it applied in the past in such a way that deposit holders feel secure that their money in banks is underwritten by guarantees from the Reserve Bank? I think it is extraordinary that, despite all this flurry of activity, they have not been able to come back to this chamber and answer that question.

The other matter that I wish to raise tonight concerns compulsory member contributions. The government has announced the concept of having compulsory member contributions to superannuation funds. This is not going to be introduced without some difficulty. I flag, in advance, a number of issues I think should be addressed, because they need to be resolved.

In most cases, awards currently specify an amount which is less than the amount of the superannuation guarantee. As a result, in some cases employers have split the superannuation guarantee liability between two funds—the award three per cent is paid into the industry fund nominated, and the balance for superannuation guarantee purposes is paid to the employer's chosen fund.

The compulsory member contribution—and maybe the government's matching contribution announced by the government—requires that the government's matching contribution be paid to the fund receiving the superannuation guarantee contribution. Consequently, it is not clear which fund would receive these contributions in the above circumstances. I point out that there is a test case before the AIRC which may result in awards being amended to include the superannuation guarantee scale, so this would be a possible part resolution of the issue. Regardless of this, the matter needs to be resolved by the time the compulsory member contribution is introduced.

I also believe that the issue of the payment of the superannuation guarantee to more than one fund should be resolved at the time awards are amended—if they are going to be amended—and at the introduction of the compulsory member contribution, thus ensuring that employers cannot, for example, move moneys between a number of funds.

Another issue is the government's matching contribution. The compulsory member contribution has to be paid by the 28th day of the month following deduction from the employee's pay. It will be necessary for prompt arrears procedures to be set in place by trustees to collect overdue contributions. The whole superannuation guarantee system ideally may have to move to monthly payments. Certainly, that would facilitate the system and make the process for the trustees a lot less messy.

But Treasury has indicated in discussions that it will be next to impossible to move to monthly payments, because of the draconian nature of the superannuation guarantee legislation, and that employers will have plenty of opportunities to breach the superannuation guarantee requirements each year, instead of only one opportunity at present. I put to the Senate that both of Treasury's concerns need to be taken into account and a workable solution which accommodates them found.

The payment of the government's matching contribution will require evidence from employers, so here is another problem for the employers. That evidence would include the fund into which the superannuation guarantee and the member contribution is being paid and the amount of the employee contribution. Therefore, group certificates will need to incorporate these details, so the Taxation Office will also have to pick these up in its printing of group certificates. The other problem is that, as the government's matching contribution is paid in arrears, it is possible that some members will have left by the time it is paid. Funds are therefore potentially faced with making two benefit payments and suffering the associated cost burden.

What about the concept of the preservation of the government's matching charge and the compulsory member contribution? The compulsory member contribution for which a matching contribution is received must be preserved. This causes administrative difficulties, because the government's matching contribution is not received until the following year. So the ideal situation may be to simply preserve what is known as the compulsory member contribution. Indeed, it is reasonable that all contributions from the commencement of the compulsory member contribution and the government's matching contribution be preserved.

There is a further change to preservation on 1 July 1996. From that time generally only ongoing member undeducted contributions are not preserved. But with the advent of the compulsory member contribution and the government member contribution as well, the preservation regime will become unintelligible to the average person. Consequently, a case could well be made for full preservation from 1 July 1996, including the removal of the $500 threshold preservation. We understand that the preservation arrangements required from 1 July 1996 will be very costly for industry to implement and, as such, urgently need simplification.

I come to the question of multiple fund membership. It will be common for part-time and casual employees to have active membership in more than one fund. So it could be deemed desirable for a general award amendment, or an amendment preferably to the superannuation guarantee charge, because it would be far better if superannuation guarantee was taken out of the award system and placed entirely under the superannuation guarantee charge, which would certainly save a lot of the sorts of problems that I am raising tonight.

Apparently, it would be a lot simpler if there was a nominated single fund to receive all sorts of contributions, both the award contribution, if that is going to continue, as well as a pick-up from the superannuation guarantee charge. After all, we now have a transfer protocol, the idea of which is to assist in reducing the number of small account balances. But there is a potential, as a result of the issues that I have introduced tonight, of having multiple fund membership.

So I put those matters before the Senate for consideration by the government because they are matters that really must be taken into consideration well before commencement dates. I do this to try to ensure that the superannuation system in Australia works both efficiently and effectively and does not provide too many cost compliance problems either for the trustees or for the employers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today I tabled around 2,000 petitions which were passed on to me by the Women's Electoral Lobby. I want to acknowledge that the person who put these petitions together lives in Bunbury in Western Australia. She is a single parent with young children and no car. When she started taking out these petitions, she was told that people do not really care anyway and are too complacent to sign anything controversial. That got her dander up. So, armed with handmade posters, she approached local business people asking their permission to stick the signs up in their windows and put petition boards in their stores. The response was so wonderful she had to photocopy extra blank petitions.

PARA.TAB: People do care. I want to thank people like Kitt Pusey who take the time to care and make sure that the rest of the world knows that they care—and to pass that message on to the French government, that we in Australia do care about this issue enough to make this effort.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Lake Macquarie Employment Training Development Centre

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment Education and Training, upon notice, on 23 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the notice of termination of an agreement between the Commonwealth and the Lake Macquarie Employment Training Development Centre Incorporated, the sponsor group of the Charlestown and Windale SkillShare projects, dated 3 December 1993:
(1) Why was this agreement terminated.
(2) What wrong-doing, if any, was levelled against the employees of the Lake Macquarie Employment Training Development Centre other than the former director, Mr Wayne Condon.

(3) What negotiations and decision-making processes have been involved in the refusal by the department to accept any financial obligations for the termination payments to eleven employees of the sponsor body.
(4) What demands for unmet or unpaid entitlements and redundancy payments have been made to the department.
(5) What is the department's position on these fiduciary obligations so claimed by the former employees.
(6) How many of these experienced former trainers and staff have been redeployed in the SkillShare system.
(7) What hardships were created for these former employees consequent upon the termination in December 1993.

(8) What is the department's view on the opinion of the appointed liquidator, PC Hicks of Forsythe's Chartered Accountants, Newcastle who stated in a letter dated 16 March 1994 that, `a distinction can be drawn between insolvency administrations in general and this administration in that its existence was entirely dependant upon the continued funding by DEET. These arrangements as set out in the Memorandum of Agreement, in the opinion of the writer, give rise to a fiduciary obligation by DEET to the former employees. The sponsor was at all times obliged to act upon the instructions of DEET employees who, in fact became quasi-directors.'

(9) What matters have been raised in this matter by the Commonwealth and Defence Force Ombudsman with the department in respect of an inquiry by senior investigator, Gillian McDonald under reference number C/94/3459:GM.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Memorandum of Agreement between the Commonwealth and the Lake Macquarie Employment Training Development Centre Incorporated, the organisation that sponsored the Charlestown and Windale SkillShare projects, was terminated on 3 December 1993 under Clause 17.1(b) on the ground of serious misconduct by Lake Macquarie Employment Training Development Centre Incorporated.
(2) None.

(3) Advice from the Australian Government Solicitor to the Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET) on 2 December 1993 confirmed that under the conditions of the Memorandum of Agreement the Commonwealth had not guaranteed payments to staff and there was no employer/employee relationship. Therefore, there is no legal liability to former employees in respect of termination payments. The Department has taken its position in the light of this advice.
(4) Demands for unpaid "entitlements" made to DEET are as follows:
(i) a request from a member of the Sponsor committee at a meeting on 13 December 1993;

(ii) a request from Mr Colin Edwards (former employee) made in person on 11 January 1994 at the creditors meeting of Lake Macquarie Employment Training Development Centre Incorporated which was attended by a DEET representative;
(iii) a request from the Australian Services Union to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training on 28 February 1994; and
(iv) a request from Louise Metse (former employee) made to the Commonwealth and Defence Force Ombudsman.

(5) The 1993 SkillShare Memorandum of Agreement with both Charlestown and Windale SkillShare projects at clause 23.1 states "The Sponsor is an independent contractor and not an agent, partner or employee of the Commonwealth for any purpose whatsoever. The Sponsor acknowledges and agrees that neither itself nor any persons employed or engaged by it in the performance of the Agreement or otherwise shall be or deemed thereby to be an agent, partner or employee of the Commonwealth."
The Commonwealth does not accept it has any legal obligation, fiduciary or otherwise, in respect of the former employees of the Sponsor.

(6) My Department is not in receipt of any advice as to the number of former employees of Lake Macquarie Employment Training Development Centre Incorporated who may have been redeployed to other SkillShare Sponsor bodies.
(7) I refer the Senator to the answer given to question (4). My Department is not in receipt of any advice as to the circumstances of former employees after 3 December 1993.
(8) I refer the Senator to the answer given to question (5).

(9) On 20 December 1994, the Commonwealth and Defence Force Ombudsman advised the Secretary of DEET that there was no case to be made for a compensation payment by the Commonwealth to meet staff entitlements for which the Sponsor did not make adequate provision. The Ombudsman also advised that it may have been better for the Department to give some warning to the Sponsor that funding would be terminated if Mr Condon were to be convicted.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Environment: Crib Point Oil Terminal

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 4 September 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Crib Point oil terminal proposal:
(1) Is it a fact that the Environment Protection Agency's (EPA) comments on the draft Shell-Mobil Oil Spill plan were essentially ignored in the final plan.
(2) Was EPA given the chance to consult over later revisions of the final plan.
(3) Did the Australian Nature Conservation Agency have a second opportunity to comment.

(4) Given that consultation `to ensure suitable strategies to protect the important wetland values of Western Port Bay, taking account of the Ramsar values of Western Port Bay' was a condition of Foreign Investment Review Board approval, why were they not given that opportunity.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Environment Protection Agency's (EPA) comments on the draft Oil Spill Response Plan for the Crib Point proposal, incorporating comments from the Australian Nature Conservation Agency (ANCA), the Australian Heritage Commission, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, the Australian Maritime Safety Authority and an independent consultant, were passed to the proponent and the Port of Melbourne Authority on 6 April 1994. Revisions were made to the Plan in the light of these and other comments received.
(2) The EPA provided comments on a revised version of the Plan.

(3) ANCA provided initial comments to the EPA on the draft Oil Spill Prevention and Response Plan for the Crib Point Terminal on 5 November 1993 and on the Contingency Plan and Terminal Operations Manual on 27 January 1994. These comments were reflected in the EPA submission referred to in (1). ANCA's views on subsequent submissions were not sought.
(4) ANCA is satisfied that the Oil spill Prevention and Response Plan for the proposed Crib Point Terminal is comprehensive in the context of existing oil spill technologies.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Child Support Agency

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to certain actions of the Child Support Agency (CSA) in respect of a constituent, Mrs Glenys E Whipper:
(1) What is the sum of money the CSA contends that Mrs Whipper owes by way of a debt, consequent upon the change in her former husband's employment status in 1991.
(2) How did the CSA arrive at this figure of debt.
(3) Why did it take the CSA or other agencies some 3 years before action was taken to recover an alleged overpayment to Mrs Whipper.
(4) Why are current CSA payments now being withheld from the client since 3 July 1995 when the former husband resumed full-time work.

(5) How can this CSA system be said to be operating in the interests of children of a broken relationship when custodial parents like Mrs Whipper can be plunged into debt when her former husband loses his employment.
(6) When will the simple rule be applied that when a spouse is in work the custodial parent will be paid assessed maintenance and when the person is unemployed the monies will not have to be paid.
(7) Under what arrangements will Mrs Whipper continue to have to repay debt in any year that Mr Whipper's assessed income is less than his estimated income.
(8) Under what legislation, ordinances or regulations was Mrs Whipper's 1994-95 financial year tax refund cheque intercepted by the CSA.
(9)(a) Why was this decision on the tax cheque then reversed; and (b) under what authority was this action taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: Due to the secrecy provisions in the child support legislation, it is not possible to answer those questions presented by the honourable Senator which directly relate to an individual child support case. However, I can provide general responses to the honourable Senator's questions as follows:

(1) The amount of child support payable under an assessment is based on each parent's taxable income for the financial year two years prior to the current child support year. This amount is indexed to take account of changes in income over this period. If either parent's current income is at least 15% less than prior year taxable income, he or she can lodge an estimate of his or her current income and the CSA will issue a revised assessment. This revised assessment more accurately reflects the current financial status of the parents. Under existing legislation, when an estimate of income is processed, the monthly child support liabilities for the whole year are revised. As a result, where a non-custodial parent has already paid more than the liability accrued under the revised assessment an overpayment to the custodial parent occurs.

However, the Government announced in the 1995-96 Budget that the child support legislation will be changed. Credit will be given for the total paid so far in the financial year and the non-custodial parent will only pay lower amounts for the rest of the year as a result of his or her estimated lower income. This will reduce the number of overpayments to custodial parents.
(2) I am unable to respond directly to this question due to secrecy provisions. The CSA can provide full details of how any debt figures have been calculated to the party concerned.

(3) In past years resourcing did not permit priority to be given to recovery of overpayments which occurred in these types of cases. It is now policy to advise clients when an overpayment occurs and an agreement is sought as to how the money is to be repaid.
(4) One of the types of arrangements which can be agreed to with a parent who has been overpaid is to repay the overpayment through reducing the amount of his or her current entitlement.

(5) The child support legislation is based on two concepts. First, children should share in their parents' changed financial circumstances, just as they would have if the parents had continued to live together. Secondly, both parents should support their children according to their capacities to pay. It follows that if the non-custodial parent's capacity to pay changes, the amount the parent is required to pay for child support should also change.

(6) The child support legislation does require a non-custodial parent to pay child support when he or she is in receipt of income and conversely, if he or she is unemployed that parent's obligations will be reduced. However, in a number of cases non-custodial parents do not inform the CSA when they lose their job and move onto unemployment benefits. This time difference can contribute to overpayments which are largely outside the control of the CSA. However, as the Government announced in the last Budget, there will be changes made to the way Department of Social Security (DSS) information is made available to the CSA. Enhanced information exchange facilities between DSS and CSA are being developed. This will include information about non-custodial parents who are in receipt of unemployment benefits.
(7) Any client who has been overpaid child support is required to repay that amount. As mentioned above, the CSA will discuss with the parent as to how the overpayment can be repaid.
(8) Authority to intercept tax refund cheques is provided under section 72 of the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988.
(9)(a) Again, case details cannot be disclosed. However, CSA policy is that tax refunds will only be intercepted where there is no arrangement to repay an overpayment.

(9)(b) A decision to repay a tax refund cheque which has already been intercepted is taken by reversing the Registrar's original decision. The authority to repay a tax refund which had been intercepted exists by reversing the Registrar's original decision to apply section 72 of the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Environment: Crib Point Oil Terminal

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 4 September 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the conditions of Foreign Investment Review Board approval of the Crib Point oil terminal proposal, that with respect to `the oil spill prevention and response strategy and plan for the facility, and the proposed baseline studies and investigations . . . taking account of the Ramsar values of Western Port Bay . . . These conditions require the proponent to consult with relevant State and Commonwealth agencies, in the preparation of the oil spill plan, to ensure that suitable strategies are in place to protect the important wetland values of Western Port Bay':

What strategies and procedures of precautions have been set in place by the Government to protect Australia's responsibilities under the Ramsar, Japan-Australia Migratory Birds Agreement and China-Australia Migratory Birds Agreement treaties, as required in this condition.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Consistent with the Intergovernmental Agreement on the Environment, activities relevant to the three international agreements referred to are under the control of State legislation in the waters of Western Port Bay. When the Environment Protection Agency responded to a request for advice from the

ANSWER.PARA: Foreign Investment Review Board concerning environmental aspects of the proposed site purchase, this advice was given on the understanding that the Victoria Government would fulfil its responsibilities, in terms of managing environmental issues relating to the overall project. For example, it is the Victorian Government which is responsible for responding to oil spills in State waters; it is the Victorian Government which has control of shipping within State waters; and it is the Victorian Government which has responsibility for implementing international nature conservation agreements on land and waters under its jurisdiction.

PARA.TAB: I have written to the Victorian Ministers for Planning and for Conservation and Environment, seeking their reconsideration of the need for an environmental impact assessment for this project under State processes.
